title: State v. Tyler
text:
<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Morris Tyler, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-063
  Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  4, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Brian Austin Katonak, of Aiken, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
          Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
          Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Morris Tyler was convicted 
  of four counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor.Â  
  On appeal, he asserts the circuit court erred in quashing a subpoena he served 
  on the Department of Social Services (DSS) and in failing to grant his motion 
  for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In May 2001, Tyler was indicted on four charges 
  of second-degree CSC with a minor occurring in August and November 2000.Â  The 
  victim of these crimes was a family member (â€œthe victimâ€).Â  As part of his defense, 
  Tyler issued a subpoena to DSS seeking â€œall documents and recordsâ€ regarding 
  the victim.Â  DSS moved to quash the subpoena, contending disclosure of the requested 
  records was prohibited under South Carolina law.Â  
During a hearing on the matter on January 11, 2002, 
  DSS informed the circuit court that the only file regarding the victim was opened 
  against the victimâ€™s mother for possible neglect, but it was determined to be 
  a Category I â€œunfoundedâ€ case.Â  DSS also indicated that, but for agency delay, 
  the file already would have been destroyed in accordance with statutory procedures.Â  
  The circuit court quashed the subpoena, ruling the applicable statutes barred 
  disclosure of the records because Tyler was not the subject of the DSS investigation.Â  
A jury trial was subsequently held on the four 
  CSC counts.Â  Tyler was convicted as charged and sentenced to life in prison 
  without parole.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Subpoena for DSS File
Tyler contends the circuit court erred in quashing 
  the subpoena because he was entitled to the DSS file even if he was not the 
  subject of the investigation; moreover, he asserts the courtâ€™s failure to conduct 
  an in camera review of the file violated his due process rights.Â  
  We disagree.
The South Carolina Code sets forth procedures for 
  handling reports of suspected child abuse or neglect. [1] Â  Section 20-7-650 requires DSS 
  to investigate a report of suspected child abuse or neglect to determine whether 
  the report is â€œindicatedâ€ or â€œunfounded.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-650(C) (Supp. 
  2001).Â  All â€œunfoundedâ€ cases must be classified as either Category I, II, or 
  III.Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-650(G).Â  Category I represents unfounded reports â€œin 
  which abuse and neglect were ruled out following the investigation.â€Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-650(G)(1).Â  
The file that Tyler wanted was determined to be 
  a Category I unfounded report, the disclosure of which is governed by section 
  20-7-695, which provides in relevant part as follows:
(B)Â  The alleged perpetrator in an unfounded report who 
  has reason to believe that the report was made maliciously or in bad faith has 
  the right to request in writing that records of the report be retained by 
  the department for up to two years from the date of the case decision.Â  The 
  written request must be received by the department within thirty days of the 
  personâ€™s receiving notice of the case decision.Â  A person exercising this 
  right may request a copy of the record of the unfounded case and the department 
  shall provide a copy of the record . . . .
. . . .
(D)Â  An alleged perpetrator in an unfounded case who 
  believes the report was made maliciously or in bad faith may petition the family 
  court to determine whether there is probable cause to believe that the reporter 
  acted maliciously or in bad faith.Â  The court shall determine probable cause 
  based on an in camera review of the case record and oral or written argument, 
  or both.Â  If the court finds probable cause, the identity of the reporter 
  must be disclosed to the moving party.
(E)Â  Notwithstanding other provisions of the law affecting 
  confidentiality of child protective services records and use and disclosure 
  of records of unfounded cases, a court conducting civil or criminal proceedings 
  resulting from disclosures authorized by this section may order the department 
  to release the record to any party to the case or to law enforcement.
Id. Â§ 20-7-695 (emphasis added).
Based on the foregoing, it is clear that the file 
  of an unfounded report may be released only to the alleged perpetrator who is 
  the subject of the investigation.Â  In this case, the subject of the investigation 
  was the victimâ€™s mother, not Tyler.Â  Thus, in the absence of a written request 
  from her, the file could not be disclosed.Â  An in camera review 
  of the report by the family court would have been necessary only if the subject 
  of the report had timely sought a determination of probable cause.Â  See id. Â§ 20-7-695(D).Â  
Further, Tyler is not entitled to the 
  file under section 20-7-695(E) because the criminal proceeding against him did 
  not result â€œfrom disclosures authorized by this section.â€Â  Rather, the criminal 
  charges resulted from law enforcementâ€™s investigation of his conduct.Â  The proceedings 
  referred to in section 20-7-695(E) concern those initiated by the subject of 
  an unfounded report who believes the original report was made maliciously or 
  in bad faith.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in quashing the subpoena.
II.Â  Directed Verdict
Tyler next contends the circuit court 
  erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We disagree.
A defendant is entitled to a directed 
  verdict when the State fails to present evidence of all of the elements of a 
  criminal offense.Â  See, e.g., State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 
  S.E.2d 30 (2001).Â  In ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial court is 
  concerned only with the existence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. 
  Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).Â  
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict 
  motion, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the State, and if there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial 
  evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find 
  the matter was properly presented to a jury.Â  McHoney, 344 S.C. at 97, 
  544 S.E.2d at 36.
In the current case, the victim testified 
  in detail regarding the four incidents of sexual molestation.Â  Moreover, her 
  testimony was corroborated by the testimony of her mother, school officials, 
  a desk clerk from the hotel where Tyler took the victim, and an investigating 
  officer from the Aiken County Sheriffâ€™s Office.
Tyler improperly asks us to evaluate the weight 
  of the evidence presented at trial, which is not the proper standard for submission 
  of the matter to the jury.Â  We hold the circuit court properly found there was 
  sufficient evidence to create a jury question as to Tylerâ€™s guilt or innocence.Â  
  Consequently, the circuit court committed no error in denying Tylerâ€™s motion 
  for a directed verdict.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.


 [1] Â  Citations are to the statutes in effect at the time of the hearing 
  since the legislature subsequently amended some of these provisions.Â  See 2002 Act No. 325, Â§ 5, effective June 7, 2002.Â  The amendments do not affect 
  our result.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Barbara Hyland Davis, Appellant/Respondent,
        v.
        Randall L. Davis, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-064
  Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  5, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART and REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
        David A. Wilson and Kenneth C. Porter, both of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
        Elizabeth Kimberly Berry, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Barbara Hyland Davis 
  (Wife) and Randall K. Davis (Husband) appeal from several aspects of a divorce 
  decree.Â  We affirm in part and remand in part.
FACTS
The parties married in May 1984 and separated 
  in October 1998.Â  They have two sons, born in 1990 and 1992. At the time of 
  the final divorce hearing, Husband was thirty-eight years old, and Wife was 
  thirty-nine years old. Both parties were employed during the marriage.Â  Husband 
  has a bachelorâ€™s degree in engineering and was employed at Design/Build Engineers, 
  Inc., a company in which he holds an ownership interest. Wife has a masterâ€™s 
  degree in business administration and, at the time of separation, was employed 
  in the accounting department at the Michelin Corporation. 
Wife instituted this action against Husband 
  in November 1998 seeking an order of separate maintenance and support, equitable 
  apportionment of marital property and debts, alimony, custody, and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs. Husband answered and counterclaimed, seeking custody of the 
  children and equitable apportionment of marital property and debts. 
At the commencement of the case, Wife moved 
  to exclude the testimony of Husbandâ€™s expert witness, James F. Joyner, III, 
  on the issue of the valuation of Husbandâ€™s business interests.Â  Wifeâ€™s basis 
  for this motion was that a pre-trial order required all expert witnesses be 
  named no later than twenty-one days before trial and Husband named Joyner only 
  twenty days before trial. [1]  Despite Wifeâ€™s objection to Joynerâ€™s testimony on the valuation of Husbandâ€™s 
  business interests, she consented to Joynerâ€™s testimony on the issues of Husbandâ€™s 
  income and income potential and Wifeâ€™s need for alimony. The family court granted 
  Wifeâ€™s motion to exclude Joynerâ€™s testimony on the valuation of Husbandâ€™s business 
  interests, but allowed Joyner to testify as to the other issues.Â  Husband proffered 
  Joynerâ€™s testimony on the valuation of his business interests.Â  
The family court granted Wife a divorce 
  from Husband on the grounds of one yearâ€™s continuous separation; ordered Husband 
  to pay quarterly installments of $4,729.75 in rehabilitative alimony for two 
  years; granted joint custody of the minor children to Husband and Wife, with 
  primary placement of the children being awarded to Husband; valued and equitably 
  apportioned marital property and debts; and denied Wifeâ€™s request for attorney 
  fees. 
Husband moved for reconsideration under 
  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, arguing the family court erred by excluding the testimony 
  of his expert witness regarding the value of his business interests, and in 
  applying low minority shareholder and marketability discounts to those interests.Â  
  The family court issued an order increasing the amount of the minority shareholder 
  and marketability discounts, but not to the extent that Husband asserted the 
  discounts should be applied.Â  The court denied Husbandâ€™s request to reconsider 
  its decision to exclude the testimony of his expert witness.Â Â  Both Husband 
  and Wife appeal. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, 
  this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of 
  the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 
  471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require 
  us to disregard the findings of the court below. Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family 
  court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. McAlister 
  v. Patterson, 278 S.C. 481, 483, 299 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1982).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Equitable Distribution
 Husband and wife agreed to distribute 
  their marital property equally; however, on appeal the parties argue the family 
  court erred in valuing Husbandâ€™s minority interests in two businesses and in 
  valuing a 1998 Harley-Davidson Motorcycle.Â  We address the valuation of the 
  two businesses and the motorcycle separately.
A.Â Valuation of Design/Build and DBE
As a threshold 
  matter, Husband argues in his cross-appeal that the family court abused its 
  discretion in refusing to admit the testimony of his valuation expert, Joyner, 
  as to the value of Husbandâ€™s interest in Design/Build Engineers, Inc. and DBE 
  Partnership, LLP.Â  We agree. 
The admission of expert testimony and 
  other evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the family court 
  judge and absent a clear abuse of discretion, the family courtâ€™s ruling will 
  not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five, 
  352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002).Â  
The family court excluded Joynerâ€™s testimony 
  on the grounds that Husband failed to designate Joyner as an expert witness 
  at least twenty-one days before the final hearing, as required by a pre-trial 
  order entered by the court. It is undisputed that Husband first notified Wife 
  of his intent to call Joyner as an expert twenty days before the final hearing 
  was scheduled. 
Rule 16(b) of the South Carolina Rules 
  of Civil Procedure grants the family court wide latitude to establish rules 
  regarding the conduct of discovery in each case, including the authority to 
  prescribe the time periods for identifying the exhibits or witnesses to be presented 
  at trial.Â  These pre-trial orders control the subsequent course of the case, 
  â€œunless modified on motion, or at the trial to prevent manifest injustice.â€Â  
  Rule 16(b), SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, a pre-trial order should not be blindly followed, 
  but should instead be applied in a manner that best serves the ends of fairness 
  and judicial economy.Â  See James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil 
  Procedure 137 (2d ed. 1996) (â€œThe language [of Rule 16, SCRCP], particularly 
  the â€˜manifest injusticeâ€™ standard for modifying the order, suggests that good 
  reason should be required for any changes.Â  The order should not be followed 
  blindly.â€). 
Our courts have held that the exclusion 
  of a witness is a severe sanction that should not be imposed lightly or summarily. See Kramer v. Kramer, 323 S.C. 212, 217, 473 S.E.2d 846, 848-49 
  (Ct. App. 1996) (finding that a court may exclude a witness â€œonly after the 
  court inquires into (1) the type of witness involved; (2) the content of the 
  evidence to be presented; (3) the nature of the failure to identify the witness; 
  and (4) the degree of surprise to the other party.â€).Â  The issue of excluding 
  a witness based on a pretrial order came before this court under similar facts 
  in Jumper v. Hawkins, 348 S.C. 142, 558 S.E.2d 911 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  In Jumper, the family court excluded a witness when the party failed 
  to comply with the pre-trial order requiring all witnesses to be designated 
  at least ten days before trial.Â  There, the opposing party was not informed 
  of the excluded witness until, at the latest, eight days before trial. Id. at 144, 558 S.E.2d at 912.Â  In finding the family court abused its discretion 
  by excluding the witness, this court stated:
We hold that even in the face 
  of a pre-trial order mandating the disclosure of a witness by a certain date, 
  a trial judge is required to consider and evaluate the following factors before 
  imposing the sanction of exclusion of a witness: 

  (1) the type of witness involved; 
  (2) the content of the evidence 
    emanating from the proffered witness; 
  (3) the nature of the failure 
    or neglect or refusal to furnish the witnessâ€™ name; 
  (4) the degree of surprise to 
    the other party, including the prior knowledge of the name of the witness; and 
  (5) the prejudice to the opposing 
    party.

  Id. at 152, 558 S.E.2d at 916. [2] 
In the present case, the record 
  provides no indication that the family court adequately considered these factors 
  when deciding to exclude Joynerâ€™s valuation testimony.Â  As an expert in valuing 
  closely-held corporations, Joynerâ€™s testimony would have been highly probative 
  on the question of the proper valuation methodology to apply in this case.Â  
  Husbandâ€™s failure to comply with the terms of the pre-trial order by one day 
  resulted in little surprise or cognizable prejudice to Wifeâ€™s case.Â  Wifeâ€™s 
  own expert and attorney had ample time to meet with Joyner and did, in fact, 
  question Joyner the day before trial.Â  Furthermore, Wife consented to the admission 
  of Joynerâ€™s testimony on the issue of determining salary for purposes of awarding 
  alimony.Â  As such, we find the family court erred in excluding the testimony 
  of Husbandâ€™s expert witness.
Moreover, we cannot say 
  the family courtâ€™s exclusion of Husbandâ€™s expert witness was harmless.Â  Joynerâ€™s 
  proffered testimony suggested applying a thirty percent minority discount and 
  twenty percent marketability discount to Husbandâ€™s interest in DBE.Â  As to husbandâ€™s 
  other business interest in Design/Build, Joyner suggested applying a twenty-five 
  percent minority discount and a thirty percent marketability discount to Husbandâ€™s 
  interest.Â Â  Even after increasing the minority and marketability discounts pursuant 
  to Husbandâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the family courtâ€™s discounts were less 
  than the discounts Husbandâ€™s expert would have recommended in his testimony.Â  
Therefore, we find the family court abused 
  its discretion by excluding the testimony of Husbandâ€™s expert witness.Â  Accordingly, 
  we do not reach the merits of the partiesâ€™ arguments as to the family courtâ€™s 
  valuation of Husbandâ€™s interests in Design/Build and DBE.Â  Instead, we remand 
  this issue to the family court so that the testimony of Husbandâ€™s expert may 
  be admitted and given full consideration.Â  In remanding, we do not make any 
  finding as to the propriety of applying discounts to Husbandâ€™s interest in Design/Build 
  and DBE.Â  Rather, we remand for a de novo determination of the 
  value of these assets, including Husbandâ€™s claim that discounts should be utilized.
B. Valuation of the Motorcycle
Wife also contests 
  the family courtâ€™s valuation of Husbandâ€™s motorcycle.Â  She first argues the 
  family court erred by relying too heavily on Husbandâ€™s testimony.Â  We disagree.Â  
At the final hearing, Wife testified 
  that the purchase price of the motorcycle in 1998 was $8,300.Â  She further testified 
  that she did not feel that the motorcycle had depreciated in value at all over 
  time and that its current value remained at $8,300.Â  Husband agreed he had paid 
  $8,320 when he purchased the motorcycle, but testified the motorcycle had sustained 
  body damage after being accidentally dropped, and that the damage had not been 
  repaired at the time of the hearing.Â  Husband also admitted evidence, over Wifeâ€™s 
  objection, that the Kelly Blue Book value as of the date of the hearing for 
  that make and model motorcycle with no damage was $4,835.Â  The family court 
  ultimately valued the motorcycle at this blue book amount.
â€œThe credibility of testimony is a matter 
  for the fact finder to judge.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Forrester, 
  282 S.C. 512, 516, 320 S.E.2d 39, 42 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In this case, the family 
  court was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the partiesâ€™ testimony.Â  
  Accordingly, we find no reason to conclude the family court erred in its consideration 
  of Husbandâ€™s testimony on this issue.
Wife also argues the family court improperly 
  relied on the blue book value of the motorcycle in assessing its value.Â  She 
  claims the $4,835 amount quoted does not accurately reflect the value of the 
  motorcycle in the present case because that blue book figure represented the 
  â€œwholesale trade-inâ€ value of the bike.Â  This argument was not presented to 
  the trial court and is therefore not preserved for appeal.Â  See Staubes 
  v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œ[A]n 
  issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
  Wife objected to the admission of the blue book figure because the value quoted 
  in the blue book was the value of the motorcycle in March 2000, over a year 
  after the commencement of the marital litigation in this case.Â  Wife asserts 
  this argument on appeal.Â  However, we find the date of the blue book value goes 
  to the weight of the evidence and not its sufficiency.Â Â  The weight to be given 
  to evidence lies within the province of the fact finder.Â  Bailey v. Bailey, 
  293 S.C. 451, 453, 361 S.E.2d 348, 350 (1987).Â  Because the family court was 
  in a better position to weigh the evidence presented at trial, we find the court 
  did not err in assessing the value of the motorcycle.
II. Alimony
Wife next argues the family court erred 
  by awarding her rehabilitative alimony rather than permanent periodic alimony.Â  
  Section 20-3-130(C)(8) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2002) requires a court, 
  in awarding alimony, to consider, inter alia, â€œthe marital and nonmarital 
  properties of the parties, including those apportioned to him or her in the 
  divorce or separate maintenance action.â€Â  Although we do not hold that an award 
  of rehabilitative alimony is improper in this case, we find the amount of the 
  rehabilitative alimony awarded was at least partially predicated on an amount 
  of money Wife had previously received from her interest in Design/Build and 
  DBE.Â  In light of our decision to remand the issue of equitable division of 
  marital property, we remand the issue of alimony to the family court.
III. Child Custody
Wife argues the family court erred in 
  awarding Husband primary placement of the partiesâ€™ minor children. We disagree.
In all child custody disputes, 
  the paramount considerations are the childâ€™s welfare and best interests. Cook 
  v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978). In awarding custody, 
  the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact the childâ€™s 
  life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional, 
  and recreational aspects.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 11, 471 S.E.2d 
  154, 157 (1996).Â  Additionally, the court must assess how each partyâ€™s character, 
  fitness, and attitude affect the child. Id.Â  Indeed, â€œwhen determining 
  to whom custody shall be awarded, all the conflicting rules and presumptions 
  should be weighed together with all of the circumstances of the particular case, 
  and all relevant factors must be taken into consideration.â€ Id.Â  
In this case, Husband has had 
  primary placement of the children since September 1999.Â  Our courts have considered 
  a parentâ€™s history as the primary caretaker to be an important factor in determining 
  which parent is best suited to receive custody of a child.Â  See Smith 
  v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 197, 363 S.E.2d 404, 406 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding 
  that the fact the wife had custody of the children since the partiesâ€™ separation 
  â€œalone supports the trial courtâ€™s decision in this instance to place the children 
  in the wifeâ€™s custodyâ€); West v. West, 294 S.C. 190, 193, 363 S.E.2d 
  402, 403 (Ct. App. 1987) (awarding custody to the husband after finding that 
  he had been the primary caretaker of the children in the months prior to separation); 
  Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina: Substantive Law 433 (3d ed. 2001) (â€œThere is an assumption that custody will be awarded to the 
  parent who has been the primary caretaker of the children, unless unfitnessÂ  
  is proved or there is other evidence that the welfare of a child will be better 
  served by awarding custody to the other parentâ€).
Additionally, the evidence supports 
  the family courtâ€™s finding that Husband has taken a more active role in the 
  daily lives of the children.Â  Husband was primarily responsible for getting 
  the children ready each morning and taking them to school or daycare.Â  He also 
  shared in the responsibility of picking up the children after school, and served 
  as the primary facilitator of the childrenâ€™s after-school sports activities.Â  
 Furthermore, the family court 
  found Husband has been able to manage the childrenâ€™s behavior more appropriately 
  than Wife. This conclusion is supported by the observations and recommendations 
  of independent experts contained in the record.Â  The guardian ad litem concluded 
  that:
Based upon [the psychologistâ€™s] 
  report and the partiesâ€™ actions during this litigation, I believe the father 
  will allow the mother to participate in the childrenâ€™s lives.Â  It does not appear 
  the mother will allow the father to do so. The report also indicates the children 
  have fewer behavioral problems with the father and therefore a more stable environment. 
Indeed, the psychologistâ€™s report states that â€œ[Wife] 
  does appear to be much less able to behaviorally manage the children . . . .Â  
  I would not judge her to be seriously deficient in this area, but in comparison 
  to [Husband] she is clearly less well-equipped.â€ 
Therefore, under the facts and circumstances 
  of this case, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s decision to award primary 
  placement of the children to Husband.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing 
  reasons, we affirm the family courtâ€™s valuation of Husbandâ€™s motorcycle and 
  determination of child custody.Â Â  However, as to the valuation of the Husbandâ€™s 
  business interests, we remand to the family court for consideration of Husbandâ€™s 
  expert testimony.Â  Because we remand a portion of the equitable division of 
  marital property, we also remand the issue of alimony.
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.



   [1] Wifeâ€™s own expert and attorney met with Joyner 
    and questioned him the day before trial.


   [2] The final hearing in this case came to a conclusion 
    on April 13, 2000.Â  The opinion in Jumper was decided on December 17, 
    2001, more than one year after the final hearing.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Jermaine Harris, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

AFFIRMED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-065
  Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  5, 2004


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
          General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of 
          Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Jermaine Harris was 
  convicted of murder, assault and battery with intent to kill, armed robbery, 
  and possession of a weapon during a crime of violence in connection with the 
  robbery of a convenience store that left one of the storeâ€™s owners dead and 
  the other injured.Â  He appeals, asserting error in the trial courtâ€™s exclusion 
  of extrinsic impeachment evidence and in its refusal to charge the jury on mere 
  knowledge. We affirm.
FACTS
Around 11:00 p.m. on December 21, 1999, Perry Loyd 
  and his wife were closing up the B & D convenience store they owned.Â  Mrs. 
  Loyd waited in their truck while Mr. Loyd locked the storeâ€™s door.Â  As he locked 
  the door, an individual holding a gun surprised him and told Mr. Loyd to â€œgive 
  it up.â€Â  The individual then fired two shots.Â  Mr. Loyd backed away from the 
  storefront and pulled out his gun.Â  A second individual then moved toward Mr. 
  Loyd, stumbled, and fired his gun at Mr. Loyd.Â  A third individual then came 
  around the side of the store, raised his gun, and fired two shots at Mr. Loyd, 
  hitting him directly below the knee.Â  Mr. Loyd was shot a total of six times 
  from three different guns.Â  Mrs. Loyd died from a gunshot wound to the head.
Mr. Loyd identified Rashaun Brooks as the first shooter, 
  Paris McLeod as the second shooter, and Harris as the third shooter.Â  All three 
  defendants were arrested shortly after the robbery upon Mr. Loydâ€™s positive 
  identification.Â  
At the residence where the three defendants were 
  arrested, the police also arrested Leroy Porter on separate and unrelated charges.Â  
  Porter approached the investigating officers after he was arrested.Â  As a result 
  of the conversation, the officers went to Young Street in an attempt to locate 
  the guns used in the robbery.Â  After the first attempt failed, Officer Gardner 
  asked Porter to wear a hidden microphone and record a conversation with Rashaun 
  Brooks to get a lead on the location of the guns.Â  After reviewing the recorded 
  conversation, the police located a Mack 90 rifle that was positively connected 
  to the shells recovered from the scene.
At trial, Officer Gardner was asked on cross-examination 
  whether he previously stated that he had reached an agreement with Porter.Â  
  Gardner denied having made such a statement.Â  The trial attorney representing 
  Paris McLeod then sought to introduce the testimony of John Davis to show that 
  Gardner, in fact, previously stated that a deal had been reached with Porter.Â  
  The trial court sustained the solicitorâ€™s objection that the testimony was improper 
  impeachment testimony.Â  All three defendants joined in the proposed impeachment 
  proffer.Â  
After hearing the proposed jury instructions, the 
  defense argued the trial court should charge that mere knowledge, in addition 
  to mere presence and mere association, was also insufficient to justify a conviction.Â  
  The court denied the motion, and charged the jury on mere presence and association, 
  but not mere knowledge.Â  The jury found Harris guilty, and he was sentenced 
  to thirty years for murder, seven years consecutive for assault and battery 
  with intent to kill, five years concurrent for armed robbery, and five years 
  concurrent for possession of a weapon during a crime of violence.Â  This appeal 
  follows.
ISSUES
1.Â  Did the trial court err in refusing to allow extrinsic 
  impeachment evidence about whether an agreement had been entered into with Leroy 
  Porter?Â  
2. Â Did the trial court err in refusing to instruct the 
  jury that mere knowledge was insufficient to establish guilt?Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Impeachment Evidence
Harris asserts the trial court erred in refusing to 
  admit extrinsic evidence contradicting the testimony of one of the Stateâ€™s witnesses.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
Rule 613(b), SCRE, provides, in part: 

  Extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement by a 
    witness is not admissible unless the witness is advised of the substance of 
    the statement, the time and place it was allegedly made, and the person to whom 
    it was made, and is given the opportunity to explain or deny the statement. 
    If a witness does not admit that he has made the prior inconsistent statement, 
    extrinsic evidence of such statement is admissible.

Accordingly, â€œ[e]very witness under cross-examination 
  may be asked whether he has made any former statements relative to the subject 
  matter of the action and inconsistent with his present testimony.â€Â  Aakjer 
  v. Spagnoli, 291 S.C. 165, 170, 352 S.E.2d 503, 507 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  In 
  order to contradict a witness by introducing a prior statement, a foundation 
  must be laid putting the witness on notice.Â  McMillan v. Ridges, 229 
  S.C. 76, 79-80, 91 S.E.2d 883, 884 (1956).Â  This notice requirement is â€œmet 
  when the cross-examiner advises the witness of the substance of the prior statement,â€ 
  the time and place of the statement, and the person to whom the statement was 
  made.Â  State v. Galloway, 263 S.C. 585, 591, 211 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1975).Â  
  The standard of review for the admissibility of evidence limits reversal by 
  this court to situations amounting to an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Saltz, 
  346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001).Â  
In this case, Harrisâ€™s co-defendant sought to contradict 
  Officer Gardnerâ€™s denial that Gardner and Leroy Porter made an agreement.Â  The 
  record indicates defense counsel alleged the conversation occurred in the solicitorâ€™s 
  office, but the proffered testimony suggests the location was elsewhere.Â  Furthermore, 
  defense counsel could only pinpoint the alleged statement to being â€œduring the 
  course of the investigation.â€Â  Reviewing the admissibility of this evidence 
  under the abuse of discretion standard, we cannot conclude that the trial court 
  erred in excluding this evidence where the prerequisites of the notice requirement 
  in Rule 613(b), SCRE, were not satisfied.
Mere Knowledge Instruction
Harris asserts the trial court erred 
  in refusing to include a jury charge that a defendantâ€™s mere knowledge that 
  a crime was going to occur is insufficient to constitute guilt.Â  After hearing 
  the trial courtâ€™s proposed jury instructions, the defense argued the court should 
  charge that mere knowledge, in addition to mere presence and mere association, 
  was also insufficient to justify a conviction. Â The court denied the motion.Â  
The evidence presented at trial determines the 
  law with which the jury should be charged.Â  Although a trial court â€œcommits 
  reversible error when it fails to give a requested charge on an issue raised 
  by the indictment and evidence presented,â€ the court should charge the jury 
  with only the law applicable to the case.Â  State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 
  364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 835-36 (1989).Â  Superfluous and inapplicable instructions 
  should be meticulously avoided, for the purpose of jury instructions is to enlighten 
  the jury; redundant instructions and those not in conformance with the facts 
  of a case only operate to imbue unwarranted confusion in the minds of jurors.Â  State v. Fair, 209 S.C. 439, 445, 40 S.E.2d 634, 637 (1946); see also State v. Franklin, 299 S.C. 133, 382 S.E.2d 911 (1989).
Although Harrisâ€™s proposed charge that 
  mere knowledge a crime is going to be committed does not, in and of itself, 
  establish guilt is a correct statement of law, an additional instruction to 
  that affect would be of no particular relevance to this case.Â  In State v. 
  Collins, 266 S.C. 566, 570, 225 S.E.2d 189, 192 (1976), the mere knowledge 
  charge was necessitated by the fact that there was evidence that the defendant 
  could not have been the principal to the armed robbery because he was in jail 
  at the time the store was robbed.Â  In this case, there is evidence of Harrisâ€™s 
  presence at the scene.Â  In addition to the testimony that Harris had prior knowledge 
  that a crime was going to be committed against the Loyds, Mr. Loydâ€™s testimony 
  placed Harris at the scene as one of the individuals who shot him.Â  There is 
  no indication anywhere in the record of the impossibility of Harrisâ€™s participation 
  or that he was not present at the scene.Â  The trial court acted appropriately 
  in denying the request to charge on mere knowledge.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Harrisâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Clarence Huell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-066
  Heard January 14, 
  2004 â€“ Filed February 6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
          General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Cecil Kelley Jackson, 
          of Sumter; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Clarence Huell was convicted 
  of murder, possession of a weapon in the commission of a violent crime, and 
  two counts of assault and battery.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to thirty 
  years imprisonment for murder, five years imprisonment for possession of a firearm 
  in the commission of a violent crime, and thirty days imprisonment for each 
  count of simple assault. Â Huell appeals, asserting error in: (1) the exclusion 
  of evidence; and (2) the Stateâ€™s closing argument.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  
FACTS
On November 5, 2000, the Williamsburg County Sheriffâ€™s 
  Department responded to a dispatch regarding a shooting at the home of Jeanette 
  Wilsonâ€™s mother.Â  Wilson was Clarence Huellâ€™s estranged girlfriend.Â  She had 
  been with the victim, Joseph Lesane, at a club earlier when Huell asked her 
  not to take Lesane to her house.Â  Huell subsequently came to the house, and 
  an altercation ensued between Wilson and Huell.Â  Huell also struck Wilsonâ€™s 
  mother, Emma.Â  Huell kept a nine-millimeter pistol in his car.Â  Â Â After 
  Wilson went into the house to call police, two gunshots were heard.Â  The shooting 
  resulted in the Lesaneâ€™s death.Â  The police were unable to find any witnesses 
  who saw the incident involving Huell and Lesane.Â Â  
Huell was indicted for murder, possession of a 
  weapon in the commission of a violent crime, and two counts of assault and battery 
  of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Huell admitted killing Lesane, but claimed 
  he did so in self-defense.Â  According to Huell, Lesane attempted to run over 
  him with the car.Â  Huell claimed that the gun had accidentally discharged after 
  he had been hit by Lesaneâ€™s car and was hanging on the hood.Â  The jury convicted 
  him on all charges, and he was sentenced.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court 
  sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 147, 
  199 S.E.2d 61, 65 (1973).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings 
  unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 
  452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 I.  Relevant Evidence 
Huell argues the trial court 
  erred by refusing to allow the defense to cross-examine the pathologist who 
  performed the autopsy, Dr. Susan McConnell, about a portion of the autopsy report 
  for the purpose of reflecting the inadequate investigation conducted by law 
  enforcement.Â  We agree, but find exclusion of the testimony was harmless error.Â Â  
The defense argued that numerous 
  errors by law enforcement in the investigation were all relevant to the juryâ€™s 
  determination of whether the State had proven its case beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  
  The defense presented considerable evidence in this regard.Â  The defense theory 
  of an inadequate investigation consisted of the failure to maintain clothing, 
  the failure to process the vehicle, and the failure to utilize the technical 
  services of SLED.Â  
Dr. McConnell performed the autopsy of 
  the victim and testified as a Stateâ€™s witness.Â  At trial, she was qualified 
  as an expert in forensic pathology and testified that the victim died of a single 
  gunshot wound.Â  She testified that the gunshot had been â€œfrom an indeterminate 
  range.â€Â  On cross-examination, Dr. McConnell admitted she usually got 
  the victimâ€™s clothing at the time of the autopsy.Â  She said, â€œthe clothing can 
  be sent to SLED for evaluation of gunshot residue et cetera, et cetera.Â  We 
  like to see the clothing so if we want to see something, so we could, you know, 
  try to make a determination.â€Â  In this case, she did not receive any clothing 
  from law enforcement.Â  Â Â 
When defense counsel began to question 
  Dr. McConnell about the contents of the autopsy report, particularly a statement 
  in the report from the deputy coroner, the State objected on the basis of hearsay 
  and relevance.Â  Â Â Outside the presence of the jury, defense counsel referenced 
  the statement in the autopsy report that a suspect and weapon were in the custody 
  of the sheriffâ€™s department.Â  It is undisputed that this information was false.Â  
  The State did not contest the fact that the information was given to Dr. McConnell.Â  
  In fact, â€œthere was no weapon foundâ€ and no suspect was in custody at the time.Â  
  Defense counsel argued it was relevant to the case in terms of additional evidence 
  bearing upon the defense strategy challenging the quality of the investigation 
  performed by law enforcement.Â  Thus, Huell sought admissibility based on the 
  falsity of the information.Â  The trial judge excluded the testimony as hearsay.Â  
Pursuant to Rule 801(c) SCRE, hearsay is â€œa statement, 
  other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, 
  offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Since the relevancy 
  of the evidence was grounded in its falsity, it was not hearsay.Â  The purpose 
  of eliciting this portion of the autopsy report from the pathologist was to 
  establish yet another example of the alleged inadequate investigation by law 
  enforcement.Â  
Even assuming it was error to exclude the evidence, 
  such error was harmless.Â  See State v. McWee, 322 S.C. 387, 393, 
  472 S.E.2d 235, 239 (1996);Â  State v. Benning, 338 S.C. 59, 64, 524 S.E.2d 
  852, 856 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding that an accused cannot avail himself of error 
  as a ground for reversal where the error has not been prejudicial to him).Â  
  We find the exclusion of the testimony was harmless, because it was cumulative 
  to other evidence bearing upon Huellâ€™s challenge to the investigation by law 
  enforcement, such as the failure of law enforcement to preserve clothing, to 
  process the vehicle, and to utilize the technical services of SLED.Â  Huellâ€™s 
  counsel acknowledged at oral argument that the excluded evidence was additional evidence supporting Huellâ€™s claim of an inadequate investigation by law enforcement.Â  
  We view the excluded evidence in the autopsy report as cumulative, and thus 
  conclude Huell was not legally prejudiced by its exclusion.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
II. Closing Argument 
During closing argument, the solicitor 
  noted the close proximity of the bullet holes in the windshield.Â  The solicitor 
  argued the proximity of the bullet holes reflected the steady position of the 
  pistol when Huell shot Lesane.Â  This, according to the solicitor, supported 
  the Stateâ€™s theory of the killing as a murder and mitigated against Huellâ€™s 
  claim of self-defense.Â  The solicitorâ€™s argument rested in part on what he referred 
  to as the lack of â€œrecoil.â€Â  The solicitor argued:Â Â Â  
STATE:Â  . . . Common sense would 
  tell you that if a gun is in a steady position and it is laying right here, 
  and itâ€™s in a vice, and you pulled the trigger once, that gun canâ€™t move because 
  itâ€™s in that vice . . . But if a person would hold a gun, a recoil would 
  make the gun move some.Â Â  And the pattern is ---
DEFENSE:Â  Objection, Your Honor.
STATE:Â  ---more erratic.
DEFENSE:Â  Objection, arguing facts that are not in evidence.
THE COURT:Â  Objection is overruled.
STATE:Â  . . . Now you look at the gunshots on that automobile.Â  
  That gun, I submit to you, was not doing a whole lot of moving.Â  It was moving 
  some, but it wasnâ€™t doing the kind of moving that if you had a man hanging on 
  for dear life on a vehicle like he was saying he was doing, that gun would have 
  been all around, everywhere . . . And those bullets would have been all 
  over everywhere. 
But where have you got them?Â  
  Youâ€™ve got them right in a row there.Â  Right near where the driver was seated.Â  
  And I submit to you that the more likely thing was the fellow was standing there 
  pumping the bullets in him . . . he intended to kill him.Â  
(emphasis added)
Our review of the closing argument is based on 
  whether the solicitorâ€™s comments so infected the trial with unfairness as to 
  make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  State v. Durden, 
  264 S.C. 86, 93, 212 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1975).Â  State v. Caldwell, 300 
  S.C. 494, 504, 388 S.E.2d 816, 822 (1990);Â  State v. Davis, 309 S.C. 
  326, 347, 422 S.E.2d 133, 146 (1992), overruled on other grounds by Brightman 
  v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 520 S.E.2d 614 (1999).Â  The Stateâ€™s closing argument 
  must be confined to evidence in the record and the reasonable inferences that 
  may be drawn from the evidence.Â  State v. Huggins, 325 S.C. 103, 107, 
  481 S.E.2d 114, 116 (1997); State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 326, 468 
  S.E.2d 620, 625 (1996); State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 312, 278 S.E.2d 
  335, 339 (1981).Â  The trial court is vested with broad discretion in determining 
  the propriety of counselâ€™s closing arguments and will not be disturbed absent 
  a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v.Â  Raffaldt, 318 S.C. 110, 
  114, 456 S.E.2d 390, 393 (1995).Â  
Huell argues the solicitorâ€™s argument was outside 
  the record and that he used his â€œexpertiseâ€ to argue the mechanical workings 
  of a firearm.Â  This was at odds with Huellâ€™s testimony that the gun had accidentally 
  discharged after he had been hit by Lesaneâ€™s car and was hanging on the hood.Â  Â 
In light of Huellâ€™s testimony, especially his version 
  of his position on the hood of the moving car at the time he shot Lesane, we 
  find the prosecutorâ€™s comments did not infect the trial with unfairness as to 
  make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  According to Huell:Â  
When [Lesane] tried to run over me, I had jump up.Â  And the 
  car struck me on this knee.Â  And thatâ€™s when it throwed me up against the windshield 
  of the car.Â  My head hit the car again, and the gun went off.Â  So he get on 
  the brakes to try to throw me off the car.Â  But by my hand, left hand, it had 
  me in between the hood and the windshield of the car.Â  It caused me to slide 
  down on the car hood.Â  And I pulled myself back from the car.Â  He take off again.Â  
  Thatâ€™s when I raised the gun up, and I shot the gun again.
We believe it is within a reasonable jurorâ€™s common 
  knowledge that if a firearm is discharged by an individual in the situation 
  described by Huell, the resulting location of the shots will tend to be varied.Â  
  One may reasonably infer that it is less likely, under such a scenario, for 
  the shots to be located in a straight line.Â  We believe the solicitorâ€™s comments 
  concerning recoil in the context of Huellâ€™s testimony fell within the range 
  of a reasonable inference from the evidence.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, based on the reasons set forth above, 
  Huellâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, J.J., concur.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Lee,        Appellant.

Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â Affirmed pursuant 
  to South Carolina Rules of Appellate Practice, Rule 220, and the following authorities:Â  
  As to Leeâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel:Â  McNeil v. Wisconsin, 
  501 U.S. 171, 175 (1991) (â€œThe Sixth Amendment right . . . is offense specific. 
  It cannot be invoked once for all future prosecutions, for it does not attach 
  until a prosecution is commenced, that is, â€˜at or after the initiation of adversary 
  judicial criminal proceedings--whether by way of formal charge, preliminary 
  hearing, indictment, information, or arraignment.â€™â€) (quoting United States 
  v. Gouveia, 467 U.S. 180, 188 (1984)); Texas v. Cobb, 532 U.S. 162, 
  173 (2001) (holding when the Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches, it only 
  encompasses the charged offense and any other offenses that would be considered 
  the same for purposes of double jeopardy); State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 
  661-62, 552 S.E.2d 745, 757-58 (2001) (adopting Texas v. Cobb); State 
  v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 15, 515 S.E.2d 508, 515 (1999) (holding the Sixth 
  Amendment right attaches only â€œpost-indictmentâ€); State v. George, 323 
  S.C. 496, 509, 476 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1996) (holding, although defendant was in 
  custody, defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel had not attached, where 
  he had not been indicted and judicial proceedings had not been initiated).
As to Leeâ€™s Fifth Amendment protection against 
  self-incrimination:Â  State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 58, 543 S.E.2d 
  541, 546 (2001) (holding short, conclusory statements are insufficient to preserve 
  an issue for appellate review); State v. Colf, 332 S.C. 313, 332, 504 
  S.E.2d 360, 364 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding a conclusory, two-paragraph argument 
  that cited no authority other than an evidentiary rule was deemed abandoned 
  on appeal).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Oscar Franklin DuBose, Jr.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kathy Sarnowski, f/k/a Kathy D. DuBose,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Donna S. Strom, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-078
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Jean Perrin Derrick, of Lexington, for Appellant.
Carolyn B. Steigner and Daun C. Steigner, both of Lexington, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM: In this domestic case, 
  Frank DuBose (â€œFatherâ€) sued Kathy Sarnowski (â€œMotherâ€), seeking a change of 
  custody following Motherâ€™s move with her new husband to Kentucky.Â  The family 
  court found a change of circumstances occurred and granted a change of custody 
  to Father.Â  Additionally, the family court granted Fatherâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  Mother appeals, arguing the family court erred by:Â  1) finding a change 
  of circumstances occurred based solely upon Motherâ€™s move from South Carolina 
  to Kentucky; 2) excluding evidence of the childrenâ€™s custody preference; 3) 
  excluding evidence of Fatherâ€™s past violent acts; 4) awarding Father attorneyâ€™s 
  fees; and 5) refusing to award Mother attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Father and Mother were divorced in 2000, and pursuant to 
  an agreement later incorporated into a divorce decree, Mother was granted sole 
  custody of the children.Â  The divorce decree also provided that if Mother intended 
  to move out of the state with the children, she could only do so after giving 
  Father seventy-five days notice.Â  
On March 3, 2000, Mother gave Father written notice of her 
  intent to move out of the state with the children.Â  However, she did not provide 
  Father with information as to where she was moving.Â  On May 18 or 19, 2000, 
  Mother left South Carolina with the intention of permanently moving to Kentucky 
  with her new husband.Â  
Father filed a summons and complaint seeking custody of the 
  children, and following a hearing at which Mother did not appear, the family 
  court awarded Father temporary custody.Â  
At the final hearing, the family court found that a substantial 
  change of circumstances occurred, and the best interests of the children would 
  be served by awarding custody to Father.Â  Additionally, the court awarded Father 
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Mother appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn appeal from an order of the family court, this 
  court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 304, 
  540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require 
  this Court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Greene v. Greene, 
  351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  Rather, because this 
  Court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should give 
  great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility 
  are involved, especially in cases involving the welfare and best interests of 
  children.Â  Kisling v. Allison, 343 S.C. 674, 677-78, 541 S.E.2d 273, 
  275 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.     Change of Circumstances 
   
 Mother argues the family court erred 
  by ruling her relocation to Kentucky, standing alone, constituted a change of 
  circumstances sufficient to alter the custody award.Â  
Appellate courts should interpret judgments by 
  the trial courts as they would any other instrument.Â  Eddins v. Eddins, 
  304 S.C. 133, 135-36, 403 S.E.2d 164, 166 (Ct. App. 1991); see also State 
  v. Evans, 354 S.C. 579, 584, 582 S.E.2d 407, 410 (2003) (holding an appellate 
  court must view the circuit courtâ€™s statements as a whole to determine its reasoning).Â  

The family courtâ€™s order states in pertinent part: 


I find that the move to Kentucky is not beneficial to the 
  children; that their lives would not be enhanced by the move; that their relationship 
  with their father was very good prior to the move and would suffer; and that 
  the motherâ€™s reasons for moving were very poor . . . . This Court finds that 
  the motherâ€™s move to Kentucky and subsequent behavior constitutes 
  a substantial change in circumstances which necessitates a change in permanent 
  custody to the father. 

(emphasis added).Â  Additionally, the family courtâ€™s 
  numerous findings of fact and conclusions of law support the conclusion the 
  decision is based on many factors, only one of which was Motherâ€™s move to Kentucky.Â  
  Thus, Motherâ€™s claim that the family court found a change of circumstances and 
  altered the custody award based solely on her move to Kentucky is without merit.
Furthermore, based on our own review of the record 
  and considering the totality of the circumstances, we hold the family court 
  did not err by altering the custody award and awarding custody to Father. 
In South Carolina, there is a presumption against 
  removing a child from the state.Â  McAlister v. Patterson, 278 S.C. 481, 
  483, 299 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1982).Â  However, the presumption may be rebutted by 
  a showing the move will benefit the child. See id. at 483, 299 
  S.E.2d at 323 (â€œIn situations where removal will benefit the child, removal 
  has been allowed.â€). Thus, the question of whether relocation will be allowed 
  requires a determination of whether relocation is in the best interest of the 
  children.Â  Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 449, 454, 517 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  In child custody cases, a court must examine the totality of the 
  circumstances to determine the best interests of the child.Â  Wheeler v. Gill, 
  307 S.C. 94, 99, 413 S.E.2d 860, 863 (Ct. App. 1992).
In reaching a determination as to custody, the 
  family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas 
  of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, 
  familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Pountain v. Pountain, 
  332 S.C. 130, 136, 503 S.E.2d 757, 760 (Ct. App. 1998). Additionally, the court 
  must assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness, and attitude as they affect the 
  child.Â  Id. at 136, 503 S.E.2d at 760.Â  
Father resides in South Carolina, with his relatives living 
  nearby, in a town where the children have gone to school their whole lives.Â  
  The record indicates Father works full-time, and thus, when the children are 
  in Fatherâ€™s custody, his mother watches the children and cooks for them on a 
  regular basis.Â  Notwithstanding that, the Guardian ad Litem (â€œGALâ€) testified 
  it was in the childrenâ€™s best interest to stay in South Carolina where they 
  have gone to school and have relatives nearby.Â  
Additionally, the GAL testified the children are bonded with 
  their Father.Â  Therefore, allowing Mother to retain custody in Kentucky would 
  have a negative impact on Fatherâ€™s relationship with the children.Â  
Evidence within the record indicates during Mother and Fatherâ€™s 
  marriage, Father had physical confrontations with both Mother and Randall, Motherâ€™s 
  son by a previous marriage.Â  However, the evidence also indicates the confrontations 
  with Mother have not occurred since the end of their marriage, and the confrontations 
  with Randall have not occurred since 1991.Â  
On Motherâ€™s side, the record indicates during the summer 
  of 2000, Mother, her new husband, several pets, and the children lived in a 
  hotel room in Kentucky.Â  Subsequently, Mother, her new husband, and the children 
  moved into a farmhouse.Â  
The record indicates Mother is unemployed, and although she 
  claims to have a disability, she did not provide evidence in the record to support 
  her claim.Â  
While the children are with Mother, Mother primarily cares 
  for the childrenâ€™s needs.Â  Additionally, testimony within the record indicates 
  Mother is more patient and understanding of the children, communicates better 
  with them, and is more involved in their lives than Father.Â  
However, we are concerned with Motherâ€™s ability to provide 
  a safe, stable environment for the children.Â  Initially, we are most concerned 
  with evidence indicating Motherâ€™s new husband is violent.Â  The evidence in this 
  regard indicates that shortly after moving to Kentucky, Motherâ€™s new husband 
  attacked her with a hammer.Â  Mother called the police, and Motherâ€™s new husband 
  was charged with criminal domestic violence.Â  
Additionally, the record indicates patterns of instability.Â  
  First, this is Motherâ€™s third marriage, and Mother only met her new husband 
  a short period of time before they were married.Â  Second, Mother was held in 
  contempt of court for damaging Fatherâ€™s property.Â  Third, the day Mother left 
  with the children to Kentucky, it was Fatherâ€™s regularly scheduled visitation 
  period.Â  Although Mother sent a letter to Father indicating she was moving, 
  Mother, in violation of the divorce decree, failed to give proper notice to 
  Father and failed to tell Father where the children would be.Â  
Subsequently, when the family court granted temporary custody 
  to Father, Mother did not voluntarily comply with the order.Â  Rather, Father 
  had to travel to Kentucky to enforce the order.Â  Furthermore, when Father took 
  the children, Mother cried, screamed, and threatened Father in front of the 
  children.Â  Mother admitted that after this confrontation, she encouraged the 
  children to perform poorly in school so that her chances of retaining permanent 
  custody would improve.Â  The children did in fact perform poorly in school, requiring 
  one of them to take summer school classes.Â  
Considering the totality of the circumstances, we conclude 
  Father is more capable of providing a stable environment for the children.Â  
  A fair reading of the record indicates while Fatherâ€™s mother tends to many of 
  the childrenâ€™s basic needs, Father does involve himself in his childrenâ€™s lives.Â  
  Furthermore, Father has a strong familial support system.Â  We are concerned 
  with evidence indicating a history of violent arguments with Mother and Randall.Â  
  The family court noted this history in its order, but ultimately concluded Father 
  was still the best parent to have custody.Â  In evaluating the significance of 
  this prior history, the family court contrasted, as do we, the evidence within 
  the record indicating Mother recently accused her current husband of assaulting 
  her with a hammer.Â  Additionally, Mother has demonstrated behavior that indicates 
  she prioritizes her own interests over the best interests of her children.Â  

We therefore agree with the family courtâ€™s conclusion that 
  the best interests of the children are served by granting Father permanent custody.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Expert 
  Witness
Mother argues the family court erred by excluding 
  testimony of a psychologist indicating the children would prefer to live with 
  Mother.Â  Mother contends the exclusion of this evidence is in contravention 
  of Rule 703, South Carolina Rules of Evidence. 
  [1] Â  
It is well settled the admission and rejection of testimony 
  are matters largely within the trial courtâ€™s discretion, the exercise of which, 
  absent abuse, will not be disturbed on appeal. Pike v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000).Â  To warrant reversal, 
  the appellant â€œmust show both the error of the ruling and resulting prejudice.â€ 
  Recco Tape and Label Co. v. Barfield, 312 S.C. 214, 216, 439 S.E.2d 838, 
  840 (1994); Potomac Leasing Co. v. Bone, 294 S.C. 494, 497, 366 S.E.2d 
  26, 28 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œBefore the Court of Appeals will reverse a judgment 
  for an alleged error in the exclusion of evidence, the appellant must show prejudice.â€). 

At the beginning of Motherâ€™s direct examination of 
  the psychologist, Mother moved to admit the psychologistâ€™s written evaluation.Â  
  The family court admitted the evaluation into evidence without objection.Â  The 
  evaluation generally indicated the children preferred living with their Mother.Â  

Thereafter, Mother asked the psychologist with whom 
  the children had indicated they preferred to live.Â  The psychologist indicated 
  the children stated they preferred to live with Mother.Â  Father objected and 
  moved to strike, and the family court excluded the testimony.Â  
Subsequently, the GAL testified, without objection, 
  that the children told him, at least at some specific points during the custody 
  litigation, they would prefer to live with Mother. Â 
Assuming, without deciding, the family court erred 
  by excluding the testimony of the psychologist, the testimonyâ€™s only value was 
  to indicate they had expressed a preference to live with Mother, evidence that 
  was introduced both through the psychologistâ€™s evaluation and the testimony 
  of the GAL.Â Â  Thus, the testimony was cumulative, and its exclusion, if error, 
  is not reversible error.Â  See Weir v. Citicorp Nat. Servs., Inc., 
  312 S.C. 511, 517, 435 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1993) (holding exclusion of cumulative 
  evidence is not prejudicial error). [2] 
III.Â Â Â  Fatherâ€™s 
  Acts of Violence
Mother argues the family court erred by excluding 
  testimony of her older son, Randall, indicating Father was violent.Â  We hold 
  the family court did consider the evidence, and thus, Motherâ€™s assignment of 
  error is without merit. [3] 
Appellate courts should interpret judgments by 
  the trial courts as they would any other instrument.Â  Eddins, 304 S.C. 
  at 135-36, 403 S.E.2d at 166; see also Evans, 354 S.C. at 584, 
  582 S.E.2d at 410 (holding an appellate court must view the circuit courtâ€™s 
  statements as a whole to determine its reasoning).Â  Thus, the primary objective 
  is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the court.Â  Eddins, 
  304 S.C. at 135, 403 S.E.2d at 166.Â  However, â€œ[a]n order should be construed 
  within the context of the proceeding in which it is rendered.â€Â  Dibble v. 
  Sumter Ice and Fuel Co., 283 S.C. 278, 282, 322 S.E.2d 674, 677 (Ct. App. 
  1984). 
During Motherâ€™s direct examination of Randall, Mother attempted 
  to introduce testimony indicating in 1991, prior to the divorce decree and original 
  custody award, Father displayed violent tendencies both toward her and Randall.Â  
  Father objected, arguing the testimony was not relevant because the alleged 
  incidents occurred prior to the divorce decree.Â  
The family court stated, â€œIf you want to proffer you can.Â  
  But I think Iâ€™m supposed to--- I think Iâ€™m supposed to hear whatâ€™s happened 
  since that divorce decree, and I can take into account whatever the court record 
  shows.â€Â  Mother then proffered Randallâ€™s testimony.Â  
During the proffer, Randall testified that he lived with 
  Father from the summer of 1987 until December of 1991.Â  He testified that during 
  that time Father was violent.Â  Specifically, he recounted one confrontation 
  where Father allegedly threw him to the ground and dented the floor vent with 
  his head.Â  He further testified that one month following this confrontation, 
  Mother sent him to live with his father in Germany.Â  
Subsequently, Mother ended her proffer and began eliciting 
  testimony from Randall for the record.Â  Thereafter, Father asked if the testimony 
  was part of the proffer or was testimony for the record.Â  The court replied 
  that the testimony was for the record.Â  Furthermore, the court indicated it 
  had not yet ruled on whether to admit the previously proffered testimony.Â Â  

Reading the transcript of the hearing, it does not indicate 
  if the family court ever ruled, during the hearing, on whether to admit Randallâ€™s 
  testimony.Â  However, in the family courtâ€™s order, the court states in its findings 
  of fact that:

Her son himself testified that, when he was 15, he 
  had had a confrontation with . . . [Father] which has resulted in the police 
  being called and . . . [Father] leaving the house overnight.Â  The incident happened 
  sometime in 1992.Â  A few months after that, . . . [Motherâ€™s] older children 
  were sent to live with their father in Germany.

(emphasis added).Â  
Given the family courtâ€™s clear, unambiguous language 
  in this ruling, the only logical inference is that the family court did consider 
  Randallâ€™s testimony.Â  Thus, Motherâ€™s contention to the contrary is without merit.
IV.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s 
  Fees
Mother argues the family court erred by awarding 
  Father attorneyâ€™s fees and not awarding her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be overturned 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 
  415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  the family court should consider:Â  1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own 
  fees; 2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; 3) the respective financial 
  conditions of the parties; and 4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard 
  of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 
  (1992).Â Â  When determining the amount of fees to award, the family court should 
  consider: Â 1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; 2) 
  the time necessarily devoted to the case; 3) counselâ€™s professional standing; 
  4) the contingency of compensation; 5) the beneficial results obtained; and 
  6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
Initially, Mother contends the family court erred 
  by awarding Father attorneyâ€™s fees because the court should not have found a 
  change of circumstances occurred.Â  Because we hold the family court did not 
  err in granting relief based upon a substantial change in circumstances, this 
  argument is without merit.
Next, Mother contends the family court erred because 
  the order â€œfails to make any of the customary findings required in connection 
  with an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, even though it cites Atkinson v. Atkinson, 
  279 S.C. 355, 309 S.E.2d 14 (Ct. App. 1983), which defines and requires such 
  findings.â€
The family courtâ€™s eighteen-page order is replete with findings 
  involving the respective positions of the parties.Â  In addition, the courtâ€™s 
  order noted Fatherâ€™s counselâ€™s professional standing.Â  Furthermore, Fatherâ€™s 
  counsel provided an affidavit indicating the time devoted to the case.Â  Moreover, 
  it is undisputed that Father obtained a beneficial result based upon the change 
  in custody.Â  
Faced with such a detailed order containing extensive findings 
  of fact, we conclude Motherâ€™s argument, merely claiming the family court failed 
  to make customary findings of fact, is insufficient to preserve this assignment 
  of error for appellate review.Â  See Solomon v. City Realty Co., 
  262 S.C. 198, 201, 203 S.E.2d 435, 435 (1974) (holding conclusory arguments 
  are deemed abandoned); Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 
  439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding an issue is deemed abandoned and 
  thus not presented for appellate review if argued in a short, conclusory statement). 
  Â Consequently, Motherâ€™s argument is without merit.
Lastly, Mother contends the family court erred 
  by not awarding her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  She contends that the financial disparity 
  between the two parties is so great that not awarding her attorneyâ€™s fees is 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  
The evidence within Fatherâ€™s financial declaration 
  indicates he has a net monthly income of $2,225.85 and monthly expenses totaling 
  $1,855.20.Â  Motherâ€™s financial declaration states she has no monthly income 
  and expenses totaling $1,718.00 per month.Â  The Motherâ€™s testimony indicates 
  she lacks monthly income because she has a disability.Â  
However, the family court did not believe Motherâ€™s 
  testimony.Â  Rather, because Mother failed to produce any evidence outside of 
  her own testimony indicating she had a disability, the family court imputed 
  income to her â€“ a determination Mother has not appealed.Â  Furthermore, Mother 
  did not win on the merits.Â  Thus, we hold the family court did not abuse its 
  discretion by denying Motherâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the family court 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1] Mother also contends the exclusion contravened Rule 803(3), South 
    Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  However, Mother did not argue Rule 803(3), South 
    Carolina Rules of Evidence, to the family court when attempting to admit the 
    psychologistâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, any argument premised upon that rule 
    is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 
    330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue 
    cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to 
    and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).

 
   
    [2] Mother additionally argues the family court erred by excluding other 
    statements made by the children to the psychologist.Â  However, Mother did 
    not proffer the psychologistâ€™s testimony.Â  Thus, any assignment of error to 
    the exclusion of this testimony is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See 
    Greenville Memâ€™l Auditorium v. Martin, 301 S.C. 242, 243, 391 S.E.2d 
    546, 547 (1990) (â€œAn alleged erroneous exclusion of evidence is not a basis 
    for establishing prejudice on appeal in the absence of an adequate proffer 
    of evidence in the court below.â€).Â  

 
   [3] Mother 
    also argues the family court erred by excluding portions of both Fatherâ€™s 
    testimony during cross-examination and her own testimony on direct examination.Â  
    However, Fatherâ€™s testimony was not proffered. Thus, any assignment of error 
    to the exclusion of this testimony is not preserved for appellate review.Â Â Â Â  
    See Greenville Memâ€™l Auditorium, 301 S.C. at 243, 391 S.E.2d 
    at 547 (holding an alleged exclusion of evidence is not a basis for establishing 
    prejudice on appeal in the absence of a proffer of the evidence in the court 
    below).Â  Furthermore, the substance of Motherâ€™s testimony was admitted though 
    the psychologistâ€™s report discussed above.Â  Thus, the testimony was cumulative, 
    and its exclusion, if error, is not reversible error.Â  See Weir, 
    312 S.C. at 517, 435 S.E.2d at 860 (holding exclusion of cumulative evidence 
    is not prejudicial error).
