THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Anna Mae Morgan       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
David Wayne Morgan, Defendant       
Respondent,
      
    
  

And,

  
    
      
Martha Ann Bartlett, Third Party Defendant       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Timothy M. Cain, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-079
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART AND DISMISSED IN PART


  
    
      
Anna Mae Morgan, Pro Se, for Appellant.
David Wayne Morgan and Martha Ann Bartlett, both Pro 
  Se, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Anna Mae Morgan (â€œMotherâ€) 
  appeals from a family court order, arguing the family court erred by:Â  1) finding 
  her in contempt of a divorce decree; and 2) ordering her to pay tutoring expenses.Â  
  Additionally, Mother asks this Court to modify her visitation award.Â  We affirm 
  in part and dismiss in part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Mother and Father have two children, Ashley and David. [1] Â  Following Mother and Fatherâ€™s divorce, Fatherâ€™s 
  mother, Martha Ann Bartlett (â€œGrandmotherâ€), received custody of David, with 
  Mother having weekend, as well as summer and holiday visitation.Â  
The divorce decree, in pertinent part, contained the following provisions:Â  
  1) Mother was required to make copies of family pictures and deliver them to 
  Father; 2) Mother was required to return several personal videotapes to Father; 
  3) Mother, Father, and Grandmother were enjoined from harassing one another; 
  4) Mother could speak with David over the telephone; however, Mother was prohibited 
  from initiating telephone contact with David; 5) Mother was required to provide 
  Grandmother with a calendar of Motherâ€™s work schedule six months in advance; 
  and 6) Mother was encouraged not to reside with paramours overnight during her 
  visitations with David.Â  
Following the decree, Grandmother and 
  Father each filed rules to show cause, alleging Mother violated the divorce 
  decree. Specifically, Grandmother alleged Mother was in contempt for: 1) initiating 
  telephone calls with David; 2) failing to provide a calendar of her work schedule 
  six months in advance; and 3) continuing to reside with her paramour during 
  visitations with David. Grandmother requested Motherâ€™s visitation be restricted 
  and requested Mother pay an additional twenty-five dollars per week for Davidâ€™s 
  tutoring. Fatherâ€™s complaint alleged Mother was in contempt for failing to make 
  copies of the family pictures and return his personal videotapes. 
The family courtâ€™s order found Mother in contempt 
  for failing to:Â  1) make copies of the family pictures; 2); return Fatherâ€™s 
  personal videotapes; and 3) provide Grandmother with a calendar of her work 
  schedule six months in advance.Â  Furthermore, while holding Mother was not in 
  contempt of the divorce decree for exposing David to her paramour, the family 
  court modified the divorce decree, altering Motherâ€™s visitation schedule and 
  restricting Davidâ€™s visitation with Mother to daytime hours.Â  Additionally, 
  the order required Mother to pay one-half of all Davidâ€™s tutoring bills.Â  Mother 
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find facts in accordance with its view of the evidence.Â  Rutherford 
  v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad 
  scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard the findings 
  of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 
  S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Contempt
Mother argues the family court erred 
  by holding her in contempt for failing to:Â  1) make copies of family pictures 
  and provide them to Father; 2) return Fatherâ€™s personal videotapes; and 3) provide 
  Grandmother with her work schedule six months in advance.Â  We deem these issues 
  abandoned.
â€œ[S]hort, conclusory statements made 
  without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not 
  presented for review.â€Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co., 
  348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Motherâ€™s brief contains little discussion as to 
  the issues on appeal and no citation to authority.Â  Thus, we deem these issues 
  as abandoned.Â  See Glasscock, Inc., 348 S.C. at 83, 557 S.E.2d 
  at 691. [2] Â  
  II.               
  Visitation
Mother argues this Court 
  should modify the family courtâ€™s visitation award because, subsequent to the 
  family courtâ€™s order, she married the paramour.Â  This issue is not properly 
  before us.
Initially, we note, 
  Mother has not argued the family court abused its discretion by altering her 
  visitation award.Â  Thus, the only issue presented is whether this Court should 
  find Motherâ€™s circumstances have changed such that her visitation award should 
  be modified.
For a court to modify 
  an existing custody or visitation award, there must be a showing of changed 
  circumstances occurring subsequent to the entry of the decree.Â  Heckle v. 
  Heckle, 266 S.C. 355, 358, 223 S.E.2d 590, 591 (1976).Â  However, a motion 
  to modify a custody or visitation award based on a change in circumstances cannot 
  be made, at the first instance, to this Court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  14-8-200(a) (Supp. 2002) (stating the Court of Appealsâ€™ jurisdiction is limited 
  to appellate jurisdiction).Â  Rather, the motion must be made in the family court.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-400(A)(1)(e) (1985) (stating the family court 
  has original jurisdiction over claims of child custody); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(30) 
  (Supp. 2002) (â€œThe family court shall have exclusive jurisdiction:Â  [t]o hear 
  and determine any questions of support, custody, separation, or any other matter 
  over which the court has jurisdiction, without the intervention of a jury . 
  . . .â€).
In Grandmotherâ€™s rule to show cause, Grandmother argued 
  Mother was in contempt of the divorce decree for residing overnight with the 
  paramour during her visitations with David.  The family court ruled the 
  divorce decree only recommended Mother not reside with paramours during her 
  visitations with David.  Thus, the family court did not hold Mother in 
  contempt.  However, the family court ruled the best interests of David 
  would be served by altering Motherâ€™s visitation award and restricting Motherâ€™s 
  visitation with David to daylight hours. 
Subsequently, Mother married the paramour.  
  However, no evidence exists within the record indicating Mother either planned 
  to marry the paramour prior to the modification or discussed the possibility 
  with the family court.  
Mother claims her marriage to 
  the paramour is a change of circumstances warranting a visitation modification.  
  However, her claim is not properly before this Court.Â  See S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 14-8-200(1) (stating the Court of Appealsâ€™ jurisdiction is limited 
  to appellate jurisdiction).  Rather, this claim must first be brought before 
  the family court.  Thus, Motherâ€™s remedy, if any, is to petition the family 
  court for modification of its order.  Accordingly, this portion of the appeal 
  is dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
III.Â Â Â  Tutoring
Mother argues the family court 
  erred by ordering her to pay one-half of Davidâ€™s tutoring bills because she 
  is capable of tutoring David, and thus, third party tutors are unneeded.Â  We 
  disagree.
In all determinations 
  involving children, the best interests of the children are the paramount concern.Â  
  See e.g.Â  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 
  (1978) (â€œThe welfare of the child and what is in his/her best interest is the 
  primary, paramount and controlling consideration of the court in all child custody 
  controversies.â€);Â  Ex Parte Stull, 276 S.C. 512, 513, 280 S.E.2d 209, 
  210 (1981) (holding in deciding whether to allow a change in a childâ€™s surname, 
  the family court should grant the request only if the change promotes the childâ€™s 
  best interests and welfare);Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Vanderhorst, 
  287 S.C. 554, 561, 340 S.E.2d 149, 153 (1986) (holding in proceedings to terminate 
  parental rights, the paramount concern is the best interests of the child).
In Grandmotherâ€™s rule 
  to show cause, she asserts David needs tutoring.Â  To support her position, Grandmother 
  testified David was having difficulty in school, and his school requested he 
  receive at least two hours of tutoring a week. Grandmother further testified 
  Davidâ€™s school provided her with a list of qualified tutors, and the hourly 
  rate for the tutors is twenty-five dollars. 
Initially, we note, Mother does 
  not dispute David needs tutoring.Â  Furthermore, Mother does not argue that she 
  should not be required to contribute to Davidâ€™s tutoring because she is without 
  financial means.Â  Rather, Mother only asserts she is capable of tutoring David, 
  and thus, third party tutors are unneeded.
Although the record indicates 
  Mother has the equivalent of a high school diploma and has completed some college 
  work at Spartanburg Technical College, no evidence exists within the record 
  indicating Mother is a qualified tutor or that she has experience tutoring children.Â  
  Thus, given the testimony of Grandmother, we agree with the family court that 
  Davidâ€™s best interests are served by having him tutored by qualified individuals 
  as recommended by his school.Â Â Â  Consequently, the family court did not err.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we AFFIRM the 
  family courtâ€™s order, and DISMISS Motherâ€™s motion to modify her visitation 
  award.Â 
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1]  Ashley reached the age of majority prior to Mother and Fatherâ€™s divorce.Â  
    Thus, Ashley was not a subject of the custody award.

 
   
    [2] Motherâ€™s entire brief fails to cite authority for her arguments.Â  
    Thus, generally we would deem all of her issues as abandoned on appeal.Â  However, 
    given this Courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minors, we will address 
    the merits of the Motherâ€™s arguments to the extent they involve the best interests 
    of David. See Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 
    536 S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000) (stating â€œprocedural rules are subservient to the 
    courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minorsâ€); Ex parte Roper, 
    254 S.C. 558, 563, 176 S.E.2d 175, 177 (1970) (holding â€œwhere the rights and 
    best interests of a minor child are concerned, the court may appropriately 
    raise, ex mero motu, issues not raised by the partiesâ€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State,       
        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kenneth Bernard Scott,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Joseph J. Watson , Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-088
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 12, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant,
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A jury found Kenneth Bernard 
  Scott guilty of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute, possession 
  of cocaine with intent to distribute within close proximity of a school, trafficking 
  in crack cocaine, and possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute 
  within close proximity of a school. He was fined $50,000 and received concurrent 
  sentences on the four charges, the longest of which was for 21 years. 
  [1] Â  On appeal, Scottâ€™s counsel argues that the trial court erred in failing 
  to grant his motion for directed verdict on the charges.Â  In a response brief, 
  Scott raises eight issues dealing with subject matter jurisdiction, violations 
  of his Constitutional rights, and evidence suppression.Â  We dismiss Scottâ€™s 
  appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
While conducting a midnight search 
  of Scottâ€™s fatherâ€™s home pursuant to a valid search warrant based on a confidential 
  informantâ€™s information, Sheriffâ€™s Department investigators found Scott standing 
  fully dressed and alone over a toilet in a bathroom in the home.Â  Someone had 
  apparently just tried to flush the toilet, because water was swirling in it.Â  
  An officer removed Scott from the bathroom and handcuffed him.Â  Another officer 
  found a bag containing crack cocaine in the toilet and a bag containing cocaine 
  on the floor where Scott had been found.Â  Investigating officers also found 
  Scottâ€™s father in a bedroom, and another man sitting in the kitchen.Â  was subsequently 
  indicted for one count each of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute, 
  possession of cocaine with intent to distribute within close proximity of a 
  school, trafficking in crack cocaine, and possession of crack cocaine with intent 
  to distribute within close proximity of a school.Â  
In a September 2000 trial, the State provided testimony 
  from six law enforcement officials who investigated the crime scene where Scott 
  was arrested.Â  Their testimony indicated that when law enforcement entered and 
  secured Scottâ€™s fatherâ€™s house, they found Scottâ€™s father in bedroom, another 
  man in the kitchen, and Scott in the bathroom with the illegal drugs.Â  At the 
  conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, Scott made a motion for directed verdict based 
  on a claim that the evidence was insufficient to support the charges.Â  Specifically, 
  Scott maintained that the office did not see drugs in the bathroom where Scott 
  was found until Scott had been removed and secured, and that Scottâ€™s â€œmere presenceâ€ 
  alone was not enough to support the pending charges.Â  The trial court denied 
  the motion, finding sufficient circumstantial evidence existed to submit the 
  case to the jury.Â  Scott renewed the motion after all evidence was presented.Â  

Scott later filed a motion to reconsider his sentence, 
  for which the circuit judge held a hearing on April 21, 2001.Â  The judge issued 
  a written order three days later stating â€œMotion for Reconsideration of Sentence 
  in this case is respectfully denied.â€Â  This appeal follows.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  ANDERS ISSUE
Scott contends that the trial court 
  erred in failing to grant his motion for directed verdict because he never had 
  actual or constructive possession of the drugs.Â  Specifically, Scott argues 
  that he had no actual possession of the drugs, and the evidence only suggests 
  his â€œmere presenceâ€ where the drugs were found rather than constructive possession 
  of the drugs.Â  Consequently, he concludes his state and federal due process 
  rights were violated.
â€œConviction of possession requires proof of possession, 
  either actual or constructive, coupled with knowledge of the drug's presence.â€Â  
  State v. Williams, 346 S.C. 424, 430, 552 S.E.2d 54, 57 (2001). â€œActual 
  possession occurs when the drugs are found to be in the actual physical custody 
  of the person charged with possession.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn order to prove constructive 
  possession, the State must show the defendant had dominion and control, or the 
  right to exercise dominion and control, over the drug.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œSuch possession 
  can be established by circumstantial or direct evidence or a combination of 
  the two.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œPossession requires more than mere presence. The State 
  must show the defendant had dominion or control over the thing allegedly possessed 
  or had the right to exercise dominion or control over it.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œWhere 
  contraband materials are found on premises under the control of the accused, 
  this fact in and of itself gives rise to an inference of knowledge and possession 
  which may be sufficient to carry the case to the jury.â€Â  Id.
In the present case, testimony from law enforcement 
  officers clearly indicated that ScottÂ  was alone in the restroom where the drugs 
  were located, thus giving him dominion over the drugs.Â  Accordingly, when viewed 
  in the light most favorable to State, the circumstantial evidence in this case 
  at least reasonably tends to prove Scottâ€™s guilt on the possession charges.Â  
  Thus, the trial court did not err in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  
  See State v. Cooper, 334 SC 540, 551-52, 514 S.E.2d 584, 590 (1999) 
  (stating that â€œ[i]n reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, 
  the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the State, and if 
  there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably 
  tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find that 
  the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€)
III.Â Â Â  PRO SE RESPONSE ISSUES
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Scott argues that the court of appeals 
  lacks subject matter jurisdiction because he never received written notice or 
  an order granting or denying his Post-Trial motions.Â  He also argues that the 
  circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because he (1) was never served 
  the charging instruments; (2) the indictments for distributing controlled substances 
  within the proximity of a school were invalid because â€œGreenville Tech is not 
  a public vocational or trade school or technical education center;â€ and (3) 
  the indictments were not filed with the Greenville County Clerk of Court.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction 
  of the Court of Appeals
Scott claims that he was never provided 
  a written order denying his post-trial motion for a new trial, this court lacks 
  subject matter jurisdiction to consider the appeal because the matter is stayed 
  pending his receipt of a written order expressing the trial courtâ€™s ruling on 
  his post-trial motion.Â  We disagree.
Scott bases his claim on Rule 29, SCRCrimP, which 
  partially provides that â€œ[t]he time for appeal for all parties shall be stayed 
  by a timely post trial (sic) motion and shall run from the receipt of written 
  notice of entry of the order granting or denying such motion.â€Â  However, the 
  court in this matter clearly issued a written order denying Scottâ€™s post-trial 
  motion, and filed the Motion in the Office of the Greenville County Clerk of 
  Court.Â  Moreover, Scottâ€™s counsel filed a notice of intent to appeal on May 
  3, 2002, which gave the South Carolina Court of Appeals exclusive jurisdiction 
  over the appeal and divested the lower courtâ€™s jurisdiction except to entertain 
  petitions for writs of supersedeas.Â  See Rule 205, SCACR (stating â€œ[u]pon 
  the service of the notice of appeal, the appellate court shall have exclusive 
  jurisdiction over the appeal;Â  the lower court shall have jurisdiction to entertain 
  petitions for writs of supersedeas as provided by Rule 225.â€)Â Â  Thus, we find 
  Scottâ€™s contention that this Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over his 
  appeal is meritless.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction 
  of the Circuit Court
Scott contends the circuit court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to hear his case because he had never been served 
  with the indictments.Â  However, in his appearance before the court, he never 
  mentioned that he had not received the indictments.Â  Additionally, his appearance 
  at the trial, along with the inclusion of the indictments in the record on appeal, 
  suggests he received the indictments contrary to his assertions.
He next argues that the trial court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to hear charges pertaining to distribution with 
  proximity of a school because â€œGreenville Tech is a private vocational trade 
  schoolâ€ to which S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445 does not apply. [2] Â  However, we take judicial notice of the fact 
  that Greenville Technical College is a state-supported, and thus public, â€œtechnical 
  education centerâ€ to which Section 44-53-445 clearly applies. 
  [3] 
Finally, Scott contends that the indictments 
  have not been filed with the Greenville County Clerk of Court, so the circuit 
  court there lacked jurisdiction to â€œentertain his case and sentence him.â€Â  However, 
  the record contains certified copies of the indictments that were provided by 
  the Greenville County Clerk of Court, suggesting that office has filed copies 
  of the indictments.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  B.Â Â Â Â Â  Constitutional Violations
Scott maintains that his Constitutional 
  rights were violated (1) by the admission of prejudicial hearsay evidence related 
  to the confidential informant; (2) by the courtâ€™s failure to suppress evidence 
  obtained from a search conducted without compliance with â€œknock and announceâ€ 
  requirements; (3) because he was arrested without probable cause; and (4) by 
  holding him in violation of his Fourteenth Amendment rights where â€œno 
  rational trial of fact would find [him] guilty of every fact and element of 
  his charges beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  However, he never raised the first 
  three issues at trial.Â  Thus, they are not preserved for our review.Â  See 
  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (stating â€œ[a]rguments not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not 
  preserved for appellate review.â€); State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 339, 
  526 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating â€œConstitutional arguments are no 
  exception to the rule, and if not raised to the trial court are deemed waived 
  on appeal.â€)Â  We find the merits of the fourth issue are so closely akin to 
  those of the directed verdict motion, and find no violation of his Fourteenth 
  Amendment rights accordingly.
CONCLUSION
After a review of the record as required by Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991),Â  and the forgoing reasons, we hold there are no 
  directly appealable issues that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, 
  we dismiss Scottâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1]  Scott received credit for time served.

 
   [2]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445(A) provides: 
  
  It is a separate criminal 
    offense for a person to distribute, sell, purchase, manufacture, or to unlawfully 
    possess with intent to distribute, a controlled substance while in, on, or 
    within a one-half mile radius of the grounds of a public or private elementary, 
    middle, or secondary school; Â a public playground or park;Â  a public vocational 
    or trade school or technical educational center;Â  or a public or private 
    college or university.
  
  (emphasis added)

 
   [3]  Greenville Technical Collegeâ€™s website states 
    that the school â€œis an accredited, state-supported institution of higher learning 
    â€¦.â€Â  See http://www.greenvilletech.com/About/index.html.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Tommy David Bonner, Appellant
        v.
        Joyce Kay Bonner, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Barry W. Knobel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-092
  Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        W. Patrick Yon, of Anderson, for Appellant
        William N. Epps, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Tommy David Bonner (Husband) appeals 
  from the family courtâ€™s denial of his motion seeking a new trial or relief from 
  the Final Divorce Decree, pursuant to Rule 59 [1]  and Rule 60 [2] , SCRCP.Â  Husband appeals, asserting that his attorney abandoned 
  the case.Â  He alleges the family court erred in ruling that the neglect of the 
  attorney is attributable to him.Â  We disagree and affirm.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
Husband filed a divorce action on 
  January 12, 2001 and Wife counterclaimed on February 20, 2001.Â  Husband released 
  his initial attorney, Mr. Ronnie Treadwell, on October 9, 2001 and retained 
  Mr. Harold Lowery on the same day to represent him.Â  It appears Husband paid 
  Mr. Lowery $500 and thereafter made subsequent payments.Â  Mr. Lowery never notified 
  Wifeâ€™s attorney or the court that he represented Husband.Â  The final hearing 
  was rescheduled for September 12, 2002 and subsequently continued to November 
  21, 2002.Â  After an extended illness, which was well known in the Anderson County 
  Bar, Mr. Lowery died on November 3, 2002.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney mailed notification 
  of the final hearing to Husbandâ€™s last known address.Â  Husband contends that 
  he never received notification.Â  
The case was tried before Family Court Judge 
  Barry W. Knobel on November 21, 2002.Â  Wife was present with her attorney.Â  
  Husband was not present.Â  The family issued a final decree and granted Wife 
  relief pursuant to her counterclaim.Â  Husband filed a Motion for New Trial or 
  Relief from Judgment, pursuant to Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP, respectively. Â Judge 
  Knobel denied the motion, finding that Husband failed to establish any excusable 
  neglect or inadvertence that would entitle him to the relief requested in his 
  motion.Â  This appeal follows.Â  Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
The grant or denial of new trial motions rests within 
  the discretion of the trial judge, and the decision will not be disturbed on 
  appeal unless the findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions 
  reached are controlled by error of law.Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 
  389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œ[M]otions for relief under 
  Rule 60(b) are addressed to the discretion of the court and appellate review 
  is limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion.â€Â  Saro 
  Invs. v. Ocean Holiday Pâ€™ship, 314 S.C. 116, 124, 441 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. 
  App. 1994).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband alleges the family court erred in ruling that 
  the neglect of the attorney is attributable to the client, and argues on appeal 
  that Mr. Lowery abandoned the case.Â  Assuming the issue of abandonment was properly 
  raised in the trial court, we disagree.Â  
Generally, â€œthe mistake inadvertence or neglect of 
  counsel has been held insufficient grounds for relief where default results 
  from inaction of counsel on behalf of the client or failure to exercise due 
  diligence in the protection of the clientâ€™s interest.â€Â  Lee v. Peek, 
  240 S.C. 203, 125 S.E.2d 353, 358 (1962). Â However, where there has been a finding 
  of willful and unilateral abandonment, the rule does not apply, and relief may 
  be granted to the party.Â  Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 452, 
  248 S.E.2d 594, 599 (1978).Â  In Goodson v. American Bankers Ins. Co. of Florida, 
  295 S.C. 400, 403, 368 S.E.2d 687, 689 (Ct. App. 1988), the court held that 
  â€œa party has a duty to monitor the progress of his case.Â  Lack of familiarity 
  with legal proceedings is unacceptable and the court will not hold a layman 
  to any lesser standard than is applied to an attorney.â€Â  
In light of the fact that Husband was the party who 
  had commenced the litigation, there was an obligation on his part to monitor 
  the status of his case.Â  There is no indication from the record that he took 
  any responsibility or attempted to do so.Â  Husbandâ€™s inaction is highlighted 
  by the unchallenged finding of the trial court regarding Mr. Loweryâ€™s extended illness.Â  Certainly, had Husband demonstrated any degree of 
  diligence concerning his case and its status, he would have learned of Mr. Loweryâ€™s 
  illness and inability to represent Husband well prior to the scheduled final 
  hearing.Â  Such readily available knowledge would have prompted a reasonable 
  person to take appropriate steps to ensure representation by counsel.Â  Moreover, 
  Mr. Lowery died approximately three weeks prior to the final hearing, and during 
  that time period, Husband offers no explanation why he failed to take any action, 
  such as contacting Mr. Loweryâ€™s office, to protect his legal interest.Â  Therefore, 
  based on the totality of the circumstances, the trial court did not abuse its 
  discretion in finding that Husband failed to establish excusable neglect or 
  inadvertence that would entitle him to relief.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, J.J., concur.Â  Â 



   [1] Â  Rule 59(a), SCRCP, states:Â  â€œA new trial may be granted to all or 
    any of the parties and on all or part of the issues . . . (2) in an action 
    tried without a jury, for any of the reasons for which rehearings have heretofore 
    been granted in the courts of the State.Â  On a motion for a new trial in an 
    action tried without a jury, the court may open the judgment if one has been 
    entered, take additional testimony, amend findings of fact and conclusions 
    of law or make new findings and conclusions, and direct the entry of a new 
    judgment.â€Â  


   [2] Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, states:Â  â€œOn motion and upon such terms as are 
    just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final 
    judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons: (1) mistake, inadvertence, 
    surprise, or excusable neglect . . . .â€Â

title: State v. Martin
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Anthony Bradford Martin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-096
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney General Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant,
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Martin appeals his conviction 
  for murder, arguing the circuit court erred in failing to let him testify at 
  his competency hearing.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In July 1998, Martin was indicted for murdering 
  his girlfriend.Â  
A two-day competency hearing was conducted in September 
  1999.Â  During the hearing, the State offered expert testimony from psychiatrist 
  Steven Shea and forensic psychologist Pamela Crawford, both of whom had examined 
  Martin and opined that he was competent to stand trial but was malingering.Â  
  Martin offered expert testimony from psychiatrist John Howard DeWitt, who opined 
  that Martin was not competent to stand trial.Â  The circuit court subsequently 
  ruled that Martin was competent to stand trial.
At the beginning of Martinâ€™s December 1999 trial, 
  his attorney argued that Martinâ€™s condition had worsened since his September 
  1999 competency hearing, rendering him incompetent to stand trial.Â  The circuit 
  court then conducted a second competency hearing, during which Dr. DeWitt again 
  testified that Martin was incompetent to stand trial.Â  
Following Dr. DeWittâ€™s testimony, Martinâ€™s attorney 
  called Martin to testify.Â  However, Judge McKellar refused to allow Martin to 
  testify, explaining that Martin did not â€œhave the right to take the stand and 
  tell us in a competency hearing that heâ€™s not competent to stand trial.â€Â  After 
  a bench conference, Martinâ€™s attorney attempted to make an offer of proof.Â  
  The circuit court refused, explaining that its decision regarding Martinâ€™s competency 
  must be based on expert testimony.Â  It also suggested that Martinâ€™s attempt 
  to have Martin testify was a â€œdelaying tactic.â€Â  The State brought no witnesses, 
  but instead rested on the expert testimony it provided during the first hearing.Â  
  
At the conclusion of the second competency hearing, 
  the circuit court concluded that Martin was competent to stand trial.Â  A jury 
  trial followed, culminating in Martinâ€™s conviction for murder.Â  This appeal 
  follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe admission of evidence is within 
  the circuit judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent abuse 
  of that discretion.â€Â  State v. Slocumb, 336 S.C. 619, 626-27, 521 S.E.2d 
  507, 511 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the circuit judgeâ€™s 
  decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â Â  
  State v. Lopez, 352 S.C. 373, 378, 574 S.E.2d 210, 212 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Martin contends that the circuit court erred in 
  refusing to allow him to testify at his own incompetency hearing on the basis 
  that Martinâ€™s testimony would be â€œbiased.â€Â  However, we find nothing in the 
  record suggesting bias was a concern of the circuit court, much less a basis 
  for its refusal to permit Martin to testify.Â  Instead, we find the circuit court 
  based its ruling on concerns for avoiding a â€œdelay tacticâ€ and obtaining evidence 
  cumulative to that provided by Martinâ€™s own expert witness.Â  Martinâ€™s 
  attorney sought Martinâ€™s testimony not to introduce new evidence, but rather 
  to allow the circuit court to â€œhave firsthand knowledge â€¦ on Anthony Martinâ€™s 
  response or lack of responses to those same questions [posed by the experts].â€Â  
  (emphasis added).Â  Martinâ€™s attorney noted the circuit court would be â€œbetter 
  servedâ€ by allowing Martinâ€™s testimony.
While we tend to agree with Martinâ€™s attorney, 
  we are not inclined to find, on this record, an abuse of discretion in refusing 
  Martinâ€™s testimony.Â  The circuit court had conducted two competency hearings.Â  
  The judge observed, â€œIâ€™ve heard from Dr. Dewitt twice, Iâ€™ve heard from Dr. Crawford 
  and Dr. Shea â€¦ I kept real good notes. And to me, it would make no sense whatsoever 
  for you to put your defendant on the stand, for him to do the same thing heâ€™s 
  done to your psychiatrist for the last year, to convince me heâ€™s not competent 
  to stand trial â€¦.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Under those circumstances, where 
  the proposed testimony was merely to provide the circuit court with a â€œfirsthandâ€ 
  observation of Martinâ€™s responses to the same questions posed by the various 
  experts, we find that the circuit court acted within its broad discretion in 
  refusing the testimony.
Martinâ€™s final assignment of error is the claim 
  that the circuit court held that its decision regarding competence could only 
  be based on expert testimony.Â  It is true that the circuit court initially provided 
  its rationale for refusing to permit Martinâ€™s testimony on this basis, but the 
  circuit court subsequently acknowledged that the determination of competency 
  is not confined to expert testimony. Martinâ€™s attorney stated, â€œExpert testimony 
  is not the only testimony his Honor can consider for purposes of determining 
  whether or not a defendant is competent to stand trialâ€ and the circuit court 
  responded:Â  â€œI know.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Martin, in essence, assigns 
  a holding to the circuit court that the circuit court rejected.Â  The circuit 
  court acknowledged that a competency determination is not limited to 
  expert testimony, but declined Martinâ€™s testimony for the reasons discussed 
  above.Â  Thus, this ground provides no basis for relief.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court 
  is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

H. Jay Haar, of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
William W. DesChamps, Jr., of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an action for the collection 
  of an indebtedness in the sum of $200,000.Â  Ghanshyam â€œDannyâ€ Patel brought 
  this action against Vinod Patel, alleging breach of contract, breach of contract 
  accompanied by fraudulent act, constructive fraud, conversion, fraud and deceit 
  based upon misrepresentation, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  The master-in-equity 
  ruled in favor of Danny.Â  Vinod appeals, arguing a resulting trust theory.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Danny has owned and operated motels 
  in the Myrtle Beach area since 1980.Â  Vinod is in the business of constructing 
  and owning motels and is a thirty-five percent shareholder in Classic Investment, 
  Inc., a South Carolina Corporation.Â Â  
In January 1998, Classic purchased 
  unimproved real property in Surfside Beach for $500,000.Â  Vinod and Danny each 
  advanced $250,000 to Classic to enable Classic to purchase the property.Â  The 
  $250,000 loan from Danny to Classic was evidenced by a promissory note from 
  Classic in favor of Danny.Â  Classicâ€™s statement of assets, liabilities, and 
  stockholdersâ€™ equity as of December 1999 showed a land value of $500,000.Â  After 
  Classic purchased the property, it obtained a construction loan to build the 
  motel, and each of the shareholders guaranteed the loan.Â  Classic also entered 
  into a franchise agreement with Comfort Inn â€“ the shareholders personally guarantying 
  the obligations.Â  Danny was never a guarantor of any franchise obligation or 
  construction loan. 
By 2000, Danny had advanced the total 
  principal sum of $575,000 to Vinod and Classic.Â  Classic received $375,000 and 
  Vinod received $200,000, pursuant to Vinodâ€™s request and for use in constructing 
  the motel.Â  Danny testified that this $200,000 was independent of the $250,000 
  he advanced to Classic in January 1998.Â  In the confession of judgment, Classic 
  admitted liability to Danny for the $375,000.Â  In addition, the Final Order 
  and Judgment of Sale and Foreclosure confirmed the $375,000 indebtedness of 
  Classic in favor of Danny.Â  This $375,000 indebtedness includes the $250,000 
  advance Danny made to Classic in January 1998.
Although Classic admitted liability to Danny for 
  the $375,000, when Danny demanded payment from Vinod for his $200,000 indebtedness, 
  Vinod refused.Â  Danny brought this action alleging breach of contract, breach 
  of contract accompanied by fraudulent act, constructive fraud, conversion, fraud 
  and deceit based upon misrepresentations, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  
  At the April 24, 2002 hearing, the master-in-equity ruled in favor of Danny 
  and awarded judgment in the amount of $200,000 plus pre-judgment interest at 
  the legal rate of 8Â¾% from January 7, 2000 to the date of the order and post-judgment 
  interest at the rate of 12% per annum from the date of judgment until paid.Â  
  Vinod appeals, arguing the master erred in failing to find a resulting trust 
  was created in which title to the property would be conveyed from Classic to 
  Danny upon completion of the motel.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although an action to determine a resulting trust sounds in equity, 
  Vinodâ€™s resulting trust defense is based on an alleged contract between Classic 
  and Danny for the reconveyance of Classicâ€™s property.Â  Because an action on 
  a contract is one at law, this action is at law.Â  Therefore, we may only correct 
  errors of law and we are bound to uphold the masterâ€™s findings of fact unless 
  there is no evidence that reasonably supports them.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. 
  v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Vinod argues the $200,000 he received from Danny 
  was not a loan, but partial repayment for the $250,000 sum he allegedly advanced 
  on behalf of Danny to purchase the motel property in January 1998.Â  He contends 
  Danny wanted to purchase the property, but could only come up with half of the 
  purchase price; therefore, he provided the other half of the purchase price 
  as a loan to Danny.Â  As a result, he claims the trial court erred in failing 
  to find a resulting trust was created between him and Danny when he allegedly 
  advanced $250,000 to Danny and agreed to convey the property to Danny at a later 
  date.Â  
In asserting his resulting trust theory, Vinod 
  claims that title to the land was placed in the name of Classic for Dannyâ€™s 
  benefit.Â  We disagree and find the evidence shows Vinod and Danny each advanced 
  $250,000 to Classic to enable Classic to purchase the real property.Â  
  A party attempting to prove the existence of a resulting trust in real property 
  must show by clear, definite, unequivocal, and convincing evidence that the 
  beneficiary of the trust paid a portion of the purchase money at the time of 
  the transaction.Â  Glover v. Glover, 268 S.C. 433, 435, 234 S.E.2d 488, 
  489 (1977).Â  Vinod failed to meet this burden of proof.Â  He did not prove by 
  definite, clear, unequivocal, and convincing evidence that the $250,000 Danny 
  advanced to Classic in January 1998 was partial payment for the real property, 
  instead of a loan to Classic.Â  The promissory note, confession of judgment, 
  and final order all document that the $250,000 Danny advanced to Classic in 
  January 1998 was a loan from Danny to Classic.Â  The promissory note, a written 
  contract, is binding against a claimed contemporaneous oral agreement that would 
  modify or vary it.Â  Ray v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, Inc., 281 S.C. 
  170, 173, 314 S.E.2d 359, 361 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Therefore, the written promissory 
  note, and the other written evidence, is controlling over Vinodâ€™s alleged oral 
  agreement.Â  
Vinod alleges he intended for Classic to convey 
  its property and assets of Classic to Danny at a later date for a price to be 
  agreed upon.Â  However, for a resulting trust to be created, the beneficiary 
  of the trust, Danny, was required to pay the monies at the time of the purchase 
  of the property, not at some unspecified future date.Â  Glover, 268 S.C. 
  at 435, 234 S.E.2d at 489.Â  In addition, to form a binding contract, there must 
  be mutual manifestation of assent between the parties as to the contract terms, 
  and certain terms, such as price, time, and place, are indispensable and must 
  be set out with reasonable certainty.Â  McPeters v. Yeargin Constr. Co., 
  290 S.C. 327, 331, 350 S.E.2d 208, 211 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  If a contract does 
  not fix a definite price term, there must be a definite method for ascertaining 
  it.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, in the present case, because the alleged agreement 
  for Classic to convey its property to Danny did not specify a date, price, or 
  a method for ascertaining the price, it is not binding and is unenforceable.Â  

We find sufficient evidence establishing an express 
  contract between Danny and Classic for a $250,000 loan.Â  However, even if the 
  promissory note, confession of judgment, and final order did not document this 
  express contract, we find the evidence shows the existence of an implied contract 
  for repayment.Â  To have a contract implied by law, there must be a benefit conferred 
  to a party, a realization of that benefit, and an inequitable retention of the 
  benefit.Â  Myrtle Beach Hosp. Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 333 S.C. 590, 
  596, 510 S.E.2d 439, 442 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Danny conferred a benefit of $200,000 
  to Vinod.Â  Vinod realized that benefit by receiving and depositing the money 
  into his account.Â  Vinod unjustifiably retained the $200,000 without conveying 
  to Danny any valuable consideration.Â  Implied contracts are similar to restitution, 
  which permits recovery of that amount the defendant has been benefited at the 
  expense of the plaintiff in order to preclude unjust enrichment.Â  Costa & 
  Sons Constr. Co. v. Long, 306 S.C. 465, 468, 412 S.E.2d 450, 452 (Ct. App. 
  1991).Â  Based on an implied contract theory, Danny should recover the $200,000 
  consideration he paid to Vinod.
As Vinod has not appealed the trial courtâ€™s findings 
  regarding the interest to be awarded on the $200,000, the trial courtâ€™s findings 
  are the law of the case.Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina v. Soden, 
  333 S.C. 554, 556, 511 S.E.2d 372, 378 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Therefore, we affirm 
  the award of pre-judgment and post-judgment interest.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, we find no error of law by 
  the trial judge.Â  Vinodâ€™s resulting trust defense is unsubstantiated.Â  All the 
  evidence establishes the $250,000 Danny advanced to Classic in January 1998 
  was a loan, and no binding contract existed for conveying Classicâ€™s assets to 
  Danny.Â  Thus, the $200,000 Danny gave to Vinod was not repayment of a loan, 
  but was a loan to Vinod; hence, Danny is entitled to collect the $200,000 from 
  Vinod.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Frances S. Smoak, as Personal Representative 
        of the Estate of Curtis P. Smoak, and Frances S. Smoak, individually,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Terry McCullough,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Robert A. Smoak, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-098
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  17, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and
REMANDED 


  
    
      
Kirby D. Shealy, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Louis H. Lang, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:  Frances S. 
  Smoak brought this suit against an adjoining landowner, Terry McCullough, to 
  settle a boundary dispute.Â  The master-in-equity dismissed the suit, ruling 
  insufficient evidence existed within the record to determine Smoakâ€™s boundary.Â  
  Smoak appeals.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Smoak and McCullough are adjoining landowners.Â  
  Smoak owns two tracts of land.Â  The first parcel, a one-hundred-acre tract, 
  lies to the west of the second tract, sharing a common boundary line.Â  The second 
  consists of approximately 2Â½ acres and lies to the east of the first tract and 
  to the west of McCulloughâ€™s property, sharing a common east/west boundary line 
  with McCulloughâ€™s property.Â  All three parcels can be traced to a common grantor, 
  Chester Hall, and Smoakâ€™s parcels pre-date the first conveyance of McCulloughâ€™s 
  tract to his predecessors in title. 
  [1] Â  
Smoakâ€™s 2Â½-acre parcel has the following description:

All that piece, parcel or lot of land, situate [sic], in 
  the County of Aiken, State of South Carolina, containing two and one-half (2 
  Â½) acres, more or less, and adjoining lands, now or formerly, of Elizabeth Thornton, 
  on the West run of branch being the line, same commencing at run at pond dam 
  and extending forty (40) feet East from the swamp or edge of swamp bushes to 
  or within twenty (20.0) feet of spring and extending West to run of said branch 
  probably known as Starching Branch.

McCulloughâ€™s tract was established by the following 
  description:

All that certain piece, parcel or tract of land situated, 
  lying and being in [the] State of South Carolina, County of Aiken, containing 
  about two acres, more or less and bounded as follows to wit:Â  Bounded all the 
  way on the west by the Betty Thornton estate; bounded on the north, east and 
  partly on the south by a County Public Road.Â  This eastern and southern boundary 
  follows the said road going west until a point is reached about even with a 
  spring, then the said southern boundary cuts across and touches the spring on 
  the northern side then follows the run of the spring until the western boundary 
  of the Betty Thornton land is reached.Â  This makes the southern boundary of 
  the land herein conveyed, a public County road, a spring and the run or branch 
  which drains the spring.Â  The spring and spring branch are not conveyed by this 
  deed, but the right is hereby given and sold to Colie Hall, his heirs and assigns, 
  to have access and entry to the said spring and to use water from the same.

After a dispute arose about the proper boundary 
  between their properties, Smoak sued McCullough.Â  In her first cause of action, 
  Smoak alleged a dispute existed between the parties as to the location of the 
  east/west boundary separating their property, and there is confusion and uncertainty 
  as to the boundary line.Â  Smoak asked the court to settle the boundary dispute 
  and to quiet the title to her property. 
In her second cause of action, Smoak alleged she 
  is in actual possession of the disputed property, and McCullough trespassed 
  to access the pond.Â  In her third cause of action for trespass quare clausum 
  fregit, Smoak sought damages for an invasion of her possession of the property 
  by McCullough, alleging he cut and removed trees.Â  
McCullough admitted the chains of title and descriptions 
  but generally denied the material allegations of the complaint.Â Â Â  
At trial, Smoak presented the testimony of an expert 
  land surveyor.Â  In reviewing the deeds in question, Smoakâ€™s expert testified 
  he was unable to locate the eastern boundary of Smoakâ€™s tract because the swamp 
  bushes were no longer in existence.Â  
McCullough presented the testimony of his own expert 
  surveyor.Â  McCulloughâ€™s expert testified that he too was unable to locate the 
  eastern boundary of the 2Â½-acre track based on Smoakâ€™s and McCulloughâ€™s deeds 
  because the natural boundaries mentioned in both deeds no longer existed. 
McCullough also presented the testimony of M.C. Smith, 
  a former owner of his tract of land, who testified the purpose of conveying 
  the 2Â½-acre tract was to allow Smoakâ€™s predecessor in title to fill in the pond 
  and own to the edge of it. [2] Â  
The master ruled the evidence was insufficient to establish 
  a boundary between the two tracts.Â  Furthermore, the master ruled Smoak failed 
  to prove a trespass by McCullough, and for that reason, the court could not 
  provide any relief.Â  Therefore, the master dismissed the case in full. Smoak 
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[T]he character, as legal or equitable, of an 
  action is determined by the complaint in its main purpose, the nature of the 
  issues as raised by the pleadings or the pleadings and proof, and the character 
  of the relief sought under them.â€ Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 86, 
  473 S.E.2d 474, 476 (Ct. App. 1996); Ins. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. South Carolina 
  Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 315, 318 (1978).Â  Furthermore, where 
  the plaintiffâ€™s complaint alleges some feature of equitable cognizance, such 
  as obliteration of the boundary line by the adjoining landowner, a cause of 
  action to settle a boundary dispute is in equity. Uxbridge Co. v. Poppenheim, 
  135 S.C. 26, 30, 133 S.E. 461, 461 (1926).Â Â  
Smoakâ€™s complaint asks the master to 
  establish the true boundary between the properties.Â  Smoak alleges the natural 
  boundaries are no longer ascertainable because McCullough obliterated the natural 
  markers.Â  Additionally, Smoak asks the master to enjoin future trespasses.
McCullough does not assert an issue of 
  title in his answer to the complaint or at trial.Â  Furthermore, the proof presented 
  by both parties at trial supports the conclusion the natural markers defining 
  the east/west border are no longer visible, and the true boundary cannot be 
  ascertained by direct reference to them.Â  Moreover, although McCullough denies 
  obliterating the natural markers, he does admit he has cut some of the foliage 
  and filled land using a backhoe.Â  
As we view the pleadings, the paramount question 
  to be decided is the placement of the boundary between the lands of the parties 
  based upon their existing property descriptions in an action to quiet title.Â  
  Thus, we view this as an action in equity.Â  See Bryan v. Bryan, 
  285 S.C. 434, 437, 330 S.E.2d 310, 312 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding an action to 
  quiet title is one in equity).Â  This conclusion is further supported by the 
  fact that Smoak claims McCullough obliterated the swamp grass and bushes, which 
  were the only markers for the boundary between their properties. See 
  Uxbridge Co. v. Poppenheim, 135 S.C. at 30, 133 S.E. at 461. Â Consequently, 
  this Court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â Â  Hayne 
  Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 247, 489 S.E.2d 472, 475 (1997) 
  (â€œOur scope of review of a case heard by a master who enters a final judgment 
  is to determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of 
  the evidence.â€).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smoak argues the master erred by concluding the 
  boundary line between the lands owned by the parties is impossible to determine.Â  
  We agree. [3] 
â€œThe paramount and cardinal rule of construction 
  of a deed is to ascertain the intention of the grantor as expressed by him in 
  the deed and then to give effect to that intention if it can be done without 
  violating an established rule of law.â€Â  Rhodes v. Black, 170 S.C. 193, 
  200, 170 S.E. 158, 159 (1933).Â  
In ascertaining a boundary, it has long been established 
  that the court â€œresort[s], 1st, to natural boundaries, such as rocks, mountains, 
  rivers, and creeks; 2nd, to artificial marks, such as corner trees and stations; 
  3rd, to adjacent boundaries; 4th, course and distance; and 5th, the shape of 
  the plat.â€ Wash v. Holmes, 19 S.C.L. (1 Hill) 12, 15 (Ct. App. 1833).Â  

Initially, we note, the only direct evidence of 
  the boundary line is the vegetation that no longer exists.Â  There are no artificial 
  marks noted by either side, and the adjacent boundary is not directly helpful 
  because it refers to Smoakâ€™s boundary as its western boundary.Â  However, we 
  conclude the key to the solution lies in reconciling the wording of the deed 
  descriptions with the evidence within the record.
Smoakâ€™s deed states the northern boundary of the 
  2Â½-acre tract is a pond dam, and the western boundary of the tract is a creek 
  branch.Â  The deed further states the tract is bordered on the east by swamp 
  bushes, presumably on the eastern side of the watercourse.Â  The deed creating 
  McCulloughâ€™s tract states the western boundary to his tract of land is the eastern 
  boundary of Smoakâ€™s tract of land.Â  The deed further grants the right to enter 
  and use the spring drained by the branch but clearly excludes the spring from 
  the deed. [4] Â  
Aerial photographs establish the pond came into 
  existence between 1951 and 1955.Â  Furthermore, M.C. Smith, a former owner of 
  McCulloughâ€™s tract, testified he was familiar with all of the boundaries of 
  the property, even before he owned it.Â  Additionally, he testified the purpose 
  of Smoakâ€™s deed description was to allow Smoakâ€™s predecessor to fill the pond 
  and to own to the edge of it. [5] Â  
We conclude the pond dam existed at the time the 
  2Â½-acre tract was conveyed to Smoakâ€™s predecessor in title, but the pond had 
  not yet been formed.Â  
When we view the other evidence within the record 
  in light of that conclusion, we hold the grantor intended to include all of 
  the land covered by the pond within the 2Â½-acre conveyance.Â  This explains why 
  the grantors referred in the same deed to the â€œrun of branchâ€ as the western 
  edge of the 2Â½-acre tract, a natural marker no longer ascertainable once the 
  pond filled.Â  See Ex Parte Keller, 189 S.C. 26, 36, 199 S.E. 909, 
  914 (1938) (holding all grants and conveyances are presumed to be made with 
  reference to an actual view of the premises by the parties).Â  Â Additionally, 
  it is consistent with Smithâ€™s testimony that the 2Â½-acre tract was conveyed 
  with an eastern boundary paralleling the swamp grass or bushes to give Smoakâ€™s 
  predecessor the entire pond once it was formed.Â  Finally, this is consistent 
  with the express language in the deed description creating McCulloughâ€™s tract 
  giving him use and access to the spring now lying under the pond but specifically 
  excluding ownership of it from his grant. [6] 
Thus, we conclude the evidence, in conjunction 
  with the language in the deeds, indicates the 2Â½-acre tract was conveyed with 
  an eastern boundary of the swamp bushes to ensure that when the creek flooded 
  and became a pond, an eventuality that was contemplated but clearly had not 
  yet occurred, the pond would be within the 2Â½-acre tract.Â  Therefore, we hold 
  the intent of the grantors was to grant Smoakâ€™s predecessor in title exclusive 
  ownership of the pond, while granting McCullough the land up to the edge of 
  the pond.Â  Consequently, the boundary between the properties should properly 
  be marked as the edge of the pond.Â  
Having concluded the eastern edge of the pond is 
  the intended boundary separating the lands of the parties, with the right to 
  access and use the water reserved to McCullough, we agree with the masterâ€™s 
  conclusion that Smoak failed in her burden of proving trespass or trespass quare 
  clausum fregit. 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the denial of relief 
  based upon trespass and trespass quare clausum fregit is AFFIRMED, that 
  portion of the order of the master, dismissing this suit is REVERSED, 
  and this matter is REMANDED with instructions to the master to set the 
  disputed boundary dividing the lands of the parties along the eastern edge of 
  the pond in accordance with this opinion.Â  Should disagreement remain between 
  the parties as to the location of any part of the eastern edge of the pond or 
  of the disputed boundary itself after location of the pond edge, the master 
  is authorized to take all measures necessary to resolve the controversy, including 
  the taking of additional evidence or retention of a surveyor or other expert, 
  as needed, with the expense thereof to be borne by the parties in such amounts 
  as shall be determined by the master.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and 
REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF, and HOWARD, JJ., concurring.

 
   [1] 
    Smoakâ€™s chain of title begins with Chester and Jerry Hall.Â  Chester and 
    Jerry Hall conveyed the property by deed to Elizabeth Thornton in 1953.Â  Subsequently, 
    in 1964, Thorntonâ€™s heirs conveyed the property by deed to Arthur Keels.Â  
    Thereafter, in 1976, Smoak received her deed from Keels.Â  
  McCulloughâ€™s chain of title also begins with 
    Chester Hall, who granted the tract to Colie Hall almost eleven years after 
    the grant to Smoakâ€™s predecessor in 1964.Â  Colie Hall then conveyed the tract 
    to M.C. Smith in 1968.Â  M.C. Smith conveyed the tract to Janice K. Smith by 
    deed dated April 14, 1992, although the description of the tract changed to 
    refer to a plat prepared by C. Ashley Abel on March 27, 1992.Â  Janice K. Smith 
    conveyed the property to McCullough on August 18, 2000.Â  His deed makes reference 
    to a plat prepared by Arthur J. Weed on August 15, 2000.Â  

 
   
    [2] M.C. Smith is the nephew of Coley Hall.Â  Coley Hall was the son of 
    the common grantor, Jerry Hall.Â  Smithâ€™s wife was Elizabeth Thorntonâ€™s granddaughter.Â  
    Elizabeth Thornton was the initial grantee in Smoakâ€™s chain and was the sister 
    of Jerry Hall.Â  Smith testified that he was familiar with all of the boundaries 
    of the property, even before he owned it.Â  According to Smith, he was raised 
    less than 300 yards from the property and owned it for twenty-three or twenty-four 
    years.Â  

 
   [3] 
    Although we agree the master erred by dismissing the suit for lack of 
    evidence, we do not agree with Smoakâ€™s proposed boundary.Â  Smoak contends 
    this Court should connect the northeastern and southeastern boundaries of 
    her property as determined by her expert surveyor, drawing a straight line 
    between them as the east/west boundary between the properties.Â  

 
   [4] 
    Generally, when a swamp or a stream is given in a deed as the boundary 
    of property, the parties will be presumed to have intended the middle of the 
    swamp or stream as the boundary.Â  Wheeler v. Wheeler, 111 S.C. 87, 
    94, 96 S.E. 714, 715 (1918).Â  However, where, as here, the deed specifically 
    excludes the watercourse, the presumption is rebutted.Â Â  See Wheeler, 
    111 S.C. at 94-95, 96 S.E. at 716 (â€œIt may be shown that the parties intended 
    the edge of the swamp rather than the stream as the boundary . . . . [I]t 
    may be done by other competent evidence appearing either upon the face of 
    the deed itself, or of the plat made at the time, and proof of the actual 
    location of a different boundary line on the ground, and possession taken 
    and held to the boundary so located.â€).

 
   [5] 
    See Richardson v. Register, 227 S.C. 81, 90, 87 S.E.2d 40, 
    44 (1955) (holding evidence of common repute is admissible as to the location 
    of a private as well as a public boundary line); see also Holden 
    v. Cantrell, 100 S.C. 265, 279, 84 S.E. 826, 829 (1915) (holding a boundary 
    may be established by reference to declarations of former owners of plaintiffâ€™s 
    land, made while they were in possession thereof, accompanying and explaining 
    acts of ownership and tending to show the character and extent of their possession).

 
   
    [6] The confusion in this case is due partly to the fact that the deed 
    creating McCulloughâ€™s tract, conveyed to his predecessor in title eleven years 
    after the 2Â½-acre tract was conveyed, does not mention the pond and refers 
    only to Smoakâ€™s predecessorâ€™s eastern boundary as its western boundary.Â  The 
    problem is exacerbated by the reference to a spring that drains a branch now 
    forming a part of the pond.Â  The aerial photographs taken in 1955 show the 
    pond was in existence, and the line of the branch was no longer ascertainable.

Dorothy Kelehear, Samuel Kelehear, Sr., John
Doe,/Oand Princess A. Cartrette

06/24/95,/OAlonzo L. Cartrette a/k/a Samuel Kelehear, Jr.Â  DOB:Â  06/04/97/OMinor(s)

Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed

Dorothy Kelehear, of Tabor City, James P. Saverance, Jr., of Bishopville, for 
  Appellant.
Stephen Bryan Doby, of Bishopville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Dorothy Kelehear appeals from

  The family court found that the children had lived outside Kelehearâ€™s home for 
  more than six months. The family court also heard testimony that Kelehear failed 
  to support the children. See S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2000).
Pursuant to Ex parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465,

Upon reviewing the record and the family courtâ€™s 
  determination in its entirety, we find no meritorious issues warranting briefing. 
  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Michael Westbury,       
        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dorchester County and Patrick Watts,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-100
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed February 17, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Westbury, of St. George, for Appellant.
Marvin C. Jones and R. Clenten Campbell, of Walterboro, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant sued Dorchester County 
  and the master in equity after the master vacated Appellantâ€™s purchase of a 
  property at an auction conducted by the master. The trial judge granted summary 
  judgment to both defendants. We affirm.
 FACTS
Dorchester County sold a property at an auction 
  on March 1, 1999. That auction was a mistake because Money First Financial Services, 
  one of the interested parties, had not been properly noticed about the auction. [1]  Michael Westbury attended the auction and placed 
  the highest bid. Following the sale, the master in equity realized that the 
  auction had been an error, not only because Money First did not attend, but 
  also because a new Notice of Sale had not been issued. The master vacated the 
  sale and refunded Westbury his earnest money. When the property was properly 
  auctioned in July 1999, Westbury was present but did not place the highest bid; 
  therefore he did not obtain the property. 
In February 2001, Westbury brought a â€œviolation 
  of legal sale actionâ€ against Dorchester County and Patrick Watts, the master 
  who conducted the sale. Following a hearing where Westbury acted as his own 
  counsel, the trial court issued an order granting summary judgment to the county 
  and to the master. Westbury appeals.
ISSUES 
  [2]   

1) Did the trial court err in finding that the master 
  was entitled to judicial immunity? 
(2) Did the trial court err in granting summary 
  judgment to the master?

ANALYSIS 
  [3]   
Summary judgment is appropriate where there is 
  no genuine issue of material fact and it is clear the moving party is entitled 
  to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP. â€œIn determining whether 
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  
  Osborne ex rel. Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 
  (2001). An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same 
  standard applied by the trial court.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 
  451, 548 S.E.2d 868, 873 (2001).
The trial court ruled that the master was acting 
  within his official capacity and was therefore entitled to judicial immunity. 
  We agree. Judicial immunity is a longstanding legal principle. See McEachern 
  v. Black, 329 S.C. 642, 647, 496 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œJudicial 
  immunity is one of the fundamental pillars upon which the modern system of justice 
  was built.â€). That principle is statutory and is also recognized at common law. 
  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 246, 553 S.E.2d 496, 506 (Ct. App. 
  2001). â€œJudicial immunity affords absolute immunity from suit. Therefore, a 
  finding of judicial immunity renders a complaint alleging judicial misconduct 
  meritless.â€ McEachern, 329 S.C. at 647, 496 S.E.2d at 661 (citation omitted).Â  
  However, judicial immunity will not protect judicial officers if they act without 
  any jurisdiction, or if their act is not a judicial one, or if the suit is seeking 
  exclusively prospective, injunctive relief. Id. at 648, 496 S.E.2d at 
  662. 
Here, the master was acting within his official 
  capacity when he mistakenly allowed the auction to proceed on the wrong date 
  and without proper notice. And he was acting within his official capacity when 
  he vacated the sale. Therefore, his actions were well within the limits of his 
  jurisdiction. Westbury seems to argue that the master should be liable because 
  the master made a mistake. But a master would be â€œabsolutely immune from liability 
  for his judicial acts even if his exercise of authority [was] flawed by the 
  commission of grave procedural errors.â€ Id. at 649, 496 S.E.2d at 663. 
  The trial court was correct in granting summary judgment to the master.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  The original date was March 1, but the master 
    had changed it to April 5.

 
   [2]  Westbury raises the following issues: â€œ(1) Did 
    the trial judge err in finding [the master was] employed by Dorchester County? 
    (2) Did the trial judge err in finding that [the master was] paid by Dorchester 
    County tax dollars of $52,593? (3) Exhibits 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.â€ Since Westbury 
    seeks a reversal of the summary judgment as â€œto the charge of appellant as 
    listed in [the] complaint,â€ we adopt Dorchesterâ€™s articulation of the issues.Â Â  
  

 
   [3]  The trial court granted summary judgment to both 
    the master and the county. In his brief, Westbury mentions that â€œDorchester 
    County has an employee named Judge Patrick Watts,â€ (the master). But that 
    declaration is a mere statement of fact, not an argument. Since Westbury presented 
    no substantive argument against the judgeâ€™s ruling concerning Dorchester County, 
    he is considered to have waived that issue on appeal. See Gold Kist, 
    Inc. v. Citizens and S. Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 286 S.C. 272, 275, 
    333 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1985) (ruling that issues not argued in the appellantâ€™s 
    brief are deemed abandoned on appeal). Therefore, we limit our analysis to 
    the summary judgment concerning the master.
