THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Beverly Hutto,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
County of Aiken,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Robert A. Smoak, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-101
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed February 18, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Chaplin Cox, III, of Columbia, for Appellant,
F. Matlock Elliott andÂ  Phillip Florence, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Beverly Hutto appeals a grant 
  of summary judgment to the County of Aiken based on her failure to serve the 
  summons and complaint in her civil action against the County within the prescribed 
  statute of limitations.Â  Hutto contends that, as a matter of law, service was 
  sufficiently completed before the statute of limitations expired.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In May 2000, a family court judge in Aiken County 
  issued a bench warrant for Hutto, alleging she failed to pay child support â€œas 
  ordered.â€Â  Consequently, Hutto was arrested and incarcerated in June 2000. 
  [1] Â  
Hutto initiated the present action, claiming she 
  was improperly arrested because the bench warrant was issued based on false 
  information given to the family court by an employee of the Aiken County Clerk 
  of Court. [2] Â  According to a signed â€œcertified mail receiptâ€, 
  she mailed a copy of the summons and complaint to â€œJoan Williams Interim Adm. 
  828 Richland Ave., W. Aiken, SC 29801â€ in December 2001.Â  A person named Sherry 
  Mathis apparently signed the receipt on December 12, 2001, indicating receipt 
  of the summons and complaint.
The County did not answer the summons and complaint, 
  prompting Hutto to seek an order granting entry of default against the county.Â  
  The County subsequently moved to set aside the entry of default.Â  In August 
  2, 2002 order, the master-in-equity set aside the entry of default, finding 
  â€œthe Complaint was never properly served on the Defendant [County] in this matter.â€Â  
  Additionally, he specified that attorney James M. Davis was the Countyâ€™s proper 
  agent for service of process, and directed Hutto to effect service on him.Â  
  Hutto then served the summons and complaint on Davis on August 8, 2002.Â  
After receiving service of Huttoâ€™s summons and 
  complaint, the County filed a motion for summary judgment, arguing the action 
  was barred by the applicable two-year statute of limitations provided by the 
  S.C. Tort Claims Act.Â  Following a hearing, the master-in-equity granted the 
  Countyâ€™s summary judgment motion based upon his finding that Huttoâ€™s action 
  was barred by the two-year statute of limitations provided by the S.C. Tort 
  Claimâ€™s Act, since Huttoâ€™s cause of action arose in June 2000 but she didnâ€™t 
  complete service until August 2002.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate 
  when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the 
  moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  CafÃ© Assocs., 
  Ltd. v. Gerngross, 305 S.C. 6, 9, 406 S.E.2d 162, 164 (1991).Â  â€œIn ruling 
  on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and the inferences which can 
  be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hutto argues that the trial court erred in granting 
  summary judgment to the County on the ground that her action was bared by the 
  applicable statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
As an initial matter, we note that Hutto does not 
  dispute that the action is subject to a two-year statute of limitations provided 
  by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. 15-78-110 
  (Supp. 2001); Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129, 134, 580 S.E.2d 109, 
  112 (2003) (â€œ[A]ny action brought pursuant to this chapter is forever barred 
  unless an action is commenced within two years after the date the loss was or 
  should have been discovered.â€)Â  Instead, she contends that service was effectuated 
  when she mailed the summons and complaint to â€œJoan Williamsâ€ in December 2001.Â  
  Specifically, she contends she substantially complied with the rule of civil 
  procedure regarding service of process by mailing the documents to the Aiken 
  County Administrator, â€œthe proper agent for service of process against the County 
  of Aiken.â€ 
Rule 4(d), SCRCP, provides service of process may 
  be made:

(1) Â Â Â  Upon an individual other than a minor under the age 
  of 14 years or an incompetent person, by delivering a copy of the summons and 
  complaint to him personally or by leaving copies thereof at his dwelling house 
  or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then 
  residing therein, or by delivering a copy to an agent authorized by appointment 
  or by law to receive service of process.  
â€¦
(3) Â Â Â  Upon a corporation or upon a partnership or other 
  unincorporated association which is subject to suit under a common name, by 
  delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer, a managing 
  or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law 
  to receive service of process and if the agent is one authorized by statute 
  to receive service and the statute so requires, by also mailing a copy to the 
  defendant. 


  (emphasis added).Â  This rule serves the dual purposes of conferring personal 
  jurisdiction on the court and assuring the defendant of reasonable notice of 
  the action.Â  Id.Â  
The plaintiff bears the burden of establishing 
  that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant.Â  Moore v. Simpson, 
  322 S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 66 (1996).Â  Exacting compliance with the rules 
  of civil procedure is not required to effect service of process.Â  Id.Â  
  â€œRather, inquiry must be made as to whether the plaintiff has sufficiently complied 
  with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction of the defendant 
  and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.â€Â  Id.Â  
Here, Hutto attempted service, as required 
  by Rule 4(d), SCRCP, on a person named Joan Williams, as the purported Interim 
  Aiken County Administrator.Â  However, the record contains no dispute as to the 
  fact that Aiken County did not employ a person named Joan Williams or that it 
  did not have an interim county administrator at the time service was attempted.Â  
  The summons and complaint were apparently received by a person named Sherry 
  Mathis, who signed the receipt returned from the summons and complaint.Â  There 
  is no allegation that any person named Sherry Mathis had specific authorization 
  to receive service on behalf of the County.Â  Thus, we find as a matter of law 
  that Hutto did not sufficiently comply with the applicable rules of civil procedure, 
  and consequently failed to effectuate service upon the County during her December 
  2001 attempt.Â  See Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. at 523-24, 473 S.E.2d 
  at 56-57 (determining that without specific authorization to receive service, 
  service is not effected upon an employee of a Defendant.)Â  While exacting compliance 
  with service of process rules is not required, the departure here is too substantial.Â  
  To uphold this attempted service as valid would effectively render the requirements 
  of Rule 4 meaningless.
We find that the record indicates Huttoâ€™s cause 
  of action arose in June 2000 and a two-year statute of limitations applies.Â  
  Accordingly, the statutory period within which she was required to complete 
  service of process sufficient to confer personal jurisdiction over the County 
  expired in June 2002.Â  Because the record indicates that Hutto did not properly 
  effect service on the County until two months later, in August 2002, we find 
  as a matter of law that the master-in-equity properly granted summary judgment 
  to the County on the grounds that the action was barred by the statute of limitations.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the Master-in-Equity 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The record is unclear as the specific date of her arrest or 
    the duration of her incarceration.Â  The parties do not dispute that she was 
    arrested in June 2000.Â  As to the duration of her incarceration, Huttoâ€™s brief 
    states she â€œremained in custody against her will until she was released by 
    the presiding Family Court Judge of Aiken County.â€Â  The County of Aikenâ€™s 
    brief specifies that she only remained in jail â€œover night.â€

 
   
     
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The summons and complaint does not appear in the record, but 
    the record and briefs indicate Hutto brought a negligence action against the 
    County for false arrest.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Pamela Ann Lautner,       
        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jack Louis Lautner,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Timothy M. Cain, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-103
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Bruce W. Bannister, of Greenville, for Appellant
Pamela A. Forrest, of Fountain Inn, pro se.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action, Jack 
  Lautner (Husband) appeals an order by the family court regarding the equitable 
  distribution of marital property owned by him and his wife, Pamela (Wife).Â  
  He argues the family court erred in finding passive earnings on the nonmarital 
  portion of a retirement account to be marital property.Â  We reverse and remand. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 
  1985 in Greenville County.Â  They separated on April 11, 2000, and this domestic 
  action followed.Â  At the time of the marriage, Husband worked for Hart Graphics, 
  Inc., which provided a 401(k) retirement account.
At the initial hearing, it was 
  agreed by the parties that portions of this account were earned prior to the 
  marriage and that other portions were marital property.Â  The parties agreed 
  that Wife would provide the court with appropriate records from the retirement 
  plan administrator as to the value of the account on the date of the marriage 
  and that Husbandâ€™s expert would calculate the amount of passive increases thereto.Â  
  At the second hearing, however, neither party presented an official record as 
  to the exact amount of the account on the date of the marriage.Â  Husband informed 
  the court that he was unable to obtain this information from the plan administrator.
Notwithstanding the lack of official 
  records as to the value of the account on the date of the marriage, both parties 
  presented evidence concerning this non-marital portion and the passive increases 
  thereafter accumulated.Â  Wifeâ€™s expert was not present at trial and was not 
  subject to any cross-examination as to his qualifications or methods. All evidence 
  provided by him was in the form of a one-page report.Â  Husbandâ€™s expert appeared 
  at trial and seemed to base his testimony on additional data not considered 
  by Wifeâ€™s expert. Â The judge found the report and evidence presented 
  by Husbandâ€™s expert to be the most reliable and allocated this reportâ€™s recommended 
  $16,606 as the pre-marital contribution amount. Â The judge also found 
  that this amount has since earned passive increases of $64,485. Â While 
  not waiving any claim to these passive increases, Wifeâ€™s counsel did stipulate 
  to the method of calculation of the value of the premarital portion of the account.
In his final order concerning the 
  equitable distribution of the property, the judge awarded Husband a credit for 
  the premarital contribution amount, but deemed all passive increases â€œmarital 
  propertyâ€ and divided this amount between the parties. Â Husband appeals, 
  arguing that the judge erred in holding that passive earnings on the nonmarital 
  portion of the retirement account constituted marital property.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this 
  court has the authority to find facts in accordance with our own view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 
  S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require 
  us to disregard the findings of the family court judge, who saw and heard the 
  witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign 
  comparative weight to their testimony.Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 
  583, 591, 506 S.E.2d 1, 5 (Ct. App. 1998).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Under South Carolina law, it is clear 
  that a passive increase in the value of a pre-marital investment, unless the 
  investment is transmuted into marital property, remains nonmarital property 
  and is not subject to equitable division by order of the family court.Â  
The family court does not have jurisdiction or authority 
  to apportion nonmarital property.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 
  2003) (â€œThe court does not have jurisdiction or authority to apportion nonmarital 
  property.â€).Â  Marital property is statutorily defined as any property â€œacquired 
  by the parties during the marriage.â€ Id.Â  The statute also clearly states 
  that any â€œincrease in value in nonmarital property, except to the extent that 
  the increase resulted directly or indirectly from efforts of the other spouseâ€ 
  remains non-marital property.Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-473(5); See also 
  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 294, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 
  1998) (finding passive earnings on a nonmarital IRA account to be nonmarital 
  property).
In the case before us, the family court judge found, 
  and the parties agreed, that a portion of Husbandâ€™s retirement fund was nonmarital 
  property invested prior to the marriage.Â  This amount was stipulated and properly 
  credited to Husband.Â  The amount of earnings, however, that this amount had 
  accrued through no effort by either spouse was wrongfully split between Husband 
  and Wife.Â  Having determined at trial that $64,485 of the retirement fund was 
  attributable to passive earnings on nonmarital investments, it was then error 
  to divide this portion of the fund between the parties. Unless transmuted or 
  the result of efforts by the claiming spouse, any increase in the value of nonmarital 
  property is itself nonmarital property. See Johnson, 296 S.C. 
  at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110; Calhoun v. Calhoun, 331 S.C. 157, 174, 501 
  S.E.2d 735, 744 (Ct. App. 1998), reversed in part 339 S.C. 
  96, 529 S.E.2d 14 (2000).Â  
In rather conclusory fashion, Wife claims for the 
  first time on appeal that the retirement account became marital property through 
  transmutation.Â  While in certain circumstances nonmarital property may be transmuted 
  into marital property, the spouse asserting this transmutation â€œmust produce 
  [at trial, not on appeal] objective evidence showing that, during the marriage, 
  the parties themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.â€ 
  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 298, 372 S.E.2d at 110-11.Â  Wife cites no such evidence, 
  nor can we find any, in the record on appeal. [2]   
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family 
  court, holding that passive earnings on the non-marital portion of the retirement 
  account constituted marital property, is
REVERSED.Â  We REMAND for a recalculation of the equitable distribution 
  award. 
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  In her responsive brief, Wife also makes vague claims of collusion 
    and misrepresentations at trial. We deem these claims abandoned due their 
    conclusory nature and the fact they are not in any way supported by the record. 
    See Bowen v. Lee Process Sys. Co., 342 S.C. 232, 536 S.E.2d 
    86 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that the failure to provide argument or supporting 
    authority for an issue renders it abandoned); Zaman v. South Carolina Bd. 
    of Med. Examâ€™rs, 305 S.C. 281, 408 S.E.2d 213 (1991) (holding that an 
    appellate court will not consider any fact which does not appear in the record 
    on appeal).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sharon Lippincott,       
Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard Lippincott,       
Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-104
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George J. Morris, of Charleston, for Appellant-Respondent.
Richard Lippincott, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Sharon Lippincott 
  (â€œWifeâ€) and Richard Lippincott (â€œHusbandâ€) each appeal the family courtâ€™s valuation 
  of certain assets in its equitable distribution of marital property following 
  their divorce.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife initiated this divorce 
  proceeding in 1998.Â  Following their separation, they entered into a settlement 
  agreement that was approved and incorporated into an order of the family court 
  dated July 17, 2001.Â  Under the terms of the agreement, Husband and Wife agreed 
  to distribute their marital estate in equal shares. 
A disagreement arose, however, regarding the value 
  of several marital assets and liabilities.Â  The disputed items included:Â  Wifeâ€™s 
  money purchase pension plan, furniture from the marital home, marital debt and 
  expenses, and Husbandâ€™s Individual Retirement Account (IRA).Â  Unable to resolve 
  the problem themselves, Husband and Wife sought the aid of the family court 
  to determine the value of these items.Â  On June 4, 2002, the court conducted 
  a hearing on the matter.Â  On August 2, 2002, the court issued an order determining 
  the value of the disputed items and dividing them equally. 
By way of the present cross-appeal, Husband and 
  Wife both argue the family court erred in reaching its valuations.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this Court has 
  authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 
  157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard 
  the findings of the court below.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 
  477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the trial judge, who saw 
  and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility 
  and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  McAlister v. Patterson, 
  278 S.C. 481, 483, 299 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1982).
The family court has broad discretion in determining 
  how marital property is to be distributed.Â  Murphy v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 
  324, 329, 461 S.E.2d 39, 41 (1995). The court below may use any reasonable means 
  to divide the property equitably, and its judgment will not be disturbed absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. at 329, 461 S.E.2d at 41-42.
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wifeâ€™s Appeal
Wife claims the family 
  court erred in its valuation of her money purchase pension plan.Â  We disagree.
The family court found 
  the value of the pension was $13,113.56 and that, under the separation agreement, 
  the parties were entitled to equal shares of $6,556.78. While not explicitly 
  stated in the family courtâ€™s order, this amount appears to be the value of the 
  pension as reflected on a June 30, 2000 
  [1]  pension statement, which lists the vested account balance as $13,113.56. 

Wife argues the family 
  court should have valued the pension as of June 1998, the time the parties separated.Â  
  As a general rule, Wife is correct.Â  Though the required date of valuation is 
  not specifically prescribed by statute, our courts have held that the valuation 
  date should be the date marital litigation is commenced, â€œsince that is the 
  time that property must now be owned to come within the meaning of the term 
  â€˜marital property.â€™â€Â  Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 203, 363 S.E.2d 404, 
  409 (Ct. App. 1987); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003) (defining 
  â€œmarital propertyâ€ as property â€œowned as of the date of filing or commencement 
  of marital litigationâ€); Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 151, 473 S.E.2d 
  804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œMarital property is valued as of the date of the 
  filing of the complaint.â€); Jamar v. Jamar, 308 S.C. 265, 267, 417 S.E.2d 
  615, 616 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œThe proper date to value marital property is the 
  time the marital litigation is filed or commenced.â€). 
This rule, however, has not been 
  inflexibly applied.Â  In Fields v. Fields, 342 S.C. 182, 536 S.E.2d 684 
  (Ct. App. 2000), this Court recognized that the family court should be given 
  latitude to account for appreciation or depreciation in marital assets that 
  occurs after separation but before the equitable division can be effectuated.Â  
  In that case, securities that had been awarded to the wife increased in value 
  during the eleven months between separation and the time the divorce was granted 
  and the property was divided. Id. at 187, 536 S.E.2d at 686.Â  The family 
  court assessed the value of the stocks as of the time of division, finding the 
  later date was the closest date to the partiesâ€™ divorce for which corporate 
  information was available. Id.Â  This Court held that â€œthe family court 
  was well within its discretion in deciding to value [the stocks] on the later 
  date.â€ Id.
As in Fields, the only 
  information available regarding the value of the asset in the present case was 
  for the later, post-separation date well after the commencement of the action.Â  
  Other than Wifeâ€™s brief testimony that the money purchase pension plan was the 
  equivalent of Husbandâ€™s IRA valued on June 30, 1998, at approximately $2,058.79, 
  the June 2000 statement is the only evidence of the pensionâ€™s value contained 
  in the record before us.Â  Wifeâ€™s assertions regarding the June 1998 value of 
  the pension is without any substantiation in the record. 
Having failed to meet 
  a minimal level of proof, Wife left the family court with little choice in selecting 
  a value for the pension plan.Â  The family court, therefore, did not err in assigning 
  the $13,113.56 value.Â  See Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 228, 
  512 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIt is an unfortunate reality that, given 
  the volume of cases handled by our family courts, there often is a substantial 
  delay between the commencement of an action and its ultimate resolution.Â  Thus, 
  it is not unusual for the value of marital assets to change, sometimes substantially, 
  between the time the action was commenced and its final resolution.Â  In such 
  a case, the family court has the ability to consider the post-filing appreciation 
  or depreciation when valuing and apportioning the marital estate.â€); Woodward 
  v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating 
  the family courtâ€™s valuation of property will be affirmed if it is within the 
  range of the evidence); Smith, 294 S.C. at 198, 363 S.E.2d at 407 (holding 
  the family court may accept one partyâ€™s valuations of marital property over 
  those of the other party).
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s 
  Appeal
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In his cross-appeal, 
  Husband asserts the family court erred by unevenly dividing the furniture from 
  the marital home, incorrectly calculating the marital debt, and improperly including 
  his IRA as part of the marital property.Â  We address Husbandâ€™s arguments separately 
  below.Â  As with Wifeâ€™s claim, however, we find Husbandâ€™s claims fail for complete 
  lack of proof.
A.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Furniture
The parties stipulated as a part 
  of their settlement agreement that the furniture had a value of $15,500 and 
  that it would be divided equally by in-kind distribution. Husband argues he 
  did not receive his share of the furniture, claiming that Wife changed the locks 
  to the marital home and prevented him from retrieving his furniture.Â  While 
  there is a brief mention of furniture division during the cross-examination 
  of Wife and direct-examination of Husband, it does not appear from the record 
  that this specific argument was raised to or ruled upon by the court.Â Â  As such, 
  it is not properly preserved for this Courtâ€™s review.Â  See Wilder 
  Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 77, 497 S.E.2d 731, 734 (1998) (holding an 
  issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); 
  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 369, 489 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 
  1997) (stating issue must be raised to and ruled on by family court to be preserved 
  for review).Â Â  
Â  Regardless of whether this 
  issue was properly preserved, the claim fails because Husband points to no evidence 
  in the record indicating the value of the furniture Husband contends he was 
  entitled to but did not receive.Â Â Â  Indeed, in neither the record nor Husbandâ€™s 
  briefs submitted to this Court is there any mention of the type of furniture 
  he claims or the size or number of the pieces.Â  The only statement is in Husbandâ€™s 
  brief where he claims: â€œThe Wife took what she wanted, . . . and left the Husband 
  one room of furniture of the marital home that equaled Two Thousand Five Hundred 
  Dollars ($2500.00). . .The Husband should receive a credit for the remaining 
  rooms of furniture that he did not take delivery of in the amount of Five Thousand 
  Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($5250).â€ 
For several reasons, this bare 
  assertion fails to satisfy Husbandâ€™s burden of showing the family court erred.Â  
  First, as previously stated, this particular argument was not raised to the 
  family court.Â  Secondly, there is no evidence in the Record on Appeal to support 
  this claim.Â  Accordingly, this Court may not consider it in our review of this 
  issue.Â  See Rule 210(h), SCACR (providing that appellate court review 
  is limited to evidence contained within the Record on Appeal); see also 
  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979) (stating 
  appellant has the burden of convincing this Court that the family court erred); 
  Chanko v. Chanko, 327 S.C. 636, 643, 490 S.E.2d 630, 634 (Ct. App. 1997) 
  (â€œA litigant who fails to offer proof on an issue may not be heard to complain 
  about the courtâ€™s resolution of that issue.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
B.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Marital 
  Debt and Expenses
Husband argues the family court 
  improperly valued and inequitably apportioned various marital debts and expenses.Â  

In making an equitable apportionment, 
  the family court should consider â€œ. . . any other existing debts incurred by 
  the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage[.]â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œ [S]ection 20-7-472 creates a presumption 
  that a debt of either spouse incurred prior to marital litigation is a marital 
  debt and must be factored in the totality of equitable apportionment.â€Â  Hardy 
  v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 436, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œThe 
  presumption is rebuttable.â€Â  Id.

(1) Â Â Â Â Â  Marital DebtÂ  

The family court valued the marital 
  debt at $15,145.41.Â  Although the court did not specify, this figure appears 
  to be the aggregate balance of five credit cards. Husband argues this was error 
  because the credit card statements Wife submitted at the final hearing were 
  either out-of-date or inaccurate.Â  The record, however, contains no evidence 
  reflecting what Husband claims to be the â€œcorrectâ€ amount of credit card debt.Â  
  As such, we cannot find the court erred in accepting Wifeâ€™s valuation of the 
  marital debt.Â  See Hardy, 311 S.C. at 437, 429 S.E.2d at 813-14Â  
  (holding the estate to be equitably divided by the family court is the net estate, 
  i.e., provision for the payment of marital debts must be apportioned 
  as well as the property itself; â€œbasically the same rules of fairness and equity 
  which apply to the equitable division of marital property also apply to the 
  division of marital debtsâ€); Honea v. Honea, 292 S.C. 456, 458, 357 S.E.2d 
  191, 192 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating the burden is on appellant to show the family 
  court committed reversible error and a party cannot sit back at trial without 
  offering proof, then come to the appellate court complaining of the insufficiency 
  of evidence to support the family courtâ€™s findings); see also Cherry 
  v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981) (holding an 
  appellate court is not required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who 
  saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility 
  and assign comparative weight to their testimony).
Husband next argues he should 
  be credited for loans obtained by Wife that were collateralized by the marital 
  401(K) retirement savings account.Â  Husband claims the debt incurred through 
  these loans should not be imputed to the marital estate because Wife forged 
  his signature in order to obtain them.Â  While there is a mention of loans obtained 
  by Wife in her testimony and Husbandâ€™s testimony in the record, no such loan 
  is accounted for in the family courtâ€™s order.Â  Husband did not raise this issue 
  in a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Thus, this issue is not properly 
  before this Court.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 
  S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding an issue not preserved where the trial court 
  does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant fails to make a Rule 
  59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the judgment on that ground).Â Â  Furthermore, 
  the record does not contain any documentary evidence concerning any loans.Â  

(2)Â Â Â Â Â Â  Marital Expenses

Husband also contends the family 
  court erred by including Wifeâ€™s claim of $2,800 for expenses incurred in the 
  sale of the marital home, arguing these expenses were unsubstantiated and unjustified. [2] Â  
Pursuant to the settlement order 
  entered on July 21, 2001, the parties were directed to equally divide the proceeds 
  from the sale of the marital home.Â  Prior to the sale of the home, Wife paid 
  for home repairs, painting, yard work, and cleaning.Â  The $2,800 figure appears 
  to be the amount charged for minor home repairs itemized on a bill from a handyman 
  service that is included in the record before us. Â Â 
Beyond Husbandâ€™s assertion in 
  his brief that the $2,800 repair expense â€œwas completely unjustified, unneeded 
  and uncorroborated by a[] Real Estate Agentâ€ and was undertaken â€œwithout Husband[â€™]s 
  knowledge or approval,â€ Husband offered no evidence that the division of that 
  expense equally between the parties was improper or without foundation.Â  Based 
  on our review of the record, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s inclusion 
  of the home repair bill given the expenses were incurred in preparation for 
  the sale of the marital home.Â Â  See Hardy, 311 S.C. at 436-37, 
  429 S.E.2d at 813 (â€œâ€˜[M]arital debtâ€™ is debt incurred for the joint benefit 
  of the parties regardless of whether the parties are legally jointly liable 
  for the debt or whether one party is legally individually liable.â€); Jenkins 
  v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 103, 545 S.E.2d 531, 539 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œDebts 
  incurred for marital purposes are subject to equitable distribution.â€); McElveen 
  v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 605, 506 S.E.2d 1, 12 (Ct. App. 1998) (stating 
  appellant bears burden of convincing the appellate court that the family court 
  erred).Â  Moreover, to the extent Husband challenges the amount of the home repair 
  bill, we find the evidence in the record supports the family courtâ€™s decision. 
  See Roe v. Roe, 311 S.C. 471, 478, 429 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 
  1993) (finding family court did not abuse its discretion where valuation of 
  marital property was supported by the evidence); see also Toler v. 
  Toler, 292 S.C. 374, 379, 356 S.E.2d 429, 432 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œIn the absence 
  of contrary evidence, the court should have accepted the value the parties assigned 
  toâ€ a marital asset.).Â Â Â  
C.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Inclusion 
  of IRA as Marital Property
The family court included Husbandâ€™s 
  IRA as a part of the marital estate and accordingly apportioned its value in 
  equal shares to the parties.Â Â  Husband asserts the IRA should not be included 
  as marital property because he purchased the IRA in 1983, approximately four 
  years prior to the marriage and never made any deposits or withdrawals from 
  the account during the marriage.Â  
There is no evidence, however, 
  this argument was raised to the court below or that the courtâ€™s inclusion of 
  the IRA as marital property was in any way challenged prior to this appeal.Â  
  This issue is, therefore, not properly before this Court. See Creech 
  v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Resources Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 33-34, 
  491 S.E.2d 571, 576 (1997) (holding that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court 
  to be preserved for appellate review); see also Iâ€™On, L.L.C. 
  v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (opining 
  that error preservation requirements are intended â€œto enable the lower court 
  to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and argumentsâ€).
CONCLUSION
Husband and Wife have 
  both failed to preserve these arguments for appeal or have failed to present 
  sufficient proof to warrant disturbing the family courtâ€™s valuation and distribution 
  of marital property.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Due to the quality of the photocopy, the date on the account is 
    not entirely clear.Â  However, it appears June 30, 2000, is the actual date 
    based on the facts set forth in Wifeâ€™s brief.Â  

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The family court awarded a total of $3,337.76 for repair and maintenance 
    expenses incurred in connection with the sale of the house.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jeremy Jerome Knight,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion N0. 2004-UP-105
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and SolicitorÂ  
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â   Jeremy Jerome Knight 
  was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Knight appeals, 
  arguing the circuit court erred by refusing to charge the jury on the law of 
  voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Knight and Miranda Aull were friends.Â  Together, they 
  attended a small party at the apartment of Bryant Cheeks and Jeremy Petty. During 
  the evening, they went to Pacolet, S.C., to attend another party and then returned 
  in the early morning hours to continue the party at the first residence.Â  Everyone 
  was drinking alcohol, and some were using drugs.Â  Knight consumed both alcohol 
  and drugs. 
Aull spent the rest of the night in Bryant Cheeksâ€™ 
  bedroom, where the two had sexual relations.Â  Knight slept on the living room 
  couch, but according to Cheeks, he frequently knocked on the bedroom door, pestering 
  Cheeks and Aull.Â  The next morning Cheeks arose, dressed, and left for work.Â  
  Aull told him she was going to her grandmotherâ€™s house to change and shower 
  but would return later in the afternoon when Cheeks got off work at 3:00 p.m.Â  
  Cheeks attempted to arouse Knight to send him home, but Knight said he was too 
  drunk to go home and asked to remain on the couch until later in the day.Â  Petty 
  was asleep in his bedroom with his door closed. 
Pettyâ€™s mother subsequently arrived to awaken Petty.Â  
  As she walked by the slightly opened door to Cheeksâ€™ bedroom, she saw Knight 
  laying spread-eagled on the bed.Â  She awoke Petty, and as she was leaving the 
  home, Knight came out of the bedroom with scratches on his face.Â  The wounds 
  were white, with fresh blood coming from them. 
When Cheeks returned from work in the afternoon, he 
  found Aull lying dead on the bed.Â  She was stiff and cold.Â  Lying on the bed 
  around her were pieces of a necklace, including a sharkâ€™s tooth witnesses testified 
  was always worn by Knight.Â  DNA samples taken from Aullâ€™s fingernail scrapings 
  matched the DNA of Knight with a probability of 6.3 trillion to one.Â  
When Knight was arrested, he gave two, conflicting 
  statements.Â  The first read as follows:

Around dusk on Sunday night (2/24 of â€™02) I drove my blue 
  Toyota Cressida to Jerome Pettyâ€™s duplex.Â  When I got there, Jerome was there, 
  and his roommate, Bryant Cheeks.Â  Also there was Miranda Aull and several other 
  people.Â  Everybody was drinking.Â  Later on Miranda went into one of the bedrooms 
  and changed clothes.Â  She came out half naked and walked around.Â  Later on someone 
  said something about going to a liquor house in Pacolet.Â  Me and Jerome rode 
  in my, my car, and Bryant, Miranda and the rest of the folks rode with Bryant.Â  
  We stayed at the liquor house until a fight broke out.Â  Miranda rode back with 
  me and Jerome.Â  When I got back to the duplex it was me, Jerome, Bryant and 
  Miranda.Â  I started watching a video in the living room.Â  Miranda went Jerome 
  - - went with Jerome to his bedroom.Â  Less than an hour later Miranda came out 
  of Jeromeâ€™s bedroom.Â  She was naked.Â  She knocked on Bryantâ€™s door and told 
  him to unlock the door.Â  He let her in.Â  I knew that they were having sex - 
  - that they were having sex with her.Â  At some point I remember knocking on 
  Bryantâ€™s door.Â  Finally he came.Â  I told him to tell her to come up there because 
  I wanted to talk to her.Â  She never came out.Â  I passed out.Â  The next thing 
  I know I am waking up.Â  Iâ€™m face down on the floor at the foot of Bryantâ€™s bed.Â  
  I remember hearing Bryant, but never saw him.Â  This is when I got up on the 
  bed with Miranda.Â  Miranda was in and out of sleep.Â  I donâ€™t remember exactly 
  what I said, but I was trying to tell her that her actions did not look good 
  that preceded her.Â  I tried to set her up behind.Â  She became upset and started 
  cursing me.Â  She said basically that it was her life and she could do whatever 
  she wanted to.Â  She came at me with her hand and scratched me in the eye.Â  I 
  got physical in a defensive way.Â  I was trying to get neutral control.Â  I used 
  one of my forearms to hold her down on the bed and across her neck.Â  She was 
  still fussing and cussing.Â  She got up again, and I think thatâ€™s when she scratched 
  me on the neck.Â  I held her down for a couple of moments.Â  I got off of her 
  and told her that I was leaving.Â  I saw that she had a tear running down her 
  cheek.Â  I didnâ€™t hear her crying.Â  I remember seeing Jeromeâ€™s mother.Â  I was 
  not laying on - - I was not laying on Miranda when I saw her.Â  I walked outside 
  and in my car.Â  I left and went to Walkerâ€™s house, but he wasnâ€™t up.Â  So I left 
  and went back to Jerome.Â  Jerome was there, and I talked to him for a couple 
  of minutes.Â  I left and went back to Walkerâ€™s house.Â  I spoke with him about 
  my car and then went home.Â  Later that afternoon I got a phone call from Mr. 
  Wingo.Â  He said M. F. why did you kill my niece, or did you kill my niece.Â  
  I asked what are you talking about.Â  He asked me if I was over there last night, 
  and I told him I was there all night.Â  This statement written by Investigator 
  Yown as I, Jeremy Jerome Knight, directed him what to write.Â  End of Statement. 


Subsequently, Knight gave the following statement:

On 2/25/02 everything that I told the detectives up until 
  the time of the incident is true.Â  As far as the incident goes, I tried to conversate 
  with Miranda Aull about things I felt she was doing that she didnâ€™t need to 
  do. She didnâ€™t want to hear it.Â  When I tried to talk to her, she kept turning 
  her back.Â  As a friend, I tried to get her to listen.Â  She basically told me 
  to stay out of it, that from past conversations about similar matters I felt 
  like I couldnâ€™t let it go, because I didnâ€™t want to see her get treated the 
  way she has been treated in the past.Â  When she wouldnâ€™t listen and turned her 
  back, I tried to turn her around so she couldnâ€™t turn her back again so she 
  could hear what I had to say.Â  I held her shoulders down.Â  She got physical 
  back.Â  Thatâ€™s when the matter got out of hand.Â  At that point I began to choke 
  her with one hand.Â  When she scratched me, she began squeezing my face.Â  I began 
  to use both hands to choke her.Â  I wanted her to hear what I had to say.Â  I 
  felt disappointment, let down.Â  I had put so much into the friendship.Â  I let 
  her go before she stopped breathing.Â  She took a deep breath.Â  She was gasping 
  for air.Â  At that point I was scared.Â  I realized she was not breathing.Â  I 
  then began to pray and use C.P.R.Â  I didnâ€™t know if I was doing it right.Â  I 
  tried.Â  I covered her all the way up except her head.Â  I was very scared.Â  I 
  didnâ€™t know what to do.Â  I kept asking myself over and over again,Â  please, 
  God donâ€™t let this be.Â  I left the house.Â  It wasnâ€™t long at all after she died.Â  
  I drove to Cowpens to see my friend Walker.Â  He wasnâ€™t there.Â  I still felt 
  I need to do something.Â  I didnâ€™t know what I was so - - I didnâ€™t know what 
  I was so scared.Â  When I went back to Jeromeâ€™s house where Mirandaâ€™s body was, 
  I wanted to do something.Â  I wanted to call the police, but I was too scared.Â  
  I talked to Jerome there.Â  I asked him for some water for the car.Â  He let me 
  fill it up, and then I left.Â  Before I left, I did stick my head in the door 
  to see if she was still dead.Â  She was still lying in the same position.Â  I 
  left and went back to Cowpens to Walkerâ€™s house.Â  He wasnâ€™t home.Â  I sat with 
  him and his wife.Â  I wanted to tell them and ask them what to do.Â  I was too 
  scared.Â  I left there.Â  I went home.Â  I got home and laid down to bring myself 
  together so I could do something.Â  I needed to do something.Â  Mirandaâ€™s uncle 
  called and asked me if I, why did I do this to my niece, why did you kill my 
  niece.Â  I told him what are you talking about.Â  I got even more scared.Â  I knew 
  I had to do something.Â  I had to tell somebody.Â  I went to my girlfriendâ€™s house.Â  
  Her name is Tawnya Hamilton in Chesnee.Â  I was going to tell her everything.Â  
  I was also trying to call the detective who left his number for me to call with 
  my mother.Â  He didnâ€™t answer the phone.Â  I didnâ€™t leave a message.Â  I wanted 
  to talk to him.Â  I told my girlfriend some of what happened.Â  My brother came 
  by and I spoke to him.Â  He told me what people are saying, and then the detective 
  showed up.Â  I had never felt like this before.Â  I never felt anger, just disappointment.Â  
  We would talk a certain way about things, and then her actions were different.Â  
  This upset me she was carrying herself like that.Â  I always respected her.Â  
  I always took time out for her if she needed me to show her I cared.Â  We never 
  argued, just small disappointments about view points.Â  I went â€“ I want her family 
  to know I never meant to hurt her.Â  I only wanted her to listen to me.Â  I felt 
  like what I had to say would have helped her to do the right things I know she 
  really wanted to do in life.Â  I swear all this is true.Â  I gave this statement 
  voluntarily.Â  I asked detective Steve Denton to write this for me as I gave 
  it to him.Â  

Both statements were introduced during the trial 
  of the case.Â  Knight did not testify.Â  At the conclusion of the evidence, the 
  defense requested a charge on the lesser-included offenses of voluntary and 
  involuntary manslaughter, [1]  
  arguing the statements provided a basis for allowing the jury to consider them.Â  
  The circuit court declined to charge voluntary manslaughter on the grounds that, 
  neither of Knightâ€™s statements provided a basis for establishing the crime resulted 
  from heat of passion with sufficient legal provocation, both of which are elements 
  of the offense.Â  Knight appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Knight argues his statements lead to an inference 
  Knight killed Aull while the two were fighting, and thus, the circuit court 
  erred by refusing to charge the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œVoluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing 
  of a human being in sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.â€Â  
  State v. Locklair,Â  341 S.C. 352, 359-360, 535 S.E.2d 420, 424 (2000) 
  (quoting State v. Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 65, 508 S.E.2d 29, 31 (1998)).Â  
  Both heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the 
  time of the killing to constitute voluntary manslaughter. State v. Locklair,Â  
  341 S.C. at 359-360, 535 S.E.2d at 424 (quoting State v. Walker, 324 
  S.C. 257, 260, 478 S.E.2d 280, 281 (1996)).Â  Sudden heat of passion upon sufficient 
  legal provocation that mitigates a felonious killing to manslaughter must be 
  such as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of an 
  ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to 
  human experience, may be called â€œan uncontrollable impulse to do violence.â€ 
  State v. Locklair,Â  341 S.C. at 360, 535 S.E.2d at 424 (quoting State 
  v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 104-105, 64 S.E.2d 130, 134 (1951)).Â  
It is proper for a trial judge to refuse to charge 
  voluntary manslaughter in a murder case where it very clearly appears there 
  is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime from murder to manslaughter. 
  State v. Locklair,Â  341 S.C. at 360, 535 S.E.2d at 424 (citing State 
  v. Davis, 278 S.C. 544, 546, 298 S.E.2d 778, 779 (1983)).
Knight argues his statements provide evidence of 
  fighting between himself and the victim, thereby establishing a factual basis 
  for concluding he acted in the sudden heat of passion with sufficient legal 
  provocation.
Considering either version of events as stated 
  by Knight, no facts exist indicating Knight and Aull were fighting.Â  Rather, 
  the evidence indicates Knight attempted to physically and verbally restrain 
  Aull, while she attempted to defend herself.Â  This evidence, without more, is 
  insufficient to establish facts or inferences demonstrating a legal provocation 
  for reducing the crime from murder to voluntary manslaughter.Â  Thus, the circuit 
  court did not err by denying Knightâ€™s motion to charge the jury on the law of 
  voluntary manslaughter.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Knightâ€™s conviction 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   [1]  Knight does not appeal the denial of his request 
    to charge involuntary manslaughter.

THIS
OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. 
IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT
AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Alvin Herbert Shuman,       
Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc. & Haywood B. Hyman, Sr.,       
Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-001
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed January 
  6, 2004
Withdrawn, Substituted and Re-Filed 
  February 19, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
G. Dana Sinkler, of Charleston, and W. Reilly Marchant, 
  of Richmond, for Appellants-Respondents.
Helen Tyler McFadden and W.E. Jenkinson, III, both of Kingstree, 
  for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This cross-appeal involves 
  a contract dispute and a claim for unpaid wages arising out of Alvin Shumanâ€™s 
  (â€œShumanâ€) employment with a car dealership.Â  A jury returned a verdict in favor 
  of Shuman against Charleston Lincoln Mercury (â€œCLMâ€) and Heyward B. Hyman, Sr. 
  [1]  for $175,000 for breach of contract and $65,000 for unpaid wages.Â  
  The trial court reduced the breach of contract verdict by $65,000, doubled the 
  amount of unpaid wages pursuant to the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, 
  and awarded Shuman $75,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  CLM and Shuman appeal.Â  We affirm 
  in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Shuman was employed as general manager of CLM.Â  
  In addition to a set salary, Shuman received incentives or bonuses based on 
  the dealershipâ€™s net profit.Â  In 1998, CLM began attempts to sell the dealership.Â  
  On July 30, 1998, Shuman received an â€œemployment agreementâ€ from CLM which provided 
  that, in exchange for Shuman using his best efforts to aid in the sale of the 
  dealership and continuing to serve as general manager, he would receive a $240,000 
  lump sum severance payment at the time of the closing of the sale of the dealership.Â  
  The agreement stated the purpose of the payment was to secure Shumanâ€™s cooperation 
  in selling the dealership despite the fact that the sale could result in his 
  loss of employment.Â  The agreement was signed by John Conway, CLMâ€™s vice-president.Â  

In January 1999, CLM began negotiations with Sonic 
  Automotive, Inc. for the sale of the CLM dealership.Â  Because of the pending 
  sale of CLM, Shuman sought employment with a car dealership in Pennsylvania.Â  
  On January 9, 1999, Shuman entered into a second â€œemployment agreementâ€ with 
  CLM providing Shuman with a six-month term of employment, renewable unless written 
  notice of termination was given by either party sixty days prior to the expiration 
  of a term.Â  The 1999 agreement referenced the terms of the prior agreements 
  between the parties.Â  The 1999 agreement further provided that Shuman would 
  make himself available on CLMâ€™s premises a minimum of seven days per month and 
  would be available for telephone consultations with the owner and managers of 
  CLM as necessary.Â  Shuman continued working at CLM as well as with the dealership 
  in Pennsylvania.Â  
By letter of July 2, 1999, CLM terminated Shumanâ€™s 
  employment.Â  On August 17, 1999 an agreement to sell the CLM dealership to Sonic 
  was finalized.Â  CLM did not provide Shuman with sixty days written notice of 
  its intent to terminate his employment and did not provide him with a severance 
  payment.Â  
Shuman filed this action against CLM alleging damages 
  for breach of contract and failure to pay wages.Â  In separate verdict forms, 
  the jury returned a verdict in favor of Shuman against CLM in the amount of 
  $175,000 for the breach of contract claim and $65,000 for the failure to pay 
  wages claim.Â  The trial court determined that the $65,000 the jury awarded for 
  unpaid wages was included in the breach of contract award and reduced the verdict 
  by $65,000.Â  The trial court doubled the award for unpaid wages pursuant to 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2002) and awarded $75,000 in attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  CLM argues the trial court erred in submitting 
  Shumanâ€™s $240,000 severance pay claim to the jury because the severance pay 
  agreement was contingent on Shumanâ€™s inability to obtain a comparable position 
  with the buyer of the CLM dealership.Â  Specifically, CLM asserts that because 
  Shuman accepted employment elsewhere prior to the closing of the sale of the 
  CLM dealership he was not entitled to the severance payment.Â  We find no error.
â€œA condition precedent is any fact . . 
  . which, unless excused, must exist or occur before a duty of immediate performance 
  by the promisor can arise.â€Â  Ballenger Corp. v. City of Columbia, 286 
  S.C. 1, 5, 331 S.E.2d 365, 368 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  â€œWhether a stipulation in a 
  contract constitutes a condition precedent is a question of construction dependent 
  on the intent of the parties to be gathered from the language they employ.â€Â  
  Id.Â  In the current appeal, there was conflicting testimony from the 
  parties as to whether Shuman was entitled to a severance payment.Â  The employment 
  agreement regarding the $240,000 severance payment made no reference to the 
  payment being conditioned on Shumanâ€™s failure to obtain employment with the 
  purchaser of the dealership.Â  Accordingly, the evidence created a jury question 
  as to whether Shuman was entitled to severance pay and whether the pay was contingent 
  on his inability to obtain comparable employment with the purchaser of the CLM 
  dealership.Â  See Fleming v. Borden, Inc., 316 S.C. 452, 457, 450 
  S.E.2d 589, 592 (1994) (â€œIn passing on motions for directed verdict, the trial 
  court must view the evidence and all inferences which may reasonably be drawn 
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  If more than 
  one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the case must be submitted 
  to the jury.â€).
2.Â  CLM asserts the trial court erred in allowing 
  Shuman to testify about the meaning of the term â€œnet profitâ€ because such testimony 
  violated the parol evidence rule.Â  We disagree.
Shumanâ€™s original employment agreement 
  with CLM in 1997 provided that he would receive a certain percentage of the 
  dealershipâ€™s net profits.Â  Shuman also alleged that under the terms of the payroll 
  agreement he was entitled to a percentage of the â€œnet profitâ€ on the sale of 
  the CLM dealership to Sonic Automotive, Inc.Â  At trial the court allowed Shuman 
  to testify as to the construction of the term â€œnet profitâ€ in relation to the 
  dealership.
The parol evidence rule generally prohibits 
  the admission of extrinsic evidence to vary or contradict the terms of a contract.Â  
  Penton v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 326 S.C. 275, 486 S.E.2d 742 (1997).Â  
  Parol evidence, however, may be admissible to ascertain the true meaning and 
  intent of the parties when the contract is ambiguous.Â  Id.; see also 
  Klutts Resort Realty, Inc. v. Down â€˜Round Dev. Corp., 268 S.C. 80, 232 
  S.E.2d 20 (1977).Â  â€œAn ambiguous contract is one capable of being understood 
  in more ways than just one or one unclear in meaning because it expresses its 
  purpose in an indefinite manner.â€Â  Penton, 326 S.C. at 280, 486 S.E.2d 
  at 745.Â  â€œThe subject-matter of the contract and the purpose of its execution 
  are material to the ascertainment of the intention of the parties and the meaning 
  of the terms they use, and when these are ascertained they must prevail over 
  the dry words of an agreement.â€Â  Chatfield-Woods Co. v. Harley, 124 S.C. 
  280, 286, 117 S.E. 539, 541 (1923) (citation omitted).Â  
Here, the term â€œnet profitâ€ was ambiguous 
  and the trial court allowed Shuman to explain the term within the context of 
  car dealerships.Â  We find this testimony did not violate the parol evidence 
  rule and did not vary or contradict the terms of the partiesâ€™ written agreements.
3.Â  The jury awarded Shuman $65,000 for his unpaid 
  wages claim.Â  The trial court doubled the award pursuant to the South Carolina 
  Payment of Wages Act.Â  CLM argues the trial court abused its discretion in doubling 
  the award.Â  Conversely, Shuman asserts that he was entitled to treble damages.
Section 41-10-80(C) of the Payment of 
  Wages Act provides that â€œ[i]n case of any failure to pay wages . . . the employee 
  may recover in a civil action an amount equal to three times the full amount 
  of the unpaid wages, plus costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees as the court 
  may allow.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2002).Â  
Our supreme court has held that a trial 
  court has the discretion to decide whether or not to award treble damages:Â  
  â€œIf there is a dispute over unpaid wages the employer acts at his peril and 
  the court in its discretion may award treble damages when the withholding was 
  unreasonable and there was no good faith wage dispute.â€Â  Rice v. Multimedia 
  Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 99, 456 S.E.2d 381, 383 (1995) (citation omitted).Â  Citing 
  Rice, this Court recently reiterated that the statuteâ€™s explicit statement 
  that the employee â€œmayâ€ recover treble damages indicates the matter is committed 
  to the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Intermedical Hosp., 355 S.C. 
  499, 585 S.E.2d 526 (Ct. App. 2003).
We find the statute specifically provides the court 
  with discretion to award an amount equal to three times the amount of 
  the unpaid wages, rather than an amount up to three times the unpaid 
  wages, so the doubling of an unpaid wages award is not an option.Â  Consequently, 
  we reverse the trial courtâ€™s doubling of the unpaid wages award and remand for 
  the court to decide, in its discretion, whether or not to award treble damages 
  on the unpaid wages claim.Â  The court should base its determination on the current 
  record and explain the grounds for its ruling. 
4.Â  CLM argues the trial courtâ€™s award to Shuman 
  of $75,000 for attorneyâ€™s fees was excessive and improper.Â  We find the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees was not excessive under the circumstances of this case.Â  
  See Evans v. Taylor Made Sandwich Co., 337 S.C. 95, 100, 522 S.E.2d 
  350, 352 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œThe amount of unpaid wages may be trebled and costs 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees may be added pursuant to the Act.â€).Â  
5.Â  CLM asserts the trial court lacked jurisdiction 
  to enter an order prohibiting CLM from seeking disbursement of the escrowed 
  accounts.Â  We disagree.
Prior to the sale of the dealership to 
  Sonic, CLM entered into two escrow agreements covering a portion of the proceeds 
  of the sale of assets.Â  One of the escrow agreements is held with the Chicago 
  Title Insurance Company in Illinois and the other agreement is with the First 
  Union National Bank in North Carolina.Â  The North Carolina escrow agreement 
  was entered into to cover claims Shuman and Conway had brought against CLM.Â  
  The Chicago agreement contained funds set aside for contingent environmental 
  liabilities associated with the dealership property and contained the following 
  provisions:Â  (1) the agreement would be governed by the applicable laws of South 
  Carolina, (2) the parties submitted to personal jurisdiction in South Carolina, 
  and (3) the parties â€œwaive[d] any and all rights under the laws of any other 
  state to object to jurisdiction within the State of South Carolina.â€Â  Because 
  of the impending appeal and the concern that funds would not be available to 
  pay the final judgment, the trial court ordered CLM not to distribute the balance 
  of the funds without the courtâ€™s approval, although certain designated expenditures 
  were exempted.Â  
We find the trial courtâ€™s order merely prohibited 
  CLM from making a request to disburse the funds for any purpose other than those 
  specifically authorized by the escrow agreements.Â  Contrary to CLMâ€™s assertion, 
  the trial court did not merge the funds or make any orders directly affecting 
  the balance in the funds.Â  Moreover, as Shuman points out, one of the agreements 
  expressly consented to jurisdiction in South Carolina and the court had jurisdiction 
  over the parties in this action.Â  We therefore find no error in the trial courtâ€™s 
  order regarding the escrow agreements.
6.Â  Shuman argues the trial court erred in failing 
  to provide him with prejudgment interest on the $175,000 judgment because it 
  was a sum certain.Â  We find no error.
â€œThe law allows prejudgment interest on 
  obligations to pay money from the time when, either by agreement of the parties 
  or operation of law, the payment is demandable, if the sum is certain or capable 
  of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Babb v. Rothrock, 310 S.C. 350, 353, 
  426 S.E.2d 789, 791 (1993).Â  Here, the issue of whether Shuman was entitled 
  to any damages was heavily disputed between the parties and was not clear from 
  the partiesâ€™ agreements.Â  CLM disputed the existence of the agreements on which 
  Shuman based his claims for breach of contract and failure to pay wages, alleging 
  Conway lacked the authority to enter into the agreements on its behalf.Â  CLM 
  also disputed the amount of any severance pay due to Shuman and the parties 
  disagreed on whether any net profit was due on the sale of the business as well 
  as its method of calculation.Â  Under the circumstances, the amount of severance 
  and unpaid wages that Shuman may have been entitled to was not readily ascertainable, 
  as was evidenced by the jury award, which was somewhere in between the amounts 
  argued to the jury; therefore, he was not entitled to prejudgment interest.Â Â Â  

7.Â  Shuman asserts the trial court erred in finding 
  the amount the jury awarded him for unpaid wages was included in the amount 
  the jury awarded for his contract claim.Â  We disagree.
In charging the jury, the trial court 
  explained that Shumanâ€™s claims for breach of contract and failure to pay wages 
  overlapped because both included Shumanâ€™s claim of $65,000 in unpaid salary 
  and the possible $325,350 he claimed was owed to him as incentive pay.Â  The 
  trial court further stated to the jury:Â  â€œIf you find that he is entitled to 
  any of that money on both of the claims, he wonâ€™t be paid twice.â€Â  The jury 
  returned two verdict forms.Â  The first form stated:Â  â€œWe find [CLM] knowingly 
  failed to pay [Shuman] wages due him as required by law in the amount of $65,000.00 
  Dollars.â€Â  The second form stated:Â  â€œWe find [CLM] broke the contract of employment 
  and must pay [Shuman] $175,000 Dollars actual damages.â€Â  
We find that, in light of the trial courtâ€™s 
  instructions to the jury and the language of the two verdict forms, the trial 
  court correctly found that the amount the jury awarded Shuman for his wage claim 
  was included in the amount awarded for the breach of contract claim.
CONCLUSION
We affirm all of the trial courtâ€™s rulings 
  with the exception of its doubling of the juryâ€™s award for unpaid wages, which 
  we reverse and remand upon our finding that the Payment of Wages Act only provides 
  a trial court with the discretion to award either treble damages or no additional 
  damages.Â  Upon remand, the trial court shall use the existing record in making 
  its determination and should give the basis for its ruling.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  CLM also includes Haywood B. Hyman, Sr. where appropriate as both 
    are parties to this appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Samuel D. Page,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Willard G. Page, S. M. Page, Betsy Page Gilliam f/k/a Betsy Page
Flinn, 
        Carolyn Page Eaton, and Conway National Bank,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-110
Heard September 9, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard N. Weldon and Janice A. Cannan, both of Conway, 
  for Appellant.
James Thomas Young, of Conway, for Respondent Conway National 
  Bank.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Samuel Page filed a complaint 
  seeking to set aside a property transaction between S. M. Page and Willard Page.Â  
  Samuel argued the transaction was invalid because he was not offered a right 
  of first refusal to the property.Â  The master refused to set aside the transfer.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
M. K. Page and Maude Page conveyed a parcel 
  of real estate to S. M. Page, in fee simple absolute, reserving a life estate 
  unto themselves.Â  In the deed, M. K. and Maude placed a restriction on S. M. 
  Pageâ€™s right to dispose of the property.Â  The restriction created a right of 
  first refusal as follows:Â  
In the event S. M. Page decides to sell all or any portion 
  of this property, it shall first be offered to Betsy Page Flinn, Carolyn Page 
  Eaton, and Samuel D. Page under the same terms and conditions as the proposed 
  sale.Â  This restriction, on transfer, shall also apply to any heirs of S. M. 
  Page.
The reserved life estate expired upon 
  Maudeâ€™s death in 1993 and S. M. Page took possession of the property.Â  In 1995, 
  S. M. Page conveyed the property to Willard Page without first offering the 
  property to any of the persons identified in the deed from M. K. and Maude as 
  having a right of first refusal.Â  There was no mention of the right of first 
  refusal clause in the deed to Willard.Â  A little more than five years after 
  that conveyance, Willard encumbered the property with a $10,000 mortgage in 
  favor of Conway National Bank.Â  
Samuel, one of the individuals to whom 
  the right of first refusal was granted, sued Willard, S. M. Page, and Conway 
  National Bank seeking to set aside the conveyance, alleging he was not offered 
  the opportunity to purchase the property before it was conveyed to Willard.Â  
  The matter was referred to the master in equity with finality.Â  The master declined 
  to set aside the transaction, reasoning that the right of first refusal language 
  contained in the deed from M. K. and Maude to S. M. Page was invalid because 
  it was an attempt to cut down a fee simple with subsequent language in the deed.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Samuel argues the master erred when he refused 
  to set aside the conveyance from S. M. Page to Willard.Â  He asserts the right 
  of first refusal language contained in the deed was a preemptive right that 
  did not cut short a fee simple absolute estate.Â  Additionally, he contends the 
  master failed to consider the deed as a whole.Â  We disagree.

One of the first canons of construction of a deed is that 
  the intention of the grantor must be ascertained and effectuated if no settled 
  rule of law is contravened.Â  In arriving at such intention, the deed must be 
  construed as a whole, and effect given to every part, if such can be done consistently 
  with law.Â  

Southern Ry. Co. v. Smoak, 243 S.C. 331, 
  336, 133 S.E.2d 806, 808 (1963).Â  However, when a granting clause in a deed 
  purports to convey a fee simple absolute title, any subsequent provisions in 
  the deed diminishing or depriving the grantee of rights incident to owning the 
  property in fee simple are invalid.Â  Shealy v. South Carolina Elec. & 
  Gas Co., 278 S.C. 132, 135, 293 S.E.2d 306, 308 (1982).Â  Thus we must decide 
  whether the right of first refusal in the deed S. M. Page received diminished 
  any of the rights attendant to the fee simple title conveyed in the deedâ€™s granting 
  clause.Â  
A right of first refusal is a pre-emptive right.Â  
  Webb v. Reames, 326 S.C. 444, 446, 485 S.E.2d 384, 385 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
  The right of first refusal is a contingent nonvested interest because the grantee 
  or the granteeâ€™s heir might never choose to sell the property.Â  Id.Â  
  It is an interest predicated on an event which is not certain to occur.Â  Id.Â  
  Pre-emptive rights are subject to the rule against restraint of alienation of 
  interest in land.Â  61 Am. Jur. 2d Perpetuities and Restraints on Alienation 
  Â§ 110 (2002).Â  Under some circumstances, a right of first refusal may not be 
  an unreasonable restriction on alienation.Â  â€œA right of first refusal . . . 
  is not a restraint on alienation, as long as both the price that the designated 
  person must pay, and the time allowed for the exercise of the right of first 
  refusal are reasonable.â€Â  Id.Â  
â€œWhether a right of first refusal is valid depends 
  on the legitimacy of the purpose, the price at which the holder may purchase 
  the land, and the procedures for exercising the right.â€Â  Restatement (Third) 
  of Prop.:Â  Servitude Â§ 3.4 cmt. (f) (2000).Â  According to the testimony, the 
  purpose of the restriction in this case was primarily to retain the property 
  in the family, which is a legitimate purpose.Â  Also, the language contained 
  in the operative deed fixed the price that must be paid by requiring that it 
  be the same as contained in the offer from a potential third party purchaser.Â  
  However, the procedures for exercising the right of first refusal are not specifically 
  spelled out in the grant itself, leaving unanswered the question as to how long 
  the right to exercise the right of first refusal must remain open and how long 
  thereafter the holder of the right had to consummate the transaction.Â  

Lengthy periods for exercise of rights of first refusal will 
  . . . substantially affect alienability of the property.Â  Potential buyers will 
  be deterred by the possibility that they may not know for a lengthy period of 
  time whether they will obtain the property or be obligated to pay the price.Â  
  The risks of change in their needs and in financial markets will be greater 
  than most buyers will be willing to accept.

Id.Â  We are therefore constrained to conclude 
  that the lack of specificity in the language of the right of first refusal creates 
  an unreasonable restraint on the alienability of the property.Â  
We adopt a rule of strict construction in this 
  case for two basic reasons.Â  The first is that South Carolina has a long line 
  of cases strongly expressing disfavor for subsequent clauses in deeds that purport 
  to cut down a fee simple estate contained in the granting clause.Â  See 
  Sandford v. Sandford, 106 S.C. 304, 306, 91 S.E. 294, 295 (1917) (â€œIt 
  is . . . clear (and no citation of authorities is necessary) that an attempt 
  to convey an estate in fee simple and deprive the purchaser of the incident 
  of ownership is not effective in law.â€); see also Douglas v. Medical 
  Investors, Inc., 256 S.C. 440, 445, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1971) (noting â€œthe 
  well established principle that when the granting clause in a deed conveys a 
  fee simple title it cannot be reduced or cut down by subsequent language in 
  the instrumentâ€); Stylecraft, Inc. v. Thomas, 250 S.C. 495, 498, 159 
  S.E.2d 46, 47 (1968) (same); Batesburg-Leesville School Dist. No. 3 v. Tarrant, 
  293 S.C. 442, 444, 361 S.E.2d 343, 345 (Ct. App. 1987) (same).Â  The second is 
  that any restraint on alienation in the form of a right of first refusal that 
  is not specific in all required elements â€“ legitimacy of purpose, price, and 
  detailed procedures â€“ runs counter to the commonly acknowledged concept in this 
  state that one of the attributes of fee simple ownership is the ability to freely 
  convey it with few if any restrictions.Â  Having held that the right of first 
  refusal in this case constitutes an unreasonable limitation upon the power of 
  alienation, it is therefore violative of the public policy of this state and 
  has no force and effect.Â  McCravey v. Otts, 90 S.C. 447, 452, 74 S.E. 
  142, 143 (1912); Wise v. Poston, 281 S.C. 574, 579, 316 S.E.2d 412, 415 
  (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
AFFIRMED. 
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
