THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James Calvin Phillips, Sr., Rudelle C. Phillips, and James Calvin Phillips, 
        Jr.,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Donna V. Phillips Cassidy, and Richard Allen Phillips,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield County
Stephen C. Wallace, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-111
Submitted November 3, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mahlon E. Padgett, IV, of Bennettsville; for Appellants.
William O. Spencer, Jr., of Chesterfield; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Calvin Phillips, Sr. 
  (Father), Rudelle C. Phillips (Mother), James Calvin Phillips, Jr. (James), 
  Donna V. Phillips Cassidy (Donna) and Richard Allen Phillips (Richard) owned 
  an undivided interest in a tract of land.Â  Father, Mother, and James (collectively, 
  â€œRespondentsâ€) filed a complaint against Richard and Donna (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€) 
  seeking the partition in-kind of the tract.Â  A special referee filed both a 
  Report and Decree of Partition of Real Estate and a supplemental order.Â  Appellants 
  now appeal, arguing the supplemental order was contrary to an agreement reached 
  by the parties.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Appellants and Respondents owned, 
  as tenants in common, a 645-acre tract of land in Chesterfield County.Â Â  Respondents, 
  seeking a partition in-kind of the land, filed both a complaint and lis 
  pendens in the circuit court.Â Â  By consent of the parties, the action 
  was referred to a special referee. 
The special referee conducted two hearings.Â  
  At the first hearing, the parties stipulated that Father and Mother were entitled 
  to a combined sixty percent interest in the tract and each of the children was 
  entitled to a ten percent interest.Â Â  Father and James testified at the hearing 
  that they were seeking a partition to allow James fifty acres in the northern 
  corner of the property on which to build a poultry farm.Â  
At the second hearing, the parties informed 
  the special referee of their agreement that James receive the fifty acres for 
  the poultry farm in the northern corner of the property.Â Â  Counsel for Appellants 
  informed the referee that as part of that agreement, Appellants would receive 
  their joint portion of the land along the highway.Â Â  Counsel for Respondents 
  agreed that Appellants could get their portion in the southwestern corner of 
  the tract, but he informed the special referee that the court would have to 
  decide the dimensions of their portion, including how much road frontage the 
  parties would receive. 
Father testified several times that the special referee 
  would have to determine the dimensions of Appellantsâ€™ joint tract.Â  Appellants 
  presented a proposed division that included mostly road frontage.Â Â  They testified 
  they wanted Father to have the rental properties in the southwestern corner 
  and to be compensated with other land.Â Â  Donna testified the special referee 
  could determine the percentage of road frontage property she and Richard should 
  receive.Â Â Â  Richard also informed the referee that he â€œhad no strong feelingsâ€ 
  about the road frontage property, but he did not want the rental property.Â Â Â  
  At the end of the hearing, counsel for Respondents excepted to Appellants receiving 
  the majority of the road frontage property and requested that the referee give 
  them a proportionate share of land fronting the highway.Â Â Â  
The special referee subsequently entered a Report 
  and Decree of Partition of Real Estate.Â  In the order, the special referee outlined 
  the partiesâ€™ agreements that Appellants would receive their undivided interest 
  in the southwestern corner of the property, James would have the fifty acres 
  for his poultry farm, and Father would receive any rental property and one acre 
  surrounding it that may lie within Appellantsâ€™ portion.Â Â  The special referee 
  found Appellants should be allotted a 129-acre portion of land (twenty percent 
  of the overall tract) in the southwest corner of the property in order to satisfy 
  their interests.Â Â  The referee explained the method to be employed in determining 
  the dimensions of this tract and stated he would retain jurisdiction to â€œcoordinate 
  and effectuate the laying out of the portion allotted to [Appellants] and to 
  enter such further order as will facilitate the conclusion of this matter.â€ 
  [1] Â Â  
Several months after the Report and Decree of Partition 
  was entered, the special referee filed a supplemental order approving a surveyorâ€™s 
  plat of the 129-acre tract allotted to Appellants.Â Â  The referee stated that, 
  as a result of the allotment, Appellants received â€œownership of a pro 
  rata share of the whole acreage relative to both land and type, (e.g. 
  road frontage, planted pines, pasture, bottom land, and river frontage).â€Â Â  
  Appellants subsequently filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration, 
  arguing the division of land approved by the special referee was contrary to 
  the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â Â  The referee denied the motion, stating there was no 
  evidence of such an agreement in the record. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA partition action is an equitable action, 
  heard by a judge alone and, as such, this Court on review may find facts in 
  accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Anderson 
  v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 113, 382 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1989).Â  This scope 
  of review does not require this Court to ignore the special refereeâ€™s findings 
  when he was in a â€œbetter position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  
  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the special referee 
  erred in issuing a supplemental order contrary to his prior order and contrary 
  to the recognized agreement of the parties.
Initially, we note there is no evidence 
  in the record of any kind of an agreement reached between the parties concerning 
  the specific allocation of property to Appellants within the tract.Â  While Appellants 
  and Respondents appear to have reached a consensus that Appellants were to receive 
  a 129-acre tract in the southwestern corner of the overall tract and that this 
  tract should have a proportional amount of road frontage, there is neither testimony 
  nor a written document memorializing a formal agreement that Appellants would 
  only receive road frontage or that they would not receive river frontage.Â  Agreements 
  between counsel are not binding unless they are reduced to written form or â€œmade 
  in open court and noted upon the record.â€Â  Rule 43(k), SCRCP; see Young 
  v. Cooler, 347 S.C. 362, 365, 555 S.E.2d 410, 412 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding 
  it was error for the trial court to enforce an â€œagreementâ€ where there was no 
  evidence of a consent order, written stipulation, or agreement made in open 
  court and noted on the record).Â  Because there is no evidence of an agreement, 
  the special refereeâ€™s supplemental order was not issued in violation of any 
  agreement.
Further, there is nothing in the record indicating 
  the special refereeâ€™s supplemental order violated the terms in the initial order.Â  
  The initial order noted the parties agreed Appellants would receive 129 acres 
  in the southwestern portion of the overall tract.Â  The parties agreed the special 
  referee would retain jurisdiction to lay out Appellantsâ€™ portion after consulting 
  with a surveyor.Â  In the supplemental order, the special referee specifically 
  outlined Appellantsâ€™ portion pursuant to the surveyorâ€™s plat. Accordingly, nothing 
  in the record indicates the special refereeâ€™s supplemental order violated the 
  terms of the original order. 
Finally, the partiesâ€™ testimony does not indicate 
  the special referee erred in partitioning the property.Â  Respondents specifically 
  stated they wanted the referee to establish the dimensions of Appellantsâ€™ tract 
  in the southwestern corner of the property.Â Â  Although Richard indicated he 
  had no interest in farming the river-front property, Appellants testified they 
  wanted the special referee to determine the location of their share of the property, 
  to consider the inclusion of several rental properties on the tract, and to 
  apportion road frontage proportional to their percentage ownership of the overall 
  tract of land.Â Â Â  Respondents agreed the special referee should make a determination 
  regarding a proportional amount of road frontage.Â  
The special referee fairly apportioned Appellantsâ€™ 
  land consistent with the intent of both parties.Â  We note that, in dividing 
  the tract, the special referee took great pains to award Appellants a fair and 
  pro rata share of all of the different types of land in the tract 
  â€“ including road frontage, planted pines, pasture, bottom land, and river frontage. 
  Â Â Further, the evidence in the record indicates the partiesâ€™ only agreement 
  was for the special referee to make the specific determination on the location 
  of Appellantsâ€™ portion.Â  Accordingly, the special refereeâ€™s supplemental order 
  did not conflict with the original order.Â  Based on the preponderance of the 
  evidence before this Court, we find the special referee did not err in apportioning 
  the tract or issuing his supplemental order.Â  Anderson, 299 S.C. at 113, 
  382 S.E.2d at 899.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the special refereeâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  In the Report and Decree of Partition, the special referee also noted 
    the partiesâ€™ stipulated value of the entire tract and levied costs to be paid 
    by the parties.Â  Â These conclusions were not appealed by either party.Â

The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John H. Locklear,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-112
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 24, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  John H. Locklear 
  was convicted of first-degree burglary and assault and battery with intent to 
  kill.Â  The circuit court sentenced him to thirty-years imprisonment for first-degree 
  burglary and twenty-years imprisonment for assault and battery with intent to 
  kill, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 
  386 U.S. 738 (1967), Locklearâ€™s counsel attached a petition to be relieved.Â  
  Locklear filed a pro se response.
After review of the record pursuant to Anders 
  v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 
  116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss Locklearâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s 
  petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED. 
  [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE,
JJ., concurring.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-113
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charles W. Bailey       
Appellant.
      
    
  

 

Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-114
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 24, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, and REMANDEDÂ  


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Legal Counsel 
  Tommy Evans, Jr. and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Charles W. Bailey 
  was indicted for unlawful possession of prescription drugs and resisting arrest 
  and sentenced to an indeterminate sentence pursuant to Section 5(c) of the Youthful 
  Offender Act, suspended upon four-years probation and payment of restitution 
  in the amount of sixty dollars.Â  Subsequently, an arrest warrant was issued 
  against Bailey for violation of his probation.Â  Thereafter, the circuit court 
  revoked Baileyâ€™s probation, modified the sentence from Youthful Offender to 
  an adult sentence of two-years imprisonment, and revoked the sentence in full.Â  
  Bailey appeals, arguing the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to revoke his probation as to his conviction for resisting arrest.Â  We affirm 
  in part, vacate in part, and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Bailey was sentenced to an indeterminate sentence 
  under Section 5(c) of the Youthful Offender Act, suspended upon four-years probation 
  and payment of restitution in the amount of sixty dollars.Â  The sentence was 
  given in disposition of two indictments, 96-GS-46-2868, charging Unlawful Possession 
  of Prescription Drugs, and 96-GS-46-2869, charging Resisting Arrest.
Subsequently, an arrest warrant was issued 
  against Bailey for violating his probation by: 1) failing to follow the advice 
  of a probation agent; 2) failing to gain approval of an agent before moving 
  out of state; 3) failing to maintain monetary obligations; and 4) failing to 
  contact a South Carolina agent for transfer to New Hampshire, therebyÂ  absconding 
  from the jurisdiction.Â  The warrant referred solely to indictment 96-GS-46-2868.Â  
  At the conclusion of the probation revocation hearing, the circuit court revoked 
  Baileyâ€™s probation, modified the sentence from Youthful Offender to an adult 
  sentence of two-years imprisonment, and revoked the sentence in full.Â  The written 
  order revoking probation referred to the charges contained in both indictments.Â  
  Bailey appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bailey argues the circuit court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to revoke his probation on indictment 96-46-GS-2869 
  because the arrest warrant only referred to indictment 96-GS-46-2868.Â  We agree 
  and vacate the portion of the order referring to indictment 96-46-GS-2869.Â  

â€œSubject matter jurisdiction to revoke an individualâ€™s 
  probation is conferred on the General Sessions Court by either the issuance 
  of a probation violation warrant or the issuance of a probation violation citation 
  and affidavit in lieu of a warrant.â€Â  State v. Lee, 350 S.C. 125, 132, 
  564 S.E.2d 372, 376 (Ct. App. 2002); see State v. Felder, 313 
  S.C. 55, 56, 437 S.E.2d 42, 43 (1993) (â€œSouth Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-450 
  (1989), [1]  requires the issuance of a probation revocation 
  warrant before probation may be revoked.Â  If a warrant has not been issued, 
  the trial court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to revoke probation and any 
  attempted revocation is a nullity.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-300 (1989), 
  however, permits the use of a citation and affidavit in lieu of a warrant.â€ 
  (internal citations omitted)).
No evidence exists within the record indicating 
  an arrest warrant was issued charging Bailey with a violation of his probationary 
  sentence under indictment 96-46-GS-2869.Â  Furthermore, the State concedes no 
  arrest warrant was issued on that indictment.Â  
Thus, the circuit court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction to revoke Baileyâ€™s probation as to indictment 96-46-GS-2869.Â  
  See Lee, 350 S.C. at 132, 564 S.E.2d at 376.Â  Accordingly, the 
  modification and revocation of Baileyâ€™s sentence given in connection with indictment 
  96-GS-46-2869 by Order of Judge John C. Hayes on November 4, 2002, is hereby 
  vacated.Â  
Based on the arrest warrant issued, the 
  circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to revoke Baileyâ€™s probation and 
  to modify his sentence as it related to indictment 96-GS-46-2868.Â  However, 
  instead of modifying Baileyâ€™s sentence as it related to this one charge, the 
  circuit court modified the single sentence given for both indictments at trial.Â  
  Thus, we remand for a determination of Baileyâ€™s modified sentence relating only 
  to indictment 96-GS-46-2868.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the circuit 
  court, revoking Baileyâ€™s probation is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, and REMANDED.Â  
GOOLSBY, HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concurring.

 
   
    [1]  Although section 24-21-450 was amended in 1991, the amendment does 
    not affect our analysis of the issue of subject matter jurisdiction.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donnie L. Williams, Jr.,       
Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Pioneer Machinery, Inc. and Blount, Inc.,       
Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-119
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  25, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Joel H. Smith, James T. Irvin, III, and Courtney Cooke Shytle, 
  all of Columbia, for Appellants/Respondents.
Frank Anthony Barton, of W. Columbia; and J. Marvin Mullis, 
  Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Donnie L. Williams, 
  Jr., sued Pioneer Machinery, Inc., (â€œPioneerâ€), and Blount, Inc., (â€œBlountâ€), 
  alleging causes of action for strict tort liability, negligence, and breach 
  of express and implied warranties.Â  Before trial, Pioneer moved for a transfer 
  of venue from Florence County to Lexington County.Â  The circuit court granted 
  the motion.Â  Subsequently, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Pioneer and 
  Blount.Â  Thereafter, Williams moved for a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine and Rule 60, South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  The circuit 
  court granted Williamsâ€™ motion.Â  All of the parties appealed.Â  Williams appeals, 
  arguing the circuit court improperly granted Pioneerâ€™s motion for change of 
  venue.Â  Pioneer and Blount appeal, arguing the circuit court improperly granted 
  Williamsâ€™ motion for a new trial absolute.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Williams worked for a logging company trimming 
  felled trees to be loaded onto logging trucks.Â  Williams was working in the 
  proximity of a Prentice 410D Loader, a piece of heavy logging equipment having 
  a boom with a grapple on the end used to pick up, move, and drop felled trees.Â  
  Williams was injured when his co-worker was moving a tree that fell from the 
  grapple onto Williams.Â  
Williams sued Pioneer, the seller of the loader 
  truck, and Blount, the manufacturer of the loader truck (collectively â€œthe Defendantsâ€), 
  in Florence County, alleging causes of action for strict tort liability, negligence, 
  and breach of express and implied warranties.Â  Williams maintained the 410D 
  Loader was defective because the boom obstructed the view of the operator, thereby 
  creating a blind spot.Â  
Before trial, the Defendants moved to transfer 
  venue from Florence County to Lexington County, arguing the convenience of the 
  witnesses and the interests of justice required the transfer.Â  The circuit court 
  granted the change of venue, and the case was tried in Lexington County.Â  
Williams introduced the testimony of an expert 
  witness who testified that visibility from the driverâ€™s seat of the loader truck 
  was limited.Â  However, the expert and the attorneys realized during a recess 
  that a different loader, a 410E model, had been produced by the Defendants for 
  inspection prior to trial, and the expert witness had based his opinion on a 
  410E loader truck having a different sized boom.Â  
When Williamsâ€™ counsel brought the pre-trial discovery 
  mistake to the attention of the circuit court, the court stated it would allow 
  the expert to be recalled during rebuttal after inspecting the correct loader.Â  
  No motion for mistrial was made or considered by the court.Â  
Thereafter, the correct loader model was displayed 
  for the jury to examine and to sit in the operatorâ€™s seat.Â  The trial judge 
  did not sit in the loader truck.Â  
In rebuttal, Williamsâ€™ expert noted the 
  smaller size of the 410D boom but explained that it made no difference in his 
  opinion regarding the restriction on operator visibility or the manufacturerâ€™s 
  ability to reduce the risk of harm by installing a mirror.Â  Â  
At the close of the trial, Williams withdrew his 
  causes of action for breach of warranties.Â  Furthermore, on motion for directed 
  verdict by the Defendants, the circuit court granted a directed verdict as to 
  Pioneer on the negligence cause of action.
Thereafter, the jury returned a verdict in favor 
  of the Defendants.Â  Williams moved the circuit court for a new trial absolute, 
  arguing the result of the trial was unjust and based upon mistake because of 
  the confusion caused by the initial testimony regarding the 410E loader.Â  The 
  circuit court granted Williamsâ€™ motion for a new trial based on both the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine and Rule 60(b), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Both 
  Williams and the Defendants appeal.Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Williamsâ€™ Appeal
Williams argues the circuit court erred by granting 
  Pioneerâ€™s motion for change of venue.Â  We disagree.
The circuit court retains the sound discretion 
  to change the venue of a trial if to do so both furthers the convenience of 
  witnesses and the ends of justice.Â  McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 
  325 S.C. 327, 335, 479 S.E.2d 67, 71 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  A circuit courtâ€™s decision 
  to change venue based on these two factors will not be disturbed absent a showing 
  of â€œmanifest abuse of discretion resulting in an error of law.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œMoreover, the error of law must be so opposed to the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion 
  as to amount to a deprivation of the legal rights of the party.â€ Id. 
 

Where a party moves for a change of venue based 
  on convenience and the ends of justice, the circuit court is charged with resolving 
  questions of fact to determine whether a change satisfies both requirements.Â  
  A great deal of discretion is left to the circuit court to determine whether 
  the witnessesâ€™ convenience would be promoted by the change.Â  The question to 
  be resolved is whether convenience and justice would be promoted, not to what 
  degree.Â  Id.
â€œThe movant has the burden of making a 
  prima facie showing that both the convenience of the witnesses and the ends 
  of justice would be promoted by the change.â€Â  Id. (quoting Brice v. 
  State Co., 193 S.C. 137, 139-40, 7 S.E.2d 850, 851 (1940)).Â Â  â€œAlthough 
  both requirements must be met, a showing of the convenience of the witnesses 
  can, depending on the facts of the case, bear on the issue of promotion of justice.â€Â  
  McKissick, 325 S.C. at 335, 479 S.E.2d at 71.
While a precise definition of the â€œends of justiceâ€ 
  is hard to elucidate, we acknowledge that justice is promoted by having the 
  â€œcredibility of witnesses judged by jurors of the vicinage, the county in which 
  the witnesses reside.â€ Id. at 335-36, 479 S.E.2d at 71.Â  
The record indicates the loader was bought from 
  Pioneer in Lexington County, the incident occurred in Lexington County, and 
  Williams, the plaintiff, is a resident of Lexington County.Â  
Furthermore, in support of its motion to change 
  venue, Pioneer submitted the affidavits of four potential witnesses.Â  The first 
  affiant, Joseph Garner Scott, the owner of Pioneer, testified he was a resident 
  of Lexington County, and as such, Lexington County was a more convenient forum 
  for him.Â  Additionally, he testified he was the trial representative for Pioneer 
  and was required to be present throughout the trial.Â  He averred that if anyone 
  would be testifying on behalf of Pioneer about the sale of the loader and the 
  subsequent maintenance and repair of the loader, it would be him.Â  Moreover, 
  he averred Pioneerâ€™s principal place of business was in Lexington County, and 
  if any of his employees were called to testify, the majority of them lived in 
  Lexington County.Â  
The second affiant, Tracey Gunter, averred he is 
  the owner of the logging company Williams works for, and as such, he owns the 
  loader truck that injured Williams.Â  He lives and works in Lexington County.Â  
  Additionally, he stated that the majority of his employees work in Lexington 
  County and it would be more convenient for him if the trial were held there.Â  

The third affiant, Edwin Oâ€™Neil Padgett, averred 
  he is a resident of Lexington County, he witnessed the accident, and it would 
  be more convenient for him if the trial were held in Lexington County.Â  
The fourth affiant, Dale Gleaton, averred he was 
  the operator of the loader at the time Williams was injured, and it would be 
  more convenient for him if the trial were in Lexington County. 
  [1] Â  
Reviewing the affidavits and testimony within the 
  record, sufficient evidence exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that 
  both the convenience of the witnesses and the ends of justice would be promoted 
  by changing venue from Florence County to Lexington County.Â  Thus, we hold the 
  circuit court did not abuse its discretion.Â  See McKissick, 325 
  S.C. at 327, 479 S.E.2d at 71 (holding a circuit courtâ€™s decision to change 
  venue will not be disturbed absent a showing of manifest abuse of discretion 
  amounting to a deprivation of the legal rights of a party). 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  The Defendantsâ€™ Appeal
The Defendants argue the circuit court erred by 
  granting Williamsâ€™ motion for a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine.Â  We disagree. [2] 
The thirteenth juror doctrine permits the circuit 
  court to grant a new trial absolute when it finds the evidence does not justify 
  the verdict.Â  South Carolina Highway Depâ€™t v. Townsend, 265 S.C. 253, 
  258, 217 S.E.2d 778, 781 (1975).Â  The effect is the same as if the jury failed 
  to reach a verdict, and thus, the circuit court is not required to give any 
  reason for granting the new trial. Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254, 
  387 S.E.2d 265, 266 (1990).Â  Rather, assuming evidence exists to support the 
  circuit courtâ€™s order, the circuit court â€œjudge . . . [, sitting as] the thirteenth 
  juror, possess[es] the veto power to the Nth degree . . .â€Â  Worrell v. South 
  Carolina Power Co., 186 S.C. 306, 313-14, 195 S.E. 638, 641 (1938).Â Â  Therefore, 
  a circuit courtâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the facts will 
  not be disturbed unless its decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence or 
  the conclusion reached was controlled by an error of law.Â  South Carolina 
  State Highway Depâ€™t v. Clarkson, 267 S.C. 121, 126, 226 S.E.2d 696, 697 
  (1976).Â  
The Defendants contend the circuit court erred 
  by granting a new trial absolute because the blind spot caused by the loaderâ€™s 
  boom is an open and obvious danger under any view of the evidence.Â  Therefore, 
  they contend the circuit court was barred, as a matter of law, from sitting 
  as a thirteenth juror.
As we view the Defendantsâ€™ argument, it is based 
  upon an erroneous understanding of the law.Â  In order to recover under a strict 
  liability theory, the plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) the defendantâ€™s product 
  was in a defective condition unreasonably dangerous for its intended use; (2) 
  the defect existed when the product left the defendantâ€™s control; and (3) the 
  defect was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.Â  Bragg v. Hi-Ranger, 
  Inc., 319 S.C. 531, 539, 462 S.E.2d 321, 326 (Ct. App. 1995).
Although it is true a product cannot be deemed 
  unreasonably dangerous for failure to warn of a danger that is open and 
  obvious, [3]  a balancing 
  test is generally employed to determine if a product is designed in an 
  unreasonably dangerous manner.Â  In that vein, the following factors are considered 
  to determine if a design defect exists:Â  1) the usefulness and desirability 
  of the product; 2) the cost involved for added safety; 3) the likelihood and 
  potential seriousness of the injury; and 4) the obviousness of the danger.Â  
  Claytor v. General Motors Corp., 227 S.C. 259, 265, 286 S.E.2d 129, 132 
  (1982).Â  Therefore, in South Carolina we balance the utility of the risk inherent 
  in the design of the product with the magnitude of the risk to determine the 
  reasonableness of the manufacturerâ€™s action in designing the product.Â  Id.Â Â  

Williamsâ€™ complaint alleges the loader was unreasonably 
  dangerous because:Â  1) it was designed in an unreasonably dangerous manner; 
  and 2) the manufacturer failed to give adequate warnings.Â  Both the operator 
  of the loader and Williams testified they knew the loader had a blind spot at 
  the four oâ€™clock position.Â  Thus, at most, the Defendants have demonstrated 
  a lack of evidence to support allegations of a failure to warn.Â  However, 
  Williamsâ€™ theory of the case encompassed more than just defective warnings, 
  as it also alleged the loader was designed in an unreasonably dangerous 
  manner.Â  
Furthermore, nothing in the circuit courtâ€™s order suggests 
  it granted the new trial solely on the theory of a failure to warn.Â  
  Rather, the circuit court did not specify any one basis for its grant of a new 
  trial.Â  Consequently, the open and obvious nature of the blind spot was, as 
  to the claim for defective design, merely one of the factors to be weighed by 
  the factfinder.Â  Therefore, this argument is without merit.
Next, the Defendants argue the circuit 
  court erred as a matter of law by granting the new trial absolute based on the 
  thirteenth juror doctrine because the judge did not actually sit in the loader.Â  
  Thus, the Defendants contend that where, as here, the judge has not viewed or 
  experienced some piece of evidence, the judge is precluded from sitting as a 
  thirteenth juror.Â  The Defendants predicate their argument on Townsend, 
  265 S.C. at 253, 217 S.E.2d at 778.
 In Townsend, the South Carolina Highway 
  Department (â€œSCHDâ€) instituted a condemnation proceeding against the defendant.Â  
  As part of the evidence at trial, the jury was permitted to view the property 
  the SCHD sought to condemn.Â  The circuit court judge did not view the property.Â  

Thereafter, following the juryâ€™s verdict in favor 
  of the defendant, SCHD moved for a new trial absolute or, in the alternative, 
  a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  The circuit court judge denied the motion for 
  a new trial absolute, stating that although he believed the jury award was excessive, 
  he was without legal authority to reduce the judgment because the jury viewed 
  the premises and he had not.
On appeal, our supreme court reversed and remanded, 
  holding the circuit court judge should view the property and then determine 
  whether the motion for new trial nisi remittitur should be granted.
 Townsend merely stands for the well-established 
  proposition the circuit court commits an error of law where it fails to exercise 
  its discretion.Â  Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 
  566 (1987) (â€œWhen the trial judge is vested with discretion, but his ruling 
  reveals no discretion was, in fact, exercised, an error of law has occurred.â€); 
  State v. Smith, 276 S.C. 494, 498, 280 S.E.2d 200, 202 (1981) (â€œIt is 
  apparent here the sentencing judge did not exercise any discretion but based 
  his ruling on an erroneous view of the law. It is an equal abuse of discretion 
  to refuse to exercise discretionary authority when it is warranted as it is 
  to exercise the discretion improperly.â€).Â  In the case at bar, the circuit court 
  judge granted a new trial absolute, ruling justice was not done.Â  Thus, the 
  circuit court exercised its discretion.Â  Consequently, we conclude Townsend 
  is not controlling here.
Furthermore, conflicting evidence exists within 
  the record to support the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  Therefore, we hold the 
  circuit court did not err by granting a new trial based on the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decisions of the 
  circuit court are
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   [1] Following Gleatonâ€™s 
    original affidavit, Gleaton stated in a subsequent affidavit that he would 
    not be unduly burdened or inconvenienced by traveling to Florence and he did 
    not want the trial moved â€œon . . . [his] account.â€Â  

 
   
    [2]  Because we hold the circuit court did not err by granting Williamsâ€™ 
    motion for a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror doctrine, we 
    decline to address whether the circuit court properly granted Williamâ€™s motion 
    for a new trial absolute based on Rule 60, South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.

 
   
    [3] See Dema v. Shore Enterprises, Ltd., 312 S.C. 
    528, 530, 435 S.E.2d 875, 876 (Ct. App. 1993); Anderson v. Green Bull, 
    Inc., 322 S.C. 268, 271, 471 S.E.2d 708, 710 (Ct. App. 1996).

PER CURIAM:Â  Clifton Ronald David was convicted

  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR, and affirm pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, because the point raised by David is manifestly without 
  merit.Â  See State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 
  252 (2001) (stating the trial court must consider the totality of the circumstances, 
  including the background, experience, and conduct of the accused when determining

  at 252 (noting the trial courtâ€™s conclusions regarding the voluntariness of 
  a statement will not be disturbed on appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as 
  to show an abuse of discretion); id. (â€œWhen reviewing a trial court's 
  ruling concerning voluntariness, this Court does not reevaluate the facts based

  whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€); State v. 
  Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 594, 521 S.E.2d 500, 505 (1999) (stating that absent 
  coercive police conduct, there is no basis for finding a confession constitutionally 
  involuntary); State v. Crawley, 349 S.C. 459, 465, 562 S.E.2d 683, 686 
  (Ct. App. 2002) (finding officerâ€™s testimony regarding the defendantâ€™s appearance 
  and actions during interrogation supported trial courtâ€™s conclusion that the 
  defendantâ€™s statements were voluntary despite any withdrawal from alcohol and 
  drugs); State v. Kennedy, 325 S.C. 295, 305, 479 S.E.2d 838, 843 (Ct. 
  App. 1996), (stating the trial court must assess the totality of the surrounding 
  circumstances, including the characteristics of the defendant and the details 
  of the interrogation when determining whether the defendantâ€™s will was overborne), 
  affâ€™d as modified, 333 S.C. 426, 510 S.E.2d 714 (1998).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

James F. Bethea, MD, M. David Mitchell, MD, James J. McCoy, Jr., MD,

Of Whom The South Carolina Workers' Compensation Commission is the

J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-127
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Paul Clarendon Ballou, of Columbia, for Appellants.
William H. Davidson, II and Andrew F. Lindemann, bothof Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: A group of orthopaedic surgeons 
  and neurologists (â€œAppellantsâ€) brought an action against the South Carolina 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (â€œRespondentâ€) and numerous private insurance 
  companies alleging they were adversely affected by Respondentâ€™s failure to periodically 
  review and amend their medical fee schedule to keep pace with the economy.Â  
  The trial court dismissed Appellantsâ€™ causes of action.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Appellants are orthopaedic surgeons and neurologists 
  licensed to practice medicine in South Carolina.Â  They voluntarily treat injured 
  South Carolina employees covered by workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  Respondent 
  oversees and administers the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-1-10, et seq. (1985 & Supp. 2003).Â  
In July 1989, Respondent adopted Regulation 67-1304 
  governing the calculation of physician fees. 
  [1] Â  Under Regulation 67-1304, physician fees were determined by first 
  assigning a specific unit value, and then multiplying the unit value by the 
  current conversion factor.Â  The conversion factor is expressed as a dollar figure 
  and is determinative of the allowable fee paid per procedure.Â  The Regulation 
  provided:

  A.      The â€œSchedule of Fees for Physicians and Surgeonsâ€ 
  (the â€œScheduleâ€) sets forth the criteria for determining a reasonable fee and 
  governs determining the maximum fee chargeable.
  
  (1)      The Occupational Medicine Committee of the 
  South Carolina Medical Association and the Commissionâ€™s Medical Review Division 
  reviews the Schedule annually and recommends to the Commission amendments to 
  the Schedule.
  (2)      The Commission may amend the Schedule as 
  necessary.
  
  B.      The Schedule catalogues and assigns a specific 
  unit value to medical procedures listed by code number. 
  
  (1)      To determine the maximum fee allowed, locate 
  the procedure in the Schedule and determine its unit value.Â  Multiply the unit 
  value by the current conversion factor to determine the maximum fee allowed.
  (2)      If a procedure is to be determined by â€œindividual 
  considerationâ€ or â€œby reportâ€, file a written request with the Commissionâ€™s 
  Medical Review Division for determination of the unit value and fee allowed.
  
  C.      The conversion factor is a variable factor 
  which the Commission periodically amends to keep pace with the economy.Â  Contact 
  the Medical Review Division to obtain the current conversion factor.Â  

In 1995, Respondent adopted a Medicare-patterned 
  Resource Based Relative Value Scale (RBRVS) with a single conversion factor 
  applicable to all procedures, surgical and non-surgical.Â  
Appellants filed this action on June 27, 2000 against 
  Respondent and numerous private insurance companies.Â  Appellants filed an amended 
  complaint on August 28, 2000.Â  Appellants alleged the Respondent violated a 
  statutory duty and denied them equal protection and due process.Â  Specifically, 
  Appellants contended Respondent failed to periodically review and amend the 
  conversion factor to keep pace with the economy.Â  In addition, they argued the 
  RBRVS system, with a single conversion factor for all procedures, surgical and 
  non-surgical, was in violation of equal protection and procedural due process.Â  
  The Appellants also asserted a cause of action against the private insurance 
  companies for unjust enrichment.Â  
The trial court ruled the Appellantsâ€™ cause of 
  action for violation of a statutory duty failed because the statutory authority 
  of the Respondent does not create a private cause of action.Â  It found the Respondent 
  did not violate the Appellantsâ€™ rights to equal protection or due process.Â  
  The trial court also dismissed the claims for unjust enrichment against the 
  private insurance companies.Â  In addition, the court concluded all of Appellantsâ€™ 
  causes of action accrued in 1995 and were barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  This appeal followed.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Appellants do not challenge the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling that their causes of action accrued in 1995 and that they brought this 
  action after either the two-year statute of limitations found in S.C. Code Ann. 
  15-78-110 (Supp. 2003) or the three year statute of limitations found in S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2003).Â  The Appellants instead argue Respondent 
  is equitably estopped from asserting a statute of limitations defense.Â  We find 
  Appellants did not preserve the equitable estoppel issue as it applies to Respondent.Â  
  Appellants did not plead an estoppel issue as to Respondent.Â  The trial courtâ€™s 
  order indicates Appellants argued the insurers were equitably estopped 
  from asserting the statute of limitations defense.Â  However, there is no evidence 
  in the record showing the Appellants argued Respondent was equitably 
  estopped from asserting the defense.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order only addressed 
  the issue of equitable estoppel as it applies to the insurers.Â  In order for 
  an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and 
  ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 
  340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000).Â  Even if the Appellants raised 
  the argument to the trial court that the Respondent should be estopped from 
  asserting the statute of limitations defense, it failed to raise in a post-trial 
  motion the trial courtâ€™s failure to address this issue in its order.Â  Noisette 
  v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding issue was 
  not preserved for appellate review where the trial judge did not explicitly 
  rule on the appellantâ€™s argument and the appellant made no Rule 59(e), SCRCP 
  motion to alter or amend the judgment).Â  As the Appellantsâ€™ estoppel argument 
  is not properly before this court, we may not consider it.Â  
In the very last line of their brief, the Appellants 
  assert â€œthe discovery rule should apply to toll the statute of limitations until 
  the time that the Appellants actually became aware of the duty by the Commission 
  to periodically adjust their fees to keep pace with the economy, which was in 
  the early months of the year 2000.â€Â  This is the Appellantsâ€™ first mention of 
  the discovery rule, which is what they argued to the trial court in response 
  to the Respondentâ€™s assertion that the statute of limitations barred their claim.Â  
  The Appellants did not set forth this argument in their statement of the issues 
  on appeal.Â  We find Appellants failed to properly raise to this court any argument 
  they intended to make concerning the discovery rule. See Rule 208(b)(1)(B), 
  SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set forth in the 
  statement of the issues on appeal.â€); Langehans v. Smith, 347 S.C. 348, 
  352, 554 S.E.2d 681, 683 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating that an issue which is not 
  supported by authority or sufficiently argued is not preserved for appellate 
  review).
The trial courtâ€™s determination that the statute of 
  limitations had run on Appellantsâ€™ claims against the Respondent because they 
  were brought more than three years after they had accrued stands unchallenged 
  and constitutes the law of the case. Â See Charleston Lumber Co. v. 
  Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) Â (stating 
  that as a general rule, an unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of 
  the case and required affirmance.)Â  Accordingly, we must affirm on this ground. 
  [2] Â  
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, JJ., concur.Â  
  

 
   [1]  Although subsequently amended by State Register Volume 21, 
    Issue No. 6, Part 2, effective June 27, 1997, the applicable language at all 
    times pertinent to the present appeal is found in 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 
    67-1304 (1990).

 
   [2]  Due to our conclusion regarding the statute of 
    limitations issue, we do not address the remaining issues on appeal.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
Regina P. Alberti, Guardian Ad Litem for William
Cadden, a Minor Under 
        the Age of Ten (10) Years and William Cadden, a Minor Under the Age of 
        Ten (10) Years,        Appellants,
v.
Catawba Insurance Company,       
Respondent.

Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-129
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Joseph Condon, Jr., of N. Charleston, for Appellants.
Bonum Sams Wilson, III, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Regina Alberti and William Cadden 
  brought a declaratory action against Catawba Insurance Company to determine 
  if uninsured motorist coverage applied to an accidental shooting that took place 
  outside a car with a firearm found in the glove compartment of the car.Â  The 
  trial judge found the uninsured motorist coverage did not apply.Â  We affirm.Â  

FACTS
While Alberti and her grandson 
  William (â€œAppellantsâ€) were visiting George Beard on April 15, 1997, William, 
  age five at the time, entered Beardâ€™s parked car and retrieved a gun from the 
  glove compartment. William was outside the car when the gun discharged, seriously 
  injuring his right hand. Alberti had an insurance policy with Catawba that provided 
  for uninsured motorist coverage. Appellants filed a declaratory judgment action 
  on August 9, 2000 to determine if the UM coverage applied to this accident.Â  
  The parties stipulated that the amount of damages exceeded the liability coverage 
  on the vehicle, and therefore, if there was coverage, Catawba would pay the 
  policy limits of the UM coverage.Â  On March 14, 2002, the trial judge ruled 
  the UM coverage did not apply.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
 ISSUE

Did the trial court err in finding that UM coverage 
  did not apply where the injury resulted from a gun that was retrieved from the 
  glove compartment of Albertiâ€™s car? 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment 
  is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying 
  issue.â€Â  Antley v. Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 621, 625, 567 S.E.2d 872, 
  874 (2002) (citing Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 
  781, 782 (1991)).Â  â€œAn action to determine coverage under an insurance policy 
  is an action at law.â€Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Wilson, 344 
  S.C. 525, 528-29, 544 S.E.2d 848, 849 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œIn an action at law, 
  the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless a 
  review of the record reveals there is no evidence which reasonably supports 
  the judgeâ€™s findings.â€ Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue uninsured motorist coverage 
  should apply to cover Williamâ€™s injuries because Beardâ€™s car was used to store 
  a gun.Â  We disagree.
A party making a claim under a car insurance 
  policy for personal injuries arising out of the â€œownership, maintenance, or 
  useâ€ of a car must meet three requirements: a causal chain between the car and 
  the injury, the absence of an act breaking the causal chain, and the use of 
  the car as transportation at the time of the injury. State Farm Mut. Auto. 
  Ins. Co. v. Bookert, 337 S.C. 291, 293, 523 S.E.2d 181, 182 (1999). There 
  is a causal chain if the car was an active accessory to the injury; if the car 
  was something less than proximate cause, but more than the mere site of the 
  injury; and if the injury is foreseeably identifiable with the normal use of 
  the car. Id.Â  
 No causal connection exists in this case 
  because the record fails to satisfy the three-part test. First, the car was 
  not an active accessory to the injury; it was merely a storage place for the 
  gun.Â  Second, the car was not the situs of the injury, as William was not injured 
  until he was outside the car.Â  Finally, the injury to William, inflicted from 
  a gun retrieved from the glove compartment, is not foreseeably identifiable 
  with the normal use of a car.Â  
Even if a causal link existed between 
  the car and the injury, that link was broken by the self-inflicted nature of 
  the injury. William pulled the trigger after removing the gun from the car. 
  That act was one of independent significance which broke any potential causal 
  connection since the car itself was not used to injure William.Â  As the trial 
  judge explained in his order, â€œ[h]ad the vehicle hit a pothole, causing the 
  gun to discharge and injure the minor Plaintiff, the Court would be faced with 
  a claim of an entirely different nature.â€ Finally, the record clearly demonstrates 
  that the car was not being used for transportation since it was parked at the 
  time of the injury.Â  
The facts of this case are quite different from 
  cases meeting the three-part test, such as Wausau Underwriters Ins. Co. v. 
  Howser, 309 S.C. 269, 422 S.E.2d 106 (1992) and Home Ins. Co. v. Towe, 
  314 S.C. 105, 441 S.E.2d 825 (1994).Â  In Howser, the court held that 
  gunshot injuries sustained during a vehicular chase by an unknown assailant 
  in an unidentified car arose out of the ownership, maintenance, or use of an 
  uninsured automobile.Â  The court stated: 

Only through use of his vehicle was the assailant able to 
  closely pursue Howser, thereby enabling him to carry out the pistol assault. 
  Â The gunshot was the culmination of an ongoing assault, in which the vehicle 
  played an essential and integral part.Â  Additionally, only a motor vehicle could 
  have provided the assailant a quick and successful escape.Â  Thus, we find a 
  sufficient causal connection exists between the use of the assailantâ€™s vehicle 
  and Howserâ€™s injuries. 

Howser, 309 S.C. at 273, 422 S.E.2d at 108. 

As for Towe, the injuries occurred when 
  a bottle thrown from a car struck the victim.Â  The court found the use of the 
  car placed the assailant in the position to throw a bottle, and the carâ€™s speed 
  contributed to the seriousness of the injury.Â  Towe, 314 S.C. at 107, 
  441 S.E.2d at 827.Â  Therefore, the court held the car was an active accessory 
  and a causal connection existed between the use of the car and the injuries.Â  
  Id. at 108, 441 S.E.2d at 827.
The present case more closely resembles State 
  Farm & Cas. Co. v. Aytes, 332 S.C. 30, 503 S.E.2d 744 (1998).Â  There, 
  an assailant used a car to transport the victim to a certain location.Â  Having 
  reached that destination, the assailant went around to the passenger side of 
  the car, intending to harm the victim.Â  The victim retrieved a gun from the 
  glove compartment to defend herself, but the assailant gained control of the 
  gun. The assailant, while standing outside the car, fired the gun toward the 
  victim, who was sitting inside. The victim, an insured passenger, sought UM 
  benefits for the gunshot injuries.Â  Id. at 33, 503 S.E.2d at 746.Â  Although 
  the car was the situs of the injuries, the court found no UM coverage applied 
  because the car was neither an active accessory nor a means of transportation 
  at the time of the injury.Â  In addition, the court stated if there was a causal 
  link, it was broken when the assailant exited the car.Â  Id. at 35, 503 
  S.E.2d at 746.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, the decision of the trial court 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD
NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Brenda Phillips, individually and as shareholder of Personnel Solutions, 
        Inc., a South Carolina Corporation,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William D. Brown, Charles Lee Smith, Robert J.
Burnstein, Express Temps, 
        Inc., Tri Core East, Inc., and Burnstein & Strickland, P.C. and Ruby 
        Cromer,        Defendants,
And
Charles Lee Smith, Robert J. Burnstein, Express Temps, Inc., Tri Core 
        East, Inc., and Burnstein & Strickland, P.C.,       
Third Party Plaintiffs,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kim Whisnant, Personnel Solutions, Inc., Preferred Personnel, Inc. and 
        Staffing Associates, Inc.,        Third Party Defendants,
of whom William D. Brown is the,       
Appellant,
And
Brenda Phillips, individually and as shareholder of Personnel Solutions, 
        Inc., a South Carolina Corporation is the,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-135
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  27, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Matthew A. Henderson and Joshua M. Henderson, both of Spartanburg, 
  for Appellant.
Kenneth C. Anthony, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this â€œbusiness divorce,â€ 
  William D. Brown appeals the special refereeâ€™s valuation of his ownership interest 
  in Personnel Solutions, Inc.Â  (PSI).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Brown and Brenda Phillips met while both 
  were working for Personnel, Inc., a temporary services provider.Â  In 
  1991, they decided to leave Personnel, Inc., and form PSI, their own competing 
  company.Â  Because of the possibility of legal action by their former 
  employer to enforce the non-compete agreements each had signed, PSI was established 
  showing Phillips as the sole shareholder of the corporation. [1] Â  Both parties, however, agreed orally 
  that in reality each held a one-half interest in the business.Â  
After a few years in business, 
  the parties formed Express Temps (ET), which was set up solely in Brownâ€™s name.Â  
  ET was established as a separate company that was to act solely as a â€œpass 
  throughâ€ corporation.Â  The desired result was that permanent employees of PSI 
  would be allowed greater benefits and PSIâ€™s many temporary employees would now 
  be officially employed by ET, which would have much lower workersâ€™ compensation 
  premiums because, as a new company, it had no history of workersâ€™ compensation 
  claims.Â  At this point, PSI, although still in fact the temporary services 
  provider, was on paper merely a management firm with ET as its sole client. 
  [2] 
In October 1995, the company accountant 
  alerted Phillips that Brown had been embezzling money from PSI for some time.Â  
  After confronting Brown, Phillips agreed that, if Brown completed a treatment 
  program for his gambling and other addictions, he could return to PSI although 
  he would have no control over the company finances.Â  The parties further 
  agreed that Phillips would be allowed certain payments over time from the company 
  to her own personal accounts until the disparity between their compensations 
  was eliminated.
After completing the treatment 
  program, Brown attempted to return to work at PSI.Â  According to Phillips, 
  however, because she had learned that the extent of Brownâ€™s embezzlement was 
  much greater than she initially believed, she did not allow him to return to 
  the business.Â  Phillips then established a new corporation, Preferred 
  Personnel, Inc., to essentially take the place of ET.
Brown attempted for a brief time to form his own 
  business under ETâ€™s name; however, Phillips subsequently filed this action and 
  secured a temporary order enjoining all parties to the action from operating 
  under that name.Â  Brown then opened Staffing Associates, a new temporary 
  employment service, and in the process hired approximately one-half of PSIâ€™s 
  employees and took a portion of the customer base of PSI.  
During the course of the litigation, the 
  parties stipulated the issues to be decided at trial were (1) the value of PSI 
  and the appropriate date on which the corporation was to be valued, [3]  and (2) the amount, if any, due from Brown 
  as a result of his embezzlement from PSI.
By order entered March 27, 2002, the special referee 
  determined the value of Brownâ€™s interest in PSI to be $16,920 as of December 
  31, 1995. [4] Â  The special referee also determined 
  that neither party was entitled to damages from the other, having found the 
  amounts Brown embezzled were offset by several large payments made to Phillips 
  from company funds.Â  Brown appeals only the special refereeâ€™s evaluation 
  of his interest, contending error in the weight given to certain expert testimony 
  and the application of certain discounts in stock value.   
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Brown first contends the special referee placed 
  too much weight on the fact that he and Phillips were not bound by a non-compete 
  agreement.Â  We disagree with this argument.
The presence or absence of a covenant not to compete 
  is a valid factor in determining the worth of a service-oriented corporate entity. 
  [5] Â  Here, Brownâ€™s own witnesses acknowledged the detrimental effect of 
  the absence of a non-compete agreement on the attractiveness of PSI to any potential 
  buyers.Â  Moreover, Brownâ€™s own actions in this case best illustrate why 
  such a decrease in value was due and proper.Â  Once prohibited by injunction 
  from interfering with PSI from within, Brown quickly moved into direct competition 
  across the street from the company, taking a substantial number of PSI employees 
  and clients with him.Â  The value of a service-oriented business such as PSI 
  lies in its contacts.Â  The right of a departing owner to take contacts with 
  him and directly compete with his former business most certainly decreases the 
  value of the original corporate entity.
2.Â  Brown argues the special referee erred in assigning 
  too much weight to the testimony of James Forest Joyner, III, Phillipsâ€™s expert 
  witness on the fair market value of PSI and in disregarding the testimony of 
  his own experts.Â  We find no error.Â  Joyner was an experienced certified public 
  accountant, certified financial planner, and certified valuation analyst.Â  
  He testified at length to the three generally accepted approaches to determining 
  the value of a corporate entity, thoroughly explaining his reasoning and methods 
  in determining the value of Brownâ€™s interest in PSI.Â  Joyner presented 
  his opinion on the corporationâ€™s net asset value, income value, and market value, 
  noting the proper weight to assign each varied with the type of business.Â  
  In contrast, althoughÂ  each of Brownâ€™s experts had varying degrees of experience 
  in the field of temporary service providers, one admitted he did not consider 
  himself â€œexactly an expertâ€ and the other was unfamiliar with the valuation 
  approaches that Joyner discussed.Â  We therefore hold the special referee 
  committed no abuse of discretion in weighing the testimony of the various experts. 
  [6] 
3.Â  Brown next contends the special referee erred 
  in applying lack of control and marketability discounts in establishing a fair 
  value for his interest in PSI.Â  In support of his argument, he cites the case 
  of Morrow v. Martschink [7] 
   for the proposition that there are policy reasons against applying minority 
  and marketability discounts to the present situation.Â  We recognize the 
  inequities in applying these discounts to judicial dissolutions; however, we 
  hold it was proper to apply them to the present situation. 
First, although the special referee referenced 
  South Carolina Code section 33-14-310(d)(4), 
  [8]  this is not a true minority shareholderâ€™s or dissenterâ€™s rights case.Â  
  Here, as it was undisputed that the parties were equal shareholders in PSI and 
  had agreed that Phillips would purchase Brownâ€™s interest in PSI, the issue before 
  the special referee was solely the value of that interest.Â  
Second, although Morrow extends the same 
  protection against the application of unfair discounts to a situation that, 
  like this one, falls outside the traditional minority dissenter paradigm, it 
  does so on the basis that many of the same policy concerns apply to close intra-family 
  transactions, â€œwhere a minority interest has been improperly squeezed out of 
  the business.â€ [9] Â  Such factors simply are not 
  present here.Â  We therefore hold the special referee properly applied lack of 
  control and marketability discounts in valuing Brownâ€™s interest in PSI. [10]   
4.Â  Brown further argues the special referee erred 
  in assigning no weight to market value because he considered only the value 
  of PSI as a stand-alone management services company rather than as a temporary 
  services company.Â  Brown further alleges error in the special refereeâ€™s calculation 
  of income value, arguing that Joynerâ€™s analysis, on which the special referee 
  based his calculation, relied on incorrect adjustments to net income and failed 
  to account for bonuses, excessive expenses, and other nonfunctional distributions 
  paid to PSIâ€™s shareholders.Â  These issues are not preserved for appellate 
  review.Â  We did not see any ruling in the appealed order specifically addressing 
  these concerns and Brown did not raise them in a post-trial motion. 
  [11] 
5.Â  We reject Brownâ€™s argument that the special 
  referee erred in assigning too much weight to net asset value. [12] Â  Although Brownâ€™s experts 
  testified that physical assets were generally never used to determine the value 
  of a temporary services company, Joyner stated the income approach, even for 
  a business that had enjoyed substantial income, was unreliable if, as was the 
  case here, a principal of the company could leave at any time and take a substantial 
  portion of the customer base. [13] 
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  The parties believed Phillips, a single mother, would be a more 
    sympathetic defendant in the event of a lawsuit.

 
   [2]  Based on this arrangement, both 
    parties were later indicted for insurance fraud and spent some time in prison.

 
   
    [3] Â  The parties agreed Brownâ€™s interest was fifty per cent of this amount 
    and Phillips would pay him for his shares. 

 
    [4] Â  The special referee 
    found December 31, 1995, was the critical date because 1995 was the last year 
    Brown was actively involved with PSI.Â  Neither party appeals this finding.

 
   
    [5] Â  See McDuffie v. Oâ€™Neal, 324 S.C. 297, 305-06, 476 
    S.E.2d 702, 706 (Ct. App. 1996) (recognizing the negative impact of the absence 
    of a covenant not to compete on the value of a corporation and imposing such 
    a covenant rather than changing the value).

 
   [6]  See 88 C.J.S. Trial 
    Â§ 208 at 415 (1955) (â€œIn weighing evidence the law makes no distinction between 
    expert testimony and evidence of any other character, and it is for the trier 
    of the facts to determine the weight to be given to any evidence.â€), quoted 
    in Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 200, 363 S.E.2d 404, 408 (Ct. 
    App. 1987). 

 
   
    [7] Â  922 F. Supp. 1093 (D.S.C. 1995).

 
   
    [8] Â  This section provides in pertinent part as follows:
  
  (d) In any action filed 
    by a shareholder to dissolve the corporation . . . the court may make such 
    order or grant such relief, other than dissolution, as in its discretion is 
    appropriate, including, without limitation, an order:
  . . . .
    (4) providing for the purchase 
    at their fair value of shares of any shareholder, either by the corporation 
    or by other shareholders.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-310(d)(4) 
    (1990).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [9] Â  Morrow, 922 F. Supp. at 1105 (emphasis added). 

 
   
    [10]  See Belk of Spartanburg v. Thompson, 337 S.C. 109, 
    124, 522 S.E.2d 357, 365 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œAppraisal is not an exact science, 
    and the precise weight to be given to any factor is necessarily a matter of 
    judgment for the court in the light of circumstances in each case.â€) (citing 
    Santee Oil Co. v. Cox, 265 S.C. 270, 277, 217 S.E.2d. 789, 793 (1975)).Â Â  
  

 
   
    [11]  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 
    122, 124 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule 
    on a question and the appellant fails to make a motion under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, 
    to amend or alter the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before 
    the court of appeals and should not be addressed).

 
   
    [12]  Although the special referee â€œaccepted, for the most part, the valuation 
    analysis undertaken by Joyner,â€ he â€œadjusted . . . the relative weights given 
    by Joyner using the income and asset approaches,â€ assigning a weight of fifty 
    per cent to each, as opposed to Joynerâ€™s decision to assign ten per cent to 
    income and ninety per cent to the assets of PSI.

 
   
    [13]  See Santee Oil Co. v. Cox , 265 S.C. 270, 273, 217 
    S.E.2d. 789, 791 (1975) (noting â€œâ€˜fair valueâ€™ does not restrict the appraising 
    court to the use of any one method of valuationâ€).
